{{Infobox recurring event | name = 1940s World War II Era Ball | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | status = Active | genre = [[Historical reenactment]] [[ball (dance)|ball]] | date = <!--"dates=" also works, but do not use both--> | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | venue = [[Boulder Municipal Airport|Boulder Airport]] | location = [[Boulder, Colorado]] | country = [[United States]] | years_active = 2008 - present | founder_name = T. Khyentse James | last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | patron = | website = {{URL|http://www.1940sball.org/}} | footnotes = }} '''1940s World War II Era Ball''' is an annual [[historical reenactment]] event in [[Boulder, Colorado]].<ref name=boulderweekly.com>{{cite web|url=http://boulderweekly.com/archives/20090611/overtones.html|title=Having a ball|author=Adam Perry|work=Boulder Weekly|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradodaily.com/ci_15204670|title=1940s World War II Ball goes to new heights in second year|author=Aimee Heckel|work=Colorado Daily|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timescall.com/lifestyles/entertainment/ci_20777142/1940s-wwii-era-ball-transports-attendees-old-styles|title=1940s WWII Era Ball to transport attendees with old styles, music, dance|author=Quentin Young|work=Times-Call|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> The event is a [[ball (dance)|ball]], which features [[swing music]] from the 1940s and [[impersonator]]s of musicians and entertainers such as [[Bob Hope]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Judy Garland]] and the [[Andrews Sisters]].<ref name=westword.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.westword.com/2010-06-17/calendar/period-piece/|title=Period Piece|work=Denver Westword|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westword.com/2012-06-14/calendar/play-it-sam/|title=Play It, Sam|author=Amber Taufen|work=Denver Westword|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> The ball is held in a hangar at the [[Boulder Municipal Airport|Boulder Airport]] and features [[World War II]]-era airplanes including [[Beechcraft Model 18|C-45 Expeditors]] and [[North American B-25 Mitchell|B-25 Mitchells]].<ref name=boulderweekly.com/><ref name=westword.com/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gazette.com/our-pick-world-war-ii-era-ball-in-boulder/article/119577|title=OUR PICK: World War II Era Ball in Boulder|author=Joy Harper|work=The Gazette|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> The ball also holds an annual 1940s White Christmas Ball.<ref name=huffingtonpost.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/10/1940s-christmas-ball-at-w_n_2274024.html|title=1940s Christmas Ball At Wings Over The Rockies Air And Space Museum Sells Out On Pearl Harbor Anniversary|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> Net proceeds from the event are donated to local charities including those that support World War II veterans and the preservation of aviation history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://generalaviationnews.com/2012/05/24/1940s-ball-at-boulder-airport/|title=1940′s Ball at Boulder Airport|author=Janice Wood|work=General Aviation News|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref>
The 1940s World War II Era Ball was first held in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kdvr.com/2012/06/15/boulders-world-war-ii-era-ball-a-trip-back-in-time/|title=Boulder World War II Ball a trip back in time|author=Dan Daru|work=FOX 31|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> The ball was founded by Khyentse James, who previously founded the [[Estrojam's Decibelle Music and Culture Festival|Decibelle Music and Culture Festival]].<ref name=boulderweekly.com/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-04-02/entertainment/ct-ott-0402-gay-rock-20100402_1_queer-band-members-gary-airedale|title=We're here, we're queer, we rock|author=Lauren R. Harrison|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref> The ball was created in honor of James' grandparents, who were radio performers and met while they were working at a radio station together in the 1940s.<ref name=huffingtonpost.com/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://askmissa.com/2011/08/10/1940s-wwii-era-ball-khyentse-james-takes-a-sentimental-journey/|title=1940′s WWII Era Ball: Khyentse James Takes A Sentimental Journey|author=Shannon Wolfe|work=Ask Miss A|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/recommended/ci_20798091|title=1940s World War II Era Ball: Boulder Airport site of June 16 1940s-era annual ball celebration|work=Denver Post|accessdate=April 12, 2014}}</ref>
In 2016, the ball expanded to two nights for its eighth annual event. The theme was "Our Troops Bring Home Paradise: A Tiki Explosion" and included car shows, film screenings and other events.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.wyomingnews.com/entertainment/take-a-step-back-in-time-at-this-s-themed/article_22b4d7ac-2dad-11e6-9acb-838f2400ec84.html | title = Take a step back in time at this 1940s-themed dance in Boulder | work = Wyoming Tribune Eagle | author = Ellen Fike | date = 11 June 2016 | access-date = 26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.dailycamera.com/entertainment/ci_30020786/1940s-wwii-era-ball-boulder-celebrates-simpler-times | title = 1940s WWII Era Ball in Boulder celebrates simpler times | work = Daily Camera | author = A.H. Goldstein | date = 17 June 2016 | access-date = 26 October 2016}}</ref>

10.0 }} '''21900 Orus''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|oʊr|ə|s}} {{Respell|OHR|əs}}), provisional designation ''{{mp|1999 VQ|10}}'', is a [[Jupiter trojan]] from the [[Greek camp]], approximately {{convert|53|km|mi|abbr=off|sigfig=2|sp=us}} in diameter, and a target of the [[Lucy (spacecraft)|''Lucy'' mission]] to be visited in November 2028. The dark Jovian [[asteroid]] belongs to the [[#Largest Jupiter trojans|100 largest Jupiter trojans]] and has a [[rotation period]] of 13.5 hours. It was discovered on 9 November 1999, by Japanese amateur astronomer [[Takao Kobayashi]] at his private [[Ōizumi Observatory]] in Gunma Prefecture, Japan, and later named after the [[Achaeans (Homer)|Achaean]] warrior [[Orus (disambiguation)|Orus]] from Greek mythology. == Orbit and classification == ''Orus'' is a dark Jovian [[asteroid]] orbiting in the leading Greek camp at Jupiter's {{L4}} [[Lagrangian point]], 60[[degree (angle)|°]] ahead of the Gas Giant's orbit in a [[Orbital resonance|1:1 resonance]] {{cross reference|(see [[Trojans in astronomy]])}}. It is also a non-[[Asteroid family|family]] asteroid in the [[background asteroid|Jovian background population]]. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 4.9–5.3 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 11 years and 7 months (4,240 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 5.13 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.04 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 8[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with a [[precovery]], published by the [[Digitized Sky Survey]] and taken at [[Palomar Observatory]] in November 1951, or 48 years prior to its official discovery observation. == ''Lucy'' mission target == ''Orus'' is planned to be visited by the [[Lucy (spacecraft)|''Lucy'' spacecraft]] which will launch in 2021. The fly by is scheduled for 20 November 2028, and will approach the asteroid to a distance of 1000 kilometers at a velocity of 7.1 kilometers per second. The mission's targets with their flyby dates are:https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2017/pdf/2025.pdf * [[52246 Donaldjohanson]] — 20 April 2025: 4 km diameter C-type asteroid in the inner main-belt, member of ~130Myr old Erigone family; * [[3548 Eurybates]] — 12 August 2027: 64 km diameter C-type Jupiter Trojan in the Greek camp at {{L4}}, largest member of the only confirmed disruptive collisional family in the Trojans; * [[15094 Polymele]] — 15 September 2027: 21 km diameter P-type Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}, likely collisional fragment; * [[11351 Leucus]] — 18 April 2028: 34 km diameter D-type [[List of slow rotators (minor planets)|slow rotator]] Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}; * '''{{mp|21900 Orus}}''' — 11 November 2028: 51 km diameter D-type Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}; * [[617 Patroclus]] — 2 March 2033: P-type [[binary asteroid|binary]] Trojan. The primary, Patroclus, has a mean diameter of 113 km and its companion, Menoetius, has a diameter of 104 km. The pair orbit at a separation of 680 km. The binary resides in the [[Trojan camp]] at {{L5}}. == Physical characteristics == ''Orus'' is characterized as a [[D-type asteroid|D-type]] and [[C-type asteroid]] by the ''Lucy'' mission team and by [[PanSTARRS]] photometric survey, respectively. It has a [[Asteroid color indices|V–I]] color index of 0.95, seem among most larger D-type Jupiter trojans. === Lightcurve === The first photometric observations of ''Orus'' have been made in October 2009, by astronomer [[Stefano Mottola]] in a photometric [[lightcurve]] survey of 80 Jupiter trojans, using the 1.2-meter telescope at [[Calar Alto Observatory]]. The obtained rotational lightcurve rendered a [[rotation period|period]] of {{val|13.45|0.08}} hours with a brightness variation of 0.18 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=2]]}}). In 2016, Mottola published a revised rotation period of {{val|13.48617|0.00007|ul=h}}, from ground-based observations taken over five apparitions in support of the ''Lucy'' mission. He finds that Orus is a retrograde rotator. The lightcurve suggests the presence of a large crater in the proximity of its north pole. === Diameter and albedo === According to the surveys carried out by the Japanese [[Akari (satellite)|Akari]] satellite and the [[NEOWISE]] mission of NASA's [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]], the body has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.083 and 0.075, with a diameter of 53.87 and 50.81 kilometers, respectively. The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes a standard albedo for carbonaceous C-type asteroids of 0.057 and calculates a diameter of 55.67 kilometers with an [[absolute magnitude]] of 10.0. {{Largest Jupiter trojans}} == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named from [[Greek mythology]] after Orus, an [[Achaeans (Homer)|Achaean]] warrior in Homer's ''[[Iliad]]''. He was killed in the [[Trojan War]] by the Trojan prince [[Hector]], after whom the largest Jupiter trojan [[624 Hektor]] is named. The approved naming citation was published by the [[Minor Planet Center]] on 22 February 2016 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 98711}}). == See also == * [[Discovery program]] == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-05-08 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 21900 Orus (1999 VQ10) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2021900 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 17 June 2018}} {{cite web |title = 21900 Orus (1999 VQ10) |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=21900 |accessdate = 17 June 2018}} {{cite web |title = List of Jupiter Trojans |work = Minor Planet Center |first3 = V. |last3 = Carruba |date = 1 June 2018 |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/JupiterTrojans.html |accessdate = 17 June 2018}} {{cite web |title = MPC/MPO/MPS Archive |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/MPCArchive_TBL.html |accessdate = 17 June 2018}} {{cite web |title = NASA announces five Discovery proposals selected for further study |first1 = Casey |last1 = Dreier |first2 = Emily |last2 = Lakdawalla |publisher = The Planetary Society |date = 30 September 2015 |url = http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2015/09301336-discovery-downselect.html |accessdate = 1 February 2016}} {{Cite journal |first1 = H. {{italic title}} '''''9 Circles''''' is a [[play (theatre)|play]] by [[Bill Cain]] based on the military career and subsequent civilian trial of murderer [[Steven Dale Green]].<ref name=AmericaMagazine9Circles/><ref name=ChicagoTribune2013-09-18/><ref name=DenverPost2012-01-19/><ref name=ChicagoNow2013-09-07/><ref name=ToonariPost2013-03-20/><ref name=MDTheatreGuide2013-02-13/><ref name=DCTheatreScene2013-02-13/><ref name=Westword/><ref name=Boston/><ref name=Wapo2013-02-18/><ref name=Nytimes2017-02-17/><ref name=TimeSquare2017-03-17/>
Cain is a [[Jesuit priest]].<ref name=AmericaMagazine9Circles/><ref name=ChicagoTribune2013-09-18/> The play's title refers to [[Dante Alighieri]]'s [[Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]—in which Dante navigates a descent into the "nine circles of hell". In Cain's play, Green passes through his discharge from the Army and various judicial and administrative procedures, roughly paralleling the nine circles of Dante's ''Inferno''. Cain structured the play so other cast members would return to play multiple characters, at each different circle.
The play won praise for being nuanced, and not taking the easy path of demonizing the protagonist.<ref name=AmericaMagazine9Circles/><ref name=ChicagoTribune2013-09-18/><ref name=DenverPost2012-01-19/><ref name=ChicagoNow2013-09-07/><ref name=ToonariPost2013-03-20/><ref name=MDTheatreGuide2013-02-13/><ref name=DCTheatreScene2013-02-13/><ref name=Westword/><ref name=Boston/><ref name=Wapo2013-02-18/><ref name=Nytimes2017-02-17/><ref name=TimeSquare2017-03-17/> However, [[Chris Jones (reviewer)|Chris Jones]], reviewing a [[Chicago]] production of the play, reported that audience members concluded the play meant to imply that Green, who was originally from [[Midland, Texas]], which had been [[United States President]] [[George W. Bush]]'s primary home, had the assistance of the President himself in clearing his entry into the Army in spite of his criminal record.<ref name=ChicagoTribune2013-09-18/>
The play is receiving its Texas premiere in San Antonio, Texas with The Surround Project's production in June 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesurroundproject.com|title=(no title) |website=www.thesurroundproject.com |language=en-US |access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref>
The script won the [[Steinberg Award]].<ref>[https://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/story/news/local/door-co/entertainment/2018/02/12/third-avenue-playhouse-opens-winter-play-reading-festival/331652002/ Third Avenue Playhouse opens Winter Play Reading Festival]</ref> Cain is the only playwright to have two plays win this award two years in a row.
==References== {{Reflist| refs= <ref name=TimeSquare2017-03-17> {{cite news | url = http://t2conline.com/nine-circles-portrait-of-an-iraqi-killer/ | title = Nine Circles Portrait of an Iraqi Killer | work = Time Square Chronicles | author = Suzanna Bowling | date = 2017-03-17 | page = | location = | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = 2018-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = War is psychologically damaging and like parking tickets or speeding tickets given out just to make their quota, recruters should not pad their numbers with psychologically unfit people and not expect criminal activity. }} </ref>
</ref>
<ref name=Nytimes2017-02-17> {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/27/theater/9-circles-review.html | title = Review: ‘9 Circles,’ a Soldier’s Story (and the Damage Done) | work = [[New York Times]] | date = 2017-02-17 | author = Laura Collins-Hughes | accessdate = 2018-02-13 | quote = In Bill Cain’s “9 Circles,” a contemporary morality play inspired by Dante’s “The Divine Comedy,” the psychic damage of war does not belong to Reeves alone, and neither do the responsibilities of conscience. }} </ref>
<ref name=Wapo2013-02-18> {{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/theater_dance/9-circles-offers-a-thoughtful-but-unemotional-descent-into-cruelty-of-war/2013/02/15/0463cbd2-7794-11e2-8f84-3e4b513b1a13_story.html | title = ‘9 Circles’ offers a thoughtful but unemotional descent into cruelty of war | work = [[Washington Post]] | date = 2013-02-18 | author = Celia Wren | accessdate = 2018-02-13 | quote = The intense tete-a-tetes — which offer occasional moments of humor — tease out provocative questions about war, justice, guilt and America’s possible exploitation of its troops. <!-- Was the invasion of Iraq a just use of force? Do we all have the same capacity for evil? Is psychological normalcy a detriment for a soldier? (Echoes of “Catch-22” here.) And especially: Isn’t it incongruous, and perhaps morally dishonest, to quibble about the military code of conduct amid the organized carnage that is war? --> }} </ref>
<ref name=AmericaMagazine9Circles> {{cite news | url = http://americamagazine.org/content/all-things/9-circles | title = 9 Circles | publisher = [[America (Jesuit magazine)|America]] | author = John Coleman | date = 2010-11-09 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307030217/http://americamagazine.org/content/all-things/9-circles | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = Jesuit playwright Bill Cain S.J., has penned a new and searingly powerful play. Just a year after his earlier successful play about the gun powder plot, Equivocation (see my review), Cain portrays in his new play, 9 Circles, a character, Daniel Reeves, as a disturbed 19-year-old snarled in the web of war. Cain's drama mirrors, through a fictional adaptation, the 2006 Iraq slayings and, subsequent, gang rape of a 14-year-old girl by United States troops. Like the real life Pvt. Steven Dale Green who, partially, serves as the prototype for Cain's Reeves and now awaits life prison without parole for his war crime, the fictional Reeves displays an 'anti-social personality disorder'. }} </ref> <ref name=ChicagoTribune2013-09-18> {{cite news | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-09-18/entertainment/ct-ent-0919-circles-review-20130918_1_war-zone-trouble-woyzeck | title = Looking for trouble in a war zone in '9 Circles' | publisher = [[Chicago Tribune]] | author = [[Chris Jones (reviewer)|Chris Jones]] | date = 2013-09-18 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140306180439/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-09-18/entertainment/ct-ent-0919-circles-review-20130918_1_war-zone-trouble-woyzeck | archivedate = 2014-03-06 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = Or maybe that should be what a man can do to a war. "9 Circles" revolves around a central character, Private Daniel Reeves (Andrew Goetten), who already has been in plenty of trouble before he walks into the office of a recruiting officer looking for soldiers to go to Iraq. Cain's point, surely, is that Daniel, who goes on to commit horrible crimes that appall even the judicial system set up to process and try him, is precisely the wrong kind of man to be allowed to carry military-grade weaponry. The stresses of war, the play argues, could send anyone over the edge. When starting with a guy wound tight enough to burst his own blood-vessels, the smart leader would anticipate trouble. }} </ref> <ref name=DenverPost2012-01-19> {{cite news | url = http://www.denverpost.com/ci_19770102 | title = Theater review: Curious' "9 Circles" questions U.S. involvement in Iraq | publisher = [[Denver Post]] | author = Terry Frei | date = 2012-01-19 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307031312/http://www.denverpost.com/ci_19770102 | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = "9 Circles" is based on the infamous case of former 101st Airborne Division Pfc. Steven Dale Green, convicted in a federal court in 2009 of raping and killing an Iraqi 14-year-old girl and murdering her family. (Green's sentence, life in prison, was different than that of Reeves in the play.) }} </ref> <ref name=ChicagoNow2013-09-07> {{cite news | url = http://www.chicagonow.com/the-fourth-walsh/2013/09/9-circles-sideshow-theatre-must-be-seen/ | title = "9 Circles" (Sideshow Theatre): Must Be Seen | publisher = [[Chicago Now]] | author = Katy Walsh | date = 2013-09-07 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307031307/http://www.chicagonow.com/the-fourth-walsh/2013/09/9-circles-sideshow-theatre-must-be-seen/ | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = Playwright Bill Cain’s story is set in 2006 Iraq but it could as easily be 2013 Syria. The play’s underlying questions of ‘what is the USA doing? And why?’ are timely to today’s government debates. Cain plots a soldier’s persecution for horrific war crimes as the 9 circles of Dante’s “Inferno.” A troubled nineteen year old is recruited by the military. His stint is marred by extracurricular war activities. Now, he is the focal point for the rage of the nationS. He is *the* enemy, both foreign and domestic. }} </ref> <ref name=ToonariPost2013-03-20> {{cite news | url = http://www.toonaripost.com/2013/03/life-style/9-circles-by-bill-cain-review/ | title = 9 Circles by Bill Cain Review | publisher = [[Toonari Post]] | author = Jason Loch | date = 2013-03-20 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307031301/http://www.toonaripost.com/2013/03/life-style/9-circles-by-bill-cain-review/ | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = From that point on, Reeves is on a downward spiral. He ends up in jail, accused of raping a 14-year old Iraqi girl and killing her along with her entire family. As he waits for a judge to decide his fate, he encounters various people who allegedly want to help him, from an enigmatic army lawyer (William Bolz) to a pastor with a penchant for internet porn (Whitney Derendinger). In a way, they play the role of Virgil to Reeves’ Dante, and each one of them helps guide Reeves along the path to self-discovery. }} </ref> <ref name=MDTheatreGuide2013-02-13> {{cite news | url = http://www.mdtheatreguide.com/2013/02/theatre-review-9-circles-at-forum-theatre | title = Theatre Review: ’9 Circles’ at Forum Theatre | publisher = [[Maryland Theatre Guide]] | author = Roger Catlin | date = 2013-02-13 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130217032322/http://www.mdtheatreguide.com/2013/02/theatre-review-9-circles-at-forum-theatre | archivedate = 2013-02-17 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = 9 Circles is inspired by an actual case, that of former 101st Airborne Division Pfc. Steven Dale Green, convicted in federal court in 2009 for raping and killing a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and murdering her family. }} </ref> <ref name=DCTheatreScene2013-02-13> {{cite news | url = http://dctheatrescene.com/2013/02/14/9-circles/ | title = 9 Circles | publisher = [[DC Theatre Scene]] | author = Ben Demers | date = 2013-02-13 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307031630/http://dctheatrescene.com/2013/02/14/9-circles/ | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = Private Daniel Edward Reeves, played by the astonishing Julian Elijah Martinez, stands accused of heinous crimes in Iraq. Reeves is trapped onstage in a concentric limbo of military tribunals, therapy sessions, and jail cells, dressed in stark white scenery by Klyph Stanford and lit in harsh tones by Dan Covey. }} </ref> <ref name=Westword> {{cite news | url = http://www.westword.com/2012-01-19/culture/9-circles-mahmudiyah-killings-play/full/ | title = Based on Iraq War atrocities, 9 Circles is clear-eyed and tightly written | publisher = [[Denver Westword Arts]] | author = Juliet Whitman | date = 2012-01-19 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307031610/http://www.westword.com/2012-01-19/culture/9-circles-mahmudiyah-killings-play/full/ | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = I was ambivalent about seeing Curious Theatre's regional premiere of Bill Cain's 9 Circles, whose plot tracks very closely with Green's known actions and experiences. <!-- Publicity implied the play would involve some kind of revelatory understanding on the part of the protagonist, here called Daniel Reeves, perhaps even his redemption — though no one actually used this word. It was an idea I fiercely resisted: Green's crime seemed beyond redemption. And all the usual explanations offered in these circumstances — the fog of war; the insanity caused by witnessing the death of fellow soldiers; a government that sends impoverished and sometimes unstable young men into battle; endless television propaganda about a clash of civilizations between Christianity and Islam (propaganda that both the real life Green and the fictive Reeves believed); the methods by which the Army turns recruits into killers, in part by convincing them that the enemy is subhuman — all of these faltered in the face of its viciousness and enormity. I kept remembering the dying Nazi who begged Simon Wiesenthal, as a representative of the Jewish faith, to forgive him. Only the dead could grant such forgiveness, Wiesenthal said. Or perhaps in Green's case, only Abeer's little brothers, who came home from school to a scene of blood and fire. --> }} </ref> <ref name=Boston> {{cite news | url = http://timeoutboston.com/arts-culture/theater/90753/review-9-circles | title = Review: 9 Circles | publisher = [[Time Out Boston]] | author = | date = | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140307035208/http://timeoutboston.com/arts-culture/theater/90753/review-9-circles | archivedate = 2014-03-07 | accessdate = 2014-03-06 | deadurl = No | quote = With all the action of the show staged on a claustrophobic circular plinth, 9 Circles takes us through a wretched year in the life of an Iraq War vet. We follow Private Daniel Reeves through a series of holding cells and psychiatrists’ offices, as he is indicted for a war crime he allegedly committed while in Iraq. Amanda Collins and Will McGarrahan play a slew of lawyers, military personnel and other authority figures who come to vie for possession of Reeves’s soul. }} </ref> }}
[[Category:2010 plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:American plays]] [[Category:Works based on poems]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film festival | name = ASVOFF | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = ASVOFF- A Shaded View On Fashion Film.jpg | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = | telephone = | founded = | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = | number = | date = | language = | website = {{URL|www.asvoff.com}} | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''A Shaded View on Fashion Film (ASVOFF)''' is the first annual festival in the world about fashion films.
Created by journalist Diane Pernet and launched in September 2008 as a three-day event at the national museum of Paris, Jeu de Paume, ASVOFF which took the form of a full festival showcasing feature films, documentaries, conferences, performances and installations. Pioneering, having brought together names such as [[Mike Figgis]], [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]], [[Erwin Olaf]], [[Nobuyoshi Araki]], [[WIng Shya]], [[Steven Klein (photographer)|Steven Klein]], [[Chris Cunningham]], [[Chloë Sevigny]], Ruth Hogben, Georgie Greville, Elisha Smith-Leverock, Waris Ahluwalla, Maison [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Nick Knight (photographer)|Nick Knight]], [[Johan Renck]], [[Jerry Schatzberg]], [[William Klein (photographer)|William Klein]], [[Tim Yip]], [[Larry Clark]], [[Ellen Von Unwerth]], [[Bruce Weber (photographer)|Bruce Weber]], [[Inez van Lamsweerde]] & Vinoodh Matadin, [[Indrani]], [[Rossy de Palma]], Michael Nyman and welcomed by: Centre Pompidou, Jeu de Paume, Milano's Palazzo Morando, FIAF, NYC, Festival du nouveau cinema Montreal, CPH-DOX, Barbican Art Gallery, Guggenheim, Bilbao, Pica Contemporary Art Museum, Perth with the support of Italian Vogue, Bvlgari, Dom Perignon, FIAF and Kering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ashadedviewonfashionfilm.com/archives |title=archives |publisher=A Shaded View on Fashion Film |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref>
Diane Pernet's first degree was in documentary film making at [[Temple University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoomagazine.de/the_magazine/contributors/ |title=Zoo Magazine |publisher=Zoomagazine.de |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110722142221/http://www.zoomagazine.de/the_magazine/contributors/| archivedate= 22 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and she has been making small low-fi movies for years. She also worked as a [[costume designer]] for, amongst others, director [[Amos Gitai]]. So the founder of ASVOFF knows how important fashion is in a film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fashionista.com/2010/08/diane-pernet-on-tavi-fashion-film-and-the-future-of-catwalks/ |title=Diane Pernet on Tavi, Fashion Film, and the Future of Catwalks – Fashionista: Fashion Industry News, Designers, Runway Shows, Style Advice |publisher=Fashionista.com |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=2 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110721062420/http://fashionista.com/2010/08/diane-pernet-on-tavi-fashion-film-and-the-future-of-catwalks/| archivedate= 21 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Places == Besides its annual festival in Paris in September, ASVOFF has other projects around the world.
Other places on the ASVOFF list<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ashadedviewonfashionfilm.com/about |title=about |publisher=A Shaded View on Fashion Film |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref> * Jeu de paume (premiere) * Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (SPAIN) * Centre Pompidou (Paris) * Palais des Festival (Cannes, France) * Museum of Fine Arts (Boston, USA) * West Bund Art Center (Shanghai, CHINA) * Shanghai Himalays Museum (Shanghai, CHINA) * Power Station of Art (Shanghai, CHINA) * China Academy of Art Shanghai Institute of Design (CHINA) * Gene Siskel Film Center (Chicago, USA) * Palazzo Morando, [[Milano]], with [[Vogue Italia]], * Scope Art Fair in New York, with films by [[Michael Nyman]] * Cinema Rise X in Tokyo, * [[Chelsea Arts Club]] in London, * [[Barbican Art Gallery]] in London, * [[Mexico City]], with Trendsétera, * [[Hyères]] International Festival of Fashion and Photography, * [[Rome]], with AltaRoma, * [[Kiev]], with Elle Ukraine * [[Seoul]], Daily Projects * [[Riga]], with Moments, * [[Vienna]] 9 Festival, * [[Copenhagen]], with CPH DOX, * [[Amsterdam]], with MASS, * [[Cluj]], with Transylvania National Theatre * [[Moscow]], Russian Fashion Week, * Cine Opera at Corso Como, Milan, with films by Michael Nyman * [[Miami]], with Art Basel * [[Cannes Film Festival]], Villa Schweppes on Croisette * [[Saint Petersburg]], Aurora Fashion Week * [[London]], with Barbarican Art Gallery * [[Łódź]], LODZ Fashion Philosophy Week * [[Tbilisi]], Georgian Fashion Week, * [[Munich]], with ABSOLUTE Creatives, * [[Antwerp]], with MoMu at MUSE, * [[Montreal]], Festival du Nouveau Cinema, * [[Arnhem]], Arnhem Biennale * [[Athens]], with Fashion Workshop by Vicky Kaya Fashion on Screen * [[Venice]], Venice International Short Film Festival * [[Minsk]], Belarus Fashion Week * [[Vienna]], with Frame (0)ut, Museum Quarter, * [[Barcelona]], with CaixaForum * [[Vladivostok]], with the Ministry of Culture of Russia & Aurora Fashion Week * [[Mexico City]], Museo Franz Mayer * [[Paris]], in collaboration with Champs-Élysées Film Festival * [[Paris]], la Gaîté lyrique *(Bulgaria) Nuboyana Film Studios *(Paris) Palais Brongniart
== History == Mark Eley of [[Eley Kishimoto]] commissioned her to make a road movie for the launch of his new [[Fashion|menswear]] line.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2006/aug/13/observerreview.onlinesupplement1?INTCMP=SRCH |title=Celebrity surfers | Technology | The Observer |publisher=Guardian |date= 13 August 2006|accessdate=2 August 2011 |location=London}}</ref> It was a short film that documented his participation in the GUMBALL 3000 which was a car race that went from London to [[Monte Carlo]]. The 18-minute film was called The Adventure of Pleasure.<ref>[http://www.gumball3000.com/videos/detail/95?page=1 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125152731/http://www.gumball3000.com/videos/detail/95?page=1 |date=25 November 2010 }}</ref>
She showed the film to Dino Dinco, her Los Angeles collaborator at the time and he asked her if she wanted to screen it in LA. A day later EGR (Enrique Gonzalez Rangel), her Mexico City contributor, sent her a fashion film that he made and Pernet posted it on her blog. The idea to create a travelling fashion film festival had been on the back burner for years before Pernet showed Adventure of Pleasure to Dinco. The name "You Wear It Well," was based on a Rod Stewart song. The first fashion film festival, "You Wear It Well," launched in August 2006, premiering in Los Angeles at Cinespace. Dinco and Pernet arranged a second edition of "You Wear It Well" in 2007.<ref name="blogspot1">[http://fashionheroines.blogspot.com/2010/05/diane-pernet-talks-about-blogging.html ]{{dead link|date=August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2006/08/you_wear_it_wel.html |title=Diane, A Shaded View on Fashion: You Wear it Well's first prize winner in Copenhagen was Jeremy Scott's Starring |publisher=Dianepernet.typepad.com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819085842/http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2006/08/you_wear_it_wel.html# |archivedate=19 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Besides the work of Diane Pernet and EGR, You Wear It Well featured video creations from [[Maison Martin Margiela]], [[Nick Knight (photographer)|Nick Knight]]/[[Alexander McQueen]], [[Jeremy Scott]], Bernhard Willhelm, Marcelo Krasilcic, [[Jean-Charles de Castelbajac]], NOKI and Ruben Toledo.<ref>http://dianepernet.typepad.com/photos/uncategorized/ywiwpostersf.jpg</ref>
In November 2007 Diane Pernet also co-curated the NOOVO fashion and photography festival in Santiago de Compostela. "You Wear It Well" was dissolved in 2007 when Pernet with the support of her current producer, David Herman, took the festival from a one-day program to a three-day program and to make it an extension of the ASVOF blog, hence the name ASVOFF (A Shaded View on Fashion Film). In September 2008, ASVOFF was launched in Paris at Jeu de Paume.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeudepaume.org/?page=article&sousmenu=102&idArt=807&lieu=7 |title=A Shaded View on Fashion Film |publisher=Jeu de Paume |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718025534/http://www.jeudepaume.org/?page=article&sousmenu=102&idArt=807&lieu=7| archivedate= 18 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Editions== ===2008=== ====Jury List==== * Danièle Hibon, President of the Jury: Director of the Cinema Department of Le Jeu de Paume. Previously supervised Le Bureau d'Accompagnement de l'Avance sur Recettes at the Centre National de la Cinématographie. Since 1995 she has been organizing cinematic workshops for art-school students<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2008/09/asvoff-the-jury.html |title=Diane, A Shaded View on Fashion: ASVOFF-the Jury deliberation |publisher=Dianepernet.typepad.com |date=22 September 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926233147/http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2008/09/asvoff-the-jury.html# |archivedate=26 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Magali Aubert: She founded Standard magazine in 2003. Her role as Editor-in-Chief of the magazine makes every artistic field her forte. * Hélène Segol: [[Music video producer]] at Wanda, one of the top ad & music video production companies in the world. * Laurent Goumarre: Producer of the Radio-show Minuit Dix. * Eric Tong Cuong: Co-founder of advertising mega-agency BETC, co-founder of enduring [[music label]] Naïve, Eric is now running his latest adventure – the pluridisciplinary advertising agency La Chose.
====Prize Categories==== *ASVOFF Grand Prize: Jenny Haniver by Camille Vivier *Special Mention: Video Look Book by Jeremy Scott * Public Prize winner of the first edition of A Shaded View On Fashion Film at [[Jeu de Paume]] was "The Pattern Film" by Anemone Skjoldager<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2008/09/asvoff---the-wi.html |title=Diane, A Shaded View on Fashion: ASVOFF – the winner of the public prize |publisher=Dianepernet.typepad.com |date=29 September 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926233142/http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2008/09/asvoff---the-wi.html# |archivedate=26 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===2009=== The festival moved to Passage du Désir/ BETC, followed by an award ceremony held at [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris with jury president Rick Owens. Due to the growing size of the selection, it was separated in two sections – Reflection (directors vision of fashion) and Communication (communication of one brand/designer). ====Jury List==== * [[Rick Owens]] President:<ref>{{cite web |author=diane pernet |url=http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2009/09/asvoff-2-jury-meeting.html |title=Diane, A Shaded View on Fashion: ASVOFF 2 jury meeting |publisher=Dianepernet.typepad.com |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625085332/http://dianepernet.typepad.com/diane/2009/09/asvoff-2-jury-meeting.html# |archivedate=25 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Eric Tong Cuong * Laurent Gaumarre * Nan Goldin * Maria de Mederios * Helene Segol
====Prize Categories ==== On 8 October, the Jury headed by Rick Owens<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/rick-owens-honored-at-fashion-film-festival-winners-announced-1800768.html |title=Rick Owens honored at fashion film festival, winners announced – Fashion, Life & Style |publisher=The Independent |date=10 October 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2011 |location=London}}</ref> handed out awards for the ASVOFF 2009 Fashion Film competition: * Public Prize: "Herr Rodebjer Part I" by Mattias Montero for Rodebjer * DailyMotion Winner: "HLH: Autumn Winter 2509 BC" by Claire Kurylowski & Jason Bradbury for Harald Lunde Helgesen * Jury Prize, Reflection Section: "Fiction Noir" by [[Steven Klein (photographer)|Steven Klein]], starring [[Lara Stone]] * Jury Prize, Communication Section: "[[Gareth Pugh]] AW09" by Ruth Hogben for Gareth Pugh * Jury Prize, Communication Section: "[[Matthew Williamson]]" by Johan Renck for [[H&M]] * Grand Prix [[Samsung]]: "I Wanna Be Your Dog" by Georgie Greville
===2010=== The festival took place on 24, 25 and 26 September at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris, with running installations of the festival's competition films held at the BETC's Passage du Desir from 25–28 September.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.it/en/talents/vogue-video-lab/2010/07/a-shaded-view-on-fashion-film-n-3 |title='A Shaded View on Fashion Film' |publisher=Vogue.it |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111828/http://www.vogue.it/en/talents/vogue-video-lab/2010/07/a-shaded-view-on-fashion-film-n-3# |archivedate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
For this edition Diane Pernet worked together with the young fashion blogger [[Tavi Gevinson]].<ref>{{cite web|author=—Sarah Perpich |url=http://www.style.com/stylefile/2010/09/diane-pernet-and-tavi-take-the-shaded-view-of-fashion-film/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927235805/http://www.style.com/stylefile/2010/09/diane-pernet-and-tavi-take-the-shaded-view-of-fashion-film/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 September 2010 |title=Diane Pernet And Tavi Take The Shaded View of Fashion Film: style file: daily fashion, party, and model news |publisher=Style.com |date=25 September 2010 |accessdate=2 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grazia.nl/2010/04/23/diane-pernet-en-tavi-op-zoek-naar-filmtalent/ |title=Diane Pernet en Tavi zoeken filmtalent – Grazia Nieuws |publisher=Grazia.nl |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152912/http://www.grazia.nl/2010/04/23/diane-pernet-en-tavi-op-zoek-naar-filmtalent/# |archivedate=24 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Jury List==== * Olivier Saillard, Fashion Historian and Director of the [[Musee Galliera]], ASVOFF President<ref>{{cite web|author=Mdvanii |url=http://mdvaniiism.blogspot.com/2010/07/interview-with-diane-pernet.html |title=Mdvanii: Interview With Diane Pernet |publisher=Mdvaniiism.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110708052804/http://mdvaniiism.blogspot.com/2010/07/interview-with-diane-pernet.html| archivedate= 8 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> * [[Mike Figgis]], [[Academy Award]] nominated writer/director; films include [[Leaving Las Vegas]] and Timecode * Elisabeth Quin, film critic and a French government representative for fashion * Michael Nyman, film composer for The Piano and 12 Peter Greenaway films * Bryan Adams, photographer and musician * [[Dita Von Teese]], performer and style icon * Fabrice Brovelli, TV production director, BETC EuroRSCG. * [[Paolo Roversi]], photographer * Emmanuelle Castro, film acquisitions and co-production director, Wild Bunch * Daphne Burki, reporter for Canal + television * Nadja Romain, independent producer * Sara Maino, senior fashion editor, Vogue Italia * Zowie Broach, designer of [[Boudicca]] * [[Abdel Bounane]], chief editor, Amusement magazine * Olivier Seguret, journalist Liberation
====Prize Categories==== * Best Film: "Lust Lust" by Martins Grauds<ref>http://www.ashadedviewonfashionfilm.com/IMG/pdf/ASVOFF_3_WINNERS.pdf</ref> * Best Artistic Director: Alex Prager for "Despair ([[Nowness]])" * Special Jury Prize: "Lights" by Yoann Lemoine with Shaun Ross * Best New Talent – Samsung: "Blacklight" by Suzie Q + Leo Siboni * Beauty Prize – [[Shu Uemura]]: "How You Look at It" by Poppy de Villeneuve (NOWNESS) * Best Sound: "CHAPTER 14 The Dream of the Disembodied Birds" by Andrea Splisgar * Best Acting: Lauren McAvoy in "Chore Damaris" by [[Justin Anderson (film director)|Justin Anderson]] * Le Book Prize: AnOther Magazine – "Nocturna" by Daniel Askill
====Extra locations==== * Milan (Palazzo Morando) in January 2010 featuring 7 hours of fashion films screening and a special installation: "LIGHT SERIES", a series of 1-minute films commissioned by Diane Pernet and co-curator Antoine Asseraf, in addition to a special contest with Vogue Italia, won by Miho Kinamura and Zaiba Jabbar.<ref name="blogspot1"/> The collaboration was suggested by Frederico Poletti who proposed the idea to Vogue Italia editor [[Franca Sozzani]]. They found it interesting to make a complementary online event with the launch of Vogue.it. A selection of the films in the LIGHT series includes: ''Blacklight'' by Suzie Q & Leo Siboni, ''Lights'' by Yoann Lemoine, ''Short Circuit in the After Hour'' by Andrea Splisgar, ''Sunshowers'' by Elisa Smith-Leverock in collaboration with jewellery designer Fred Butler, ''Untitled'' by Sofia Sanchez & Mauro Mongiello and ''Spectre'' by Antoine Asseraf & René Habermacher. * Milan (Cinema Opera) in April 2010: a series of films by Michael Nyman at 10 Corso Como. * New York Art Fair: a curating a fashion/art exhibition and an ASVOFF film program.

In 2014, the festival ASVOFF was held in the U.S for the first time through a partnership with Kering. The festival opened on 14 March 2014 at the FIAF's Florence Gould Hall. The screening consisted of 12 short films, and after the festival, the founder [[Diane Pernet]] held a Q&A with the filmmakers [[Mike Figgis]] (''Leaving Las Vegas'') and [[Jerry Schatzberg]] (''Scarecrow'').Among the selections were Bruce Weber's short made for Barneys New York and Figgis's famous short 'Agent provocateur' in which [[Kate Moss]] made her screen debut.<ref>http://www.wwd.com/media-news/film-tv/kering-bringing-french-film-fest-to-us-7486580</ref>
===2015=== ASVOFF 8 took place December 2–6 at Centre Pompidou with Jean Paul Gaultier, Nicolas Godin, Nicolas Saada, Mathias Kiss, and Iris Van Herpen. The festival explores the genre of fashion film as well as new dimensions and interpretations in the fields of fashion and film through conferences, documentaries and even live performances (Pete Drungle and Loane).

== ASVOFF Association == In December, 2013 ASVOFF became an Association with the following members: President-Emmanuel Asmar, Vice President,Founder and Director- [[Diane Pernet]], Secretary- David Herman and Treasurer- Fabrice Rebois and Jason Last.
== Future == Diane Pernet would like ASVOFF to be an extension of other film festivals around the world. That would be a way to promote new filmmakers just like she has done for new designers with her blog.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}

{{Infobox Former Country |conventional_long_name = Allied administration of Libya |native_name = ''Occupazione alleata della Libia'' {{it icon}}
''احتلال الحلفاء لليبيا'' {{ar icon}} |common_name = Libya |continent = Africa |region = North Africa |country = Libya |era = |status = Military Administration |empire = |p1 = Italian Libya |flag_p1 = Flag of Italy (1861-1946).svg |s1 = Emirate of Cyrenaica |flag_s1 = Flag of Cyrenaica.svg |s2 = Kingdom of Libya |flag_s2 = Flag of Libya.svg |image_flag = Flag of the United Kingdom.svg |image_flag2 = Flag of Fezzan-Ghadames.svg |symbol = |national_motto = |national_anthem = |image_map = LIBYA While occupied during and after WWII.png |image_map_caption = The three regions of Libya during the Allied occupation: Tripolitania and Cyrenaica were British-administered, while Fezzan was French |capital = [[Tripoli]] |common_languages = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] |event_start = British occupation of Cyrenaica |year_start = 1942 |event_end = became the [[Kingdom of Libya]] |date_end = 24 December |year_end = 1951 |event1 = French occupation of Fezzan |date_event1 = 1943 |currency = [[Algerian franc]] (Fezzan-Ghadames)
[[Egyptian pound]] (Cyrenaica)
[[Tripolitanian lira|Military Authority Lira]] (Tripolitania) }} {{History of Libya}} The '''Allied administration of Libya''' was the control of the ex-Italian colony of [[Libya]] by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] from 1943 until Libyan independence was granted in 1951. It was divided into the following: *[[British Military Administration (Libya)|British Military Administration of Libya]] (British Administration after 1950) *[[Fezzan-Ghadames (French Administration)|Military Territory of Fezzan-Ghadames]] ==Characteristics== The Allied administration was done by the [[United Kingdom]] in [[Tripolitania]] and [[Cyrenaica]], and by [[France]] in [[Fezzan]]. Officially Libya remained "[[Italian Libya]]" until February 1947, when [[Italy]] signed the Peace Treaty losing all the colonies and possessions of the defeated former Italian Empire. The British administered it as the [[British Military Administration (Libya)|British Military Administration of Libya]]. The French forces occupied the area that was the former Italian [[Territorio Sahara Libico]] and made several requests to annex administratively their Fezzan to the [[French colonial Empire]]. The administrative personnel remained the former Italian bureaucrats. {{Quote|The British administration began the training of a badly needed Libyan civil service. Italian administrators continued to be employed in Tripoli, however. The Italian legal code remained in effect for the duration of the war. In the lightly populated Fezzan region, a French military administration formed a counterpart to the British operation. With British approval, Free French forces moved north from Chad to take control of the territory in January 1943. French administration was directed by a staff stationed in Sabha, but it was largely exercised through Fezzan notables of the family of Sayf an Nasr. At the lower echelons, French troop commanders acted in both military and civil capacities according to customary French practice in the Algerian Sahara. In the west, Ghat was attached to the French military region of southern Algeria and Ghadamis to the French command of southern Tunisia--giving rise to Libyan nationalist fears that French intentions might include the ultimate detachment of Fezzan from Libya.|Library of Congress:Libya|[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+ly0034) Library of Congress:Libya]}} ==History== {{See also|The Holocaust in Italian Libya}} {{See also|Western Desert Campaign}} [[Image:British tanks and crews line up on Tripoli's waterfront.jpg|thumb|British tanks and crews line up on [[Tripoli]]'s waterfront after capturing the city during [[World War II]] - December 1942]] In November 1942, the Allied forces retook Cyrenaica. By February 1943, the last German and Italian soldiers were driven from Libya and the Allied occupation of Libya began. In the early post-war period, Tripolitania and Cyrenaica remained under [[United Kingdom|British]] administration, while the [[France|French]] controlled Fezzan. In 1944, Idris returned from exile in [[Cairo]] but declined to resume permanent residence in Cyrenaica until the removal in 1947 of some aspects of foreign control. Under the terms of the 1947 peace treaty with the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]], Italy, which hoped to maintain the colony of [[Tripolitania]], (and France, which wanted the [[Fezzan]]), relinquished all claims to Libya. Libya so remained united. Severe anti-Jewish violence erupted in Libya following the liberation of North Africa by Allied troops. From November 5 to November 7, 1945, more than 140 Jews (including 36 children) were killed and hundreds injured in a [[1945 Tripoli pogrom|pogrom in Tripoli]]. Five synagogues in Tripoli and four in provincial towns were destroyed, and over 1,000 Jewish residences and commercial buildings were plundered in Tripoli alone.Selent, pp. 20-21Shields, Jacqueline."[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/jewref.html Jewish Refugees from Arab Countries]" in [[Jewish Virtual Library]].Stillman, 2003, p. 145. In June 1948, anti-Jewish rioters in Libya killed another 12 Jews and destroyed 280 Jewish homes. The fear and insecurity which arose from these anti-Jewish attacks and the [[Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel|founding of the state of Israel]] led many Jews to [[Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim lands|flee Libya]]. From 1948 to 1951, 30,972 Libyan Jews [[Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim lands|moved to Israel]].[http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/JewsofLibya/LibyanJews/thejews.html History of the Jewish Community in Libya] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718035942/http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/JewsofLibya/LibyanJews/thejews.html |date=18 July 2006 }}". Retrieved July 1, 2006 By the 1970s, the rest of Libyan Jews (some 7,000) were evacuated to Italy. {{Quote|Disposition of Italian colonial holdings was a question that had to be considered before the peace treaty officially ending the war with Italy could be completed. Technically, Libya remained an Italian possession administered by Britain and France, but at the Potsdam Conference in 1945 the Allies--Britain, the Soviet Union, and the United States--agreed that the Italian colonies seized during the war should not be returned to Italy. Further consideration of the question was delegated to the Allied Council of Foreign Ministers, which included a French representative; although all council members initially favored some form of trusteeship, no formula could be devised for disposing of Libya. The United States suggested a trusteeship for the whole country under control of the United Nations (UN), whose charter had become effective in October 1945, to prepare it for self-government. The Soviet Union proposed separate provincial trusteeships, claiming Tripolitania for itself and assigning Fezzan to France and Cyrenaica to Britain. France, seeing no end to the discussions, advocated the return of the territory to Italy. To break the impasse, Britain finally recommended immediate independence for Libya{{cn|date=August 2018}}|Library of Congress: United Nations and Libya}} [[Idris I of Libya|Idris as-Senussi]], the [[Emir]] of Tripolitania and Cyrenaica and the leader of the [[Senussi]] Muslim Sufi order, represented Libya in the UN negotiations, and on 24 December 1951, Libya declared its independence with representatives from Cyrenaica, Tripolitania and Fezzan declaring a [[Political union|union]] with the country being called the United Kingdom of Libya, and Idris as-Senussi being offered the crown. In accordance with the constitution the new country had a [[federal government]] with the three states of Cyrenaica, Tripolitania and Fezzan having [[autonomy]]. The kingdom also had three capital cities: [[Tripoli]], [[Benghazi]] and [[Bayda, Libya|Bayda]]. Two years after independence, on 28 March 1953, Libya joined the [[Arab League]]. When Libya declared its independence on 24 December 1951, ending the Allied occupation of Libya, it was the first country to achieve independence through the [[United Nations]] and one of the first former European possessions in [[Africa]] to gain independence. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Italian Libya]] * [[1945 Tripoli pogrom]] * [[1948 Tripoli pogrom]] * [[Kingdom of Libya]] {{Italian Libya}} {{Years in Libya}} {{Use DMY dates|date=June 2014}} [[Category:20th century in Libya]] [[Category:Aftermath of World War II]] [[Category:Italy–Libya relations]] [[Category:World War II occupied territories|Libya]] [[Category:Military occupation]]

{{Infobox television | name = Baltimore Rising | image = | alt = | caption = | film name = | director = [[Sonja Sohn]] | producer = [[Sonja Sohn]]
[[Anthony Hemingway]]
[[Marc Levin]]
[[Sheila Nevins]]

Mark Taylor | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = Dontae Winslow | cinematography = Ashwin Gandbhir | editor = Cliff Charles | studio = [[HBO Films]]
[[Blowback Productions]] | distributor = | released ={{Film date|TV=y|2017|11|20}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Baltimore Rising''''' is a 2017 documentary on the [[2015 Baltimore protests|protests in Baltimore after the death of Freddie Gray]]. It was created, directed, and produced by actor and filmmaker [[Sonja Sohn]] and [[HBO Films]]. It covers the [[death of Freddie Gray]], the protests and riots immediately following, efforts to keep the peace during the unsuccessful prosecutions of the six police officers involved, as well as efforts to change policing by both the [[Maryland General Assembly]] and the [[US Department of Justice]]. It includes segments covering the perspective of [[Black Lives Matter]] protesters, community leaders, and members of the [[Baltimore Police Department]].[http://www.newsweek.com/what-happened-after-freddie-gray-baltimore-rising-depicts-protests-shook-689699 WHAT HAPPENED AFTER FREDDIE GRAY? 'BALTIMORE RISING' DEPICTS PROTESTS THAT SHOOK THE NATION] Among the protesters, it focuses on [[Kwame Rose]] and Makayla Gilliam-Price, two young (17-21 years old) activists. Among community leaders, the documentary shows Adam Jackson and Dayvon Love, members of the group Leaders of a Beautiful Struggle. Among the police, ''Baltimore Rising'' includes Lt. Colonel Melvin Russell, head of a community affairs program in the BPD; Dawnyell Taylor, the lead police investigator into the death of Gray; and interim police commissioner Kevin Davis, who came to his position shortly after Gray's death.[http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-tv-baltimore-rising-20170727-story.html HBO doc 'Baltimore Rising' explores life after Freddie Gray][https://www.hbo.com/content/hboweb/en/documentaries/baltimore-rising/synopsis.html Baltimore Rising synopsis] ''Baltimore Rising'' premiered on [[HBO]] on November 20, 2017. ==Reception== Melanie McFarland of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' praised the documentary, writing it accurately communicated the "systemic and entrenched" problems on both sides: police who feel unsafe, retreat to their cars, and see everyone as potentially dangerous suspects, which furthers the alienation felt by the community and by the activists. She also felt that while it provided no neat conclusions or solutions, it accurately presented and summarized the many conflicting voices and opinions in the conflict.[https://www.salon.com/2017/11/20/baltimore-rising-questing-for-justice-from-the-ground-up/ "Baltimore Rising": Questing for justice from the ground up] Hank Steuver of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called ''Baltimore Rising'' simultaneously fascinating, scattered, and frustrating. He felt that this reflected the disorganized nature of the protests and the difficulties with channeling grievances into useful systemic change, however, so the frustration was authentic and accurate to the source material.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/like-the-activism-it-chronicles-baltimore-rising-struggles-to-find-real-progress/2017/11/19/2aba2e00-cbc4-11e7-aa96-54417592cf72_story.html Like the activism it chronicles, ‘Baltimore Rising’ struggles to find real progress] David Zurawick of ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' thought ''Rising'' was excellent, especially its "brilliant" opening, but felt it was somewhat too lenient in its treatment of the Baltimore police's efforts, which he felt should have been examined more skeptically.[http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/z-on-tv-blog/bs-fe-zontv-baltimore-rising-hbo-20171106-story.html Sonja Sohn's 'Baltimore Rising' on HBO drills down on life after Freddie Gray] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.hbo.com/documentaries/baltimore-rising Official website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9t87jLeOzPI Official trailer] [[Category:2017 television films]] [[Category:HBO documentary films]] [[Category:Death of Freddie Gray]]
