revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/174.60.116.143|174.60.116.143]] ([[User talk:174.60.116.143|talk]]): Rv - irrelevant, misplaced and inccurate. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
In the [[United Kingdom]], the '''Fixated Threat Assessment Centre''' ('''FTAC''') is a joint police/mental health unit set up in October 2006 by the [[Home Office]], the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] and [[Metropolitan Police Service]] to assess and manage the risk to politicians, members of the [[House of Windsor|British Royal Family]], and other public figures from obsessive individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article1847697.ece|publisher=The Times|title=VIP 'stalker' squad set up by government|author=Joanna Bale|date=May 27, 2007}}{{Cite journal | journal = Journal of Forensic Psychiatry & Psychology | title = The Fixated Threat Assessment Centre: preventing harm and facilitating care | first5 = L. | volume = 21 | pages = 1 | doi = 10.1080/14789941003596981 | year = 2010 | last1 = James | last5 = Preston | last2 = Kerrigan | first1 = D. | first2 = T. | last3 = Forfar | last4 = Farnham | first3 = R. | first4 = F. | issue = 4}} ==Rationale== The rationale for a joint police/mental health unit was the finding that the main danger of death or serious injury to politicians in Western Europe came from attacks by people suffering from a mental health illness, who had given warnings of what they might do in the form of inappropriate, harassing or threatening communications or approaches towards the politicians in question.{{Cite web|url=http://forensis.org/PDF/published/2007_TheRoleofMental.pdf|publisher=Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica|title=The role of mental disorder in attacks on European politicians 1990–2004|author1=James DV |author2=Mullen PE |author3=Meloy JR |author4=Pathe´ MT |author5=Farnham FR |author6=Preston L |author7=Darnley B |year=2007}} A similar picture was found in a study of historical attacks on the British royal family.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jaapl.org/cgi/reprint/36/1/59|publisher=Journal of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law|title=Attacks on the British Royal Family - The Role of Psychotic Illness|author1=David James |author2=Paul E. Mullen |author3=Michele T. Pathe´ |author4=J. Reid Meloy |author5=Frank R. Farnham |author6=Lulu Preston |author7=Brian Darnley |year=2007}} A separate detailed study of recent inappropriate communications and approaches to members of the royal family found that 83% of the individuals concerned were suffering from [[psychosis]].{{Cite web|url=http://forensis.org/PDF/published/2009_StalkersandHara.pdf|publisher=Psychological Medicine|title=Stalkers and harassers of royalty: the role of mental illness and motivation|author1=David James |author2=Paul E. Mullen |author3=Michele T. Pathe´ |author4=J. Reid Meloy |author5=Lulu Preston |author6=Brian Darnley |author7=Frank R. Farnham |year=2009}} Similar findings have come from the United States, where Park Dietz has written: “Every instance of an attack on a public figure by a lone stranger in the United States for which adequate information has been made publicly available has been the work of a mentally disordered person who issued one or more pre-attack signals in the form of inappropriate letters, visits or statements...."{{Cite web|url=http://www.jaapl.org/cgi/reprint/38/3/341|publisher=Journal of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law |title=Commentary – Approaching and stalking public figures – a prerequisite to attack|author1=Park Dietz |author2=Daniel Martell |year=2010}} The role of FTAC in the UK is to detect such signals, to evaluate the risks involved and to intervene to reduce them. Such intervention often entails the obtaining of treatment and care for the fixated individual from psychiatric and social services and general practitioners in their town of residence. ==The Fixated== The word ‘fixated’ in the name of the unit indicates that the main motivational drives behind the [[stalking]] of public figures are pathologically intense fixations on individuals or causes, these being obsessive pre-occupations pursued to an abnormally intense degree.{{Cite web|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a903475075|publisher=Journal of Forensic Psychiatry & Psychology|title=The fixated and the pursuit of public figures|author1=Paul E. Mullen |author2=David James |author3=J. Reid Meloy |author4=Michele T. Pathe´ |author5=Frank R. Farnham |author6=Lulu Preston |author7=Brian Darnley |author8=Jeremy Berman |year=2009}} In the case of those pursuing the Royal Family, these fixations divide between beliefs that the individual was a member of the family or married to a member of the family; that the royal personage was involved in plots to persecute them; and that the Royal Family were culpable for failing to redress a particular grievance, often delusional, with which the individual was angrily obsessed. ==Staffing and Role== FTAC is staffed by ten police officers from the [[Metropolitan Police Service]], three full-time senior forensic nurses, a full-time senior social worker and a number of senior forensic psychiatrists and psychologists from the Barnet Enfield and Haringey NHS Trust and the Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust. FTAC receives around 1,000 referrals a year of people who have engaged in threatening or harassing communications towards politicians or the Royal Family.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11259190|publisher=BBC News|title=How do the police keep an eye on VIP stalkers?|author=Chris Summers|date=September 16, 2010}} Around half are assessed as being of low risk after initial enquiries. The remainder are investigated by FTAC staff. They may then be referred to local health services for further assessment and potential [[involuntary commitment]]. In some cases, they may be detained by police under the [[Mental Health Act 1983#Civil sections|section 136 powers]] of the [[Mental Health Act 1983]] prior to referral. Although run by London's Metropolitan Police Service, FTAC is responsible for dealing nationally with the stalking or harassment of public figures by lone individuals. According to its founder, David James, it attempts not only to provide protection for the subjects of obsessive attention, but also to help people with obsessions who have [[mental illness]]es that might otherwise have gone undiagnosed or untreated. The basis of the approach arises from the fact that the majority of the fixated are driven by delusional beliefs based in potentially treatable mental disorders. Treating those with evident mental illness will have an important effect in reducing the level of risk to public figures, whilst at the same time improving the health and welfare of the individuals concerned. The strap-line on FTAC's stationery is 'Preventing Harm and Facilitating Care'. According to a statement made in June 2007 by the then Minister of State for the Home Office Tony McNulty,
"FTAC does not detain people in psychiatric hospitals. When it encounters an individual in need of mental health care it alerts their general practitioners and psychiatrists, who then provide appropriate help under existing legislation. FTAC may make use of police powers under section 136 of the Mental Health Act 1983 to take a person who appears to be suffering from mental disorder, and in immediate need of care or control, to a place of safety. When people are removed to hospital under section 136, they are examined by a registered medical practitioner and interviewed by an approved social worker, not associated with FTAC, in order to make any necessary arrangements for their treatment or care."{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/cm200607/cmhansrd/cm070625/text/70625w0068.htm|title=Daily Hansard - Written Answers - 25 Jun 2007 : Column 301W}}
==Activity== In a parliamentary reply made in June 2009, the Secretary of State for the Home Office David Hanson said: "Since 2006, when FTAC began operation, 246 people have been detained under the Mental Health Act following a referral from FTAC and a subsequent decision by local health services. No individual has received a custodial sentence as a result of FTAC involvement."{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200809/cmhansrd/cm090610/text/90610w0004.htm|title=Daily Hansard - Written Answers - 10 Jun 2009 : Column 875W}} He also stated that during that same period, 27 people had been conveyed to a "[[place of safety]]" by FTAC staff under section 136 of the Mental Health Act 1983. FTAC published the details of its interventions in its first 100 cases in the ''Journal of Forensic Psychiatry & Psychology'' in 2010. Eighty-six per cent of those assessed by FTAC were diagnosed as suffering from psychotic illness; 57% of the sample group were subsequently admitted to hospital, and 26% treated in the community. In 80% of cases, the risk level was reduced to low by FTAC intervention, the remainder of cases remaining under continued FTAC management In protection terms, FTAC’s activities are said to benefit the families of the fixated individuals and the general public as much as the public figures that they are hounding. This is because those close to the fixated are more regularly exposed to their irrational and threatening behaviour than the public figures they target.{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/cbm.769|publisher=Criminal Behaviour and Mental Health|title=Protecting the prominent? A research journey with Paul Mullen|author=David James |year=2010}} This finding is similar to that made in the USA by Dietz and Martell in a report prepared for the National Institute of Justice: “The persons most at risk of violence from the individual mentally ill person who pursues public figures are not the public figures or those that protect them – assuming they have the necessary security arrangements - but rather the private citizens who are the family members and neighbours of the mentally disordered subject.”{{Cite web|url=http://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/ICPSR/studies/6007;jsessionid=1435D130C3F9DEA26C73544A4A54C97B?keyword=mental+disorders|title=Mentally disordered offenders in pursuit of celebrities and politicians|author1=Park Elliott Dietz |author2=Daniel Allen Martell |year=1989}} ==Origins== The setting up of FTAC was the main recommendation of the report of Fixated Research Group (FRG) which undertook a major research project on behalf of the [[Home Office]] between 2003 and 2006. This looked at inappropriate communications and approaches to members of the Royal Family, and systematically examined 8,000 files held by [[SO14]], the royalty protection division of the Metropolitan Police Service’s [[Protection Command]]. The Fixated Research Group was composed of forensic psychiatrists and psychologists from the UK, Australia and the USA, who are experts in the field of stalking. They included Paul Mullen and Michele Pathé from Australia, co-authors of ‘Stalkers and their Victims’,{{cite web|url=http://www.cup.es/uk/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521732413&ss=fro|publisher=Cambridge University Press|title=Stalkers and their Victims, 2nd edition|author1=Paul Mullen |author2=Michele Pathé |author3=Rosemary Purcell |year=2009}} and J. Reid Meloy from San Diego, editor of ''The Psychology of Stalking''.{{cite web|url=http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/bookdescription.cws_home/679416/description#description|publisher=Academic Press|title=The Psychology of Stalking|author=J Reid Meloy|year=1998}} The series of research papers published by the group in peer-reviewed scientific journals forms the evidence base for the Fixated Threat Assessment Centre. ==Other applications of the model== The researchers at FTAC contend that the joint police-NHS model has other possible applications within the UK, such as in police responses to stalking of ordinary people and in homicide prevention. In their view, a logical further development would be the modification of the role of NHS police-liaison psychiatric nurses, so that they become embedded in police responses at borough or county level in order to perform an enabling role, to the benefit of individual patients and of public protection. ==Awards== *FTAC won an Association of Chief Police Officers’ Excellence Award in 2009. == See also == * [[Involuntary commitment]] * [[Protection Command]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2007/aug/26/features.magazine67 ''Observer'' article on the Fixated Threat Assessment Centre], including interviews with its founder David James * [http://www.fixatedthreat.com The web-site of the ''Fixated Research Group''], containing information about FTAC and a wealth of detail about the research which led to its being established. * [http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(11)60113-X/fulltext ''Lancet'' article on the Fixated Threat Assessment Centre], entitled ''The UK's Fix for Fixated Threats'' * [http://www.stalkingriskprofile.com The Stalking Risk Profile web-site.] {{UK mental health legislation}} [[Category:Mental health law in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Metropolitan Police]] [[Category:Department of Health (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Mental health organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Stalking]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox referendum | name = Greek bailout referendum, 2015 | title = Should the agreement plan submitted by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund to the Eurogroup of 25 June 2015, and {{sic|comprised |hide=y|of}} two parts which make up their joint proposal, be accepted? The first document is titled ''"[http://www.referendum2015gov.gr/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/REFORMS-FOR-COMPLETION-OF-CURRENT-PROGRAM-1.pdf Reforms For The Completion Of The Current Program And Beyond]"'' and the second ''"[http://www.referendum2015gov.gr/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/P.S.A.pdf Preliminary Debt Sustainability Analysis]."'' ---- | location = [[Greece]] | date = 5 July 2015 | yes = 2245537 | no = 3558450 | total = 6161140 | electorate = 9858508 | map = Greek referendum 2015 map.svg | mapdivision = [[List of parliamentary constituencies of Greece|constituency]] | mapcaption ={{legend|#FFD5D5|>50–55% No}} {{legend|#FFAAAA|>55–60% No}} {{legend|#FF696D|>60–65% No}} {{legend|#FF2A2A|>65–70% No}} {{legend|#D40000|>70–75% No}} | notes = *[http://www.referendum2015gov.gr/en/ Official website ] *[http://www.ypes.gr/el/Elections/referendum2015/ Official referendum announcements {{el icon}}] *[http://www.ypes.gr/UserFiles/f0ff9297-f516-40ff-a70e-eca84e2ec9b9/F092-22-4277.pdf The unified proposal {{el icon}}] *[http://s.kathimerini.gr/resources/article-files/yhfodeltio-1.pdf Voting ballot {{el icon}}] }} {{Greek economic crisis}}
A [[referendum]] to decide whether [[Greece]] was to accept the bailout conditions in the [[Greek government-debt crisis|country's government-debt crisis]] proposed jointly by the [[European Commission]] (EC), the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) and the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) on 25 June 2015, took place on 5 July 2015.<ref name="Referendum announcement">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33296839|title=Greece debt crisis: Tsipras announces bailout referendum| publisher=BBC News|date=27 June 2015}}</ref> The referendum was announced by [[Prime Minister of Greece|Prime Minister]] [[Alexis Tsipras]] in the early morning of 27 June 2015, and ratified the following day by the [[Hellenic Parliament|Parliament]] and the [[President of Greece|President]]. It was the first referendum to be held since the [[Greek republic referendum, 1974|republic referendum of 1974]], and the only one in modern Greek history not to concern the form of government.
As a result of the referendum, the bailout conditions were rejected by a majority of over 61% to 39% approving, with the "No" vote winning in all of Greece's regions. The referendum results also forced the immediate resignation of [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] leader [[Antonis Samaras]] as party president because of the perceived negative result of the "Yes" choice, to which the conservative party and Samaras had committed themselves.<ref name='samarasresigns'>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ekathimerini.com/198993/article/ekathimerini/news/greek-conservative-opposition-chief-samaras-resigns|title=Greek conservative opposition chief Samaras resigns|work=Ekathimerini|accessdate=5 July 2015|date=5 July 2015}}</ref> Although winning the referendum, Finance Minister [[Yanis Varoufakis]] also resigned and was replaced on 6 July by [[Euclid Tsakalotos]].
Despite the result of the referendum, on 13 July 2015 the government of Tsipras reached an agreement with the European authorities for a [[Third Economic Adjustment Programme for Greece|3-year-bailout]] with even harsher austerity conditions as the ones rejected by the voters. This represented a "drastic turnaround" for Prime Minister Tsipras position,<ref name=wsj20150708></ref> as he had been [[Greek legislative election, January 2015|elected in an anti-austerity platform]]. Former Finance Minister [[Varoufakis]] characterised the harshness of the deal as a new [[Treaty of Versailles]] and "Greece’s Terms of Surrender".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/varoufakis-greece-deal-new-versailles-surrender-blog-parliament/ |title=Varoufakis calls Greek deal ‘new Versailles’ |last=Brown |first=Stephen |date=15 July 2015 |website= |publisher=Politico |access-date=25 September 2018 |quote=}}</ref> In July and August, Tsipras was able to get the new [[Greek government-debt crisis countermeasures#Tenth austerity package and reforms (July 2015)|austerity packages]] and the entire bailout agreement approved by the [[Hellenic Parliament|Parliament]], but had to relly in the pro-European Union opposition parties as around 40 MPs of the [[Syriza|major ruling party]] abstained or voted against the measures.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greek parliament approves bailout prior measures package |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eurozone-greece/greek-parliament-approves-bailout-prior-measures-package-idUSKBN0P40EO20150715|publisher=Reuters|date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=25 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=As Greek Bailout Deal Passes, Alexis Tsipras Faces Rebellion |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/15/world/europe/greece-bailout-vote.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=14 August 2015 |accessdate=25 September 2018}}</ref> This triggered the [[Greek legislative election, September 2015|September 2015 snap election]], where Tsipras was re-elected albeit with an historical low turnout. The second Tsipras government was thus marked by an intense austerity policy in the context of the [[Third Economic Adjustment Programme for Greece|third bailout to Greece]]. The country left bailout in August 2018, though austerity policies continued after that due to pressure from European Union and IMF.
==Background==
The referendum was announced by Tsipras in the early morning of 27 June 2015.<ref name="Referendum announcement"/> No prior notice of the decision was given to the Eurogroup.<ref>{{Cite web|title = EU taken by surprise by Greek referendum|url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/europe/69776916/eu-taken-by-surprise-by-greek-referendum|website = Stuff|accessdate = 2015-07-10|date = 29 June 2015}}</ref> In the early hours of 28 June 2015, Parliament voted on whether or not the government's proposed bailout referendum should be held, with 178 MPs (Syriza, [[Independent Greeks|ANEL]] and [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]]) for, 120 MPs (all other parties) against and two MPs abstaining.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Traynor|first1=Ian|last2=Hooper|first2=John|title=Greek banks to stay closed on Monday|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/28/greek-crisis-ecb-decide-emergency-funding|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=The Guardian|date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
==Referendum question== [[File:Greece 2015 referendum ballot.png|thumb|left|Ballot paper used in the referendum (ΟΧΙ = No, ΝΑΙ = Yes)]] Voters were asked whether they approve of the proposal made to Greece by the [[Juncker Commission]], the IMF and the ECB during the [[Eurogroup]] meeting on 25 June. This proposal with a list of [http://europa.eu/rapid/attachment/IP-15-5270/en/List%20of%20prior%20actions%20-%20version%20of%2026%20June%2020%2000.pdf ''10 prior action items'']<ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/attachment/IP-15-5270/en/List%20of%20prior%20actions%20-%20version%20of%2026%20June%2020%2000.pdf EU-IMF-ECB proposal with ''10 prior action items'']</ref> was [http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-5270_en.htm published] by the commission, but withdrawn when negotiations were abandoned shortly after.
The Greek government thus asked to vote on two previous documents, titled ''"[http://www.referendum2015gov.gr/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/REFORMS-FOR-COMPLETION-OF-CURRENT-PROGRAM-1.pdf Reforms For The Completion Of The Current Program And Beyond]"'' and ''"[http://www.referendum2015gov.gr/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/P.S.A.pdf Preliminary Debt Sustainability Analysis]."''.<ref name="documents-gr">{{el icon}} [https://www.efsyn.gr/arthro/ayto-einai-erotima-toy-dimopsifismatos Στις 5 Ιουλίου ψηφίζουμε «ναι» ή «όχι» στην πρόταση των «θεσμών»]</ref> The possible answers were stated as "Not approved/No" and "Approved/Yes".<ref name="parliament">{{el icon}} [http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/Enimerosi/Simera-sti-Vouli/?ilt_id=d2c5678b-a7d9-41b0-ba0c-a4c4002f9f0f Hellenic Parliament, 27 June 2015]</ref><ref name="tovima">{{el icon}} [http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=717101 Αυτό είναι το ερώτημα του δημοψηφίσματος που προτείνει η κυβέρνηση]</ref>
== Legality concerns == [[Evangelos Venizelos]] from [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement|PASOK]] party, as well as the [[To Potami]] and [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] parties, said that the proposed referendum would be unconstitutional, as the [[Constitution of Greece|constitution]] does not allow for referendums on fiscal matters.<ref>{{el icon}} [http://www.emea.gr/βενιζέλος-«αντισυνταγματικό-το-δημο/450891 Βενιζέλος: «Αντισυνταγματικό το δημοψήφισμα!»]</ref> Article 44, section 2 provides for two referendum procedures, one for 'crucial national matters' (first clause) and a second for 'Bills passed by Parliament regulating important social matters, with the exception of the fiscal ones' (second clause).<ref>[http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/UserFiles/f3c70a23-7696-49db-9148-f24dce6a27c8/001-156%20aggliko.pdf The Constitution of Greece, Article 44, Section 2.]</ref> The Syriza-led government argued the referendum was in accordance with the first clause, and therefore not unconstitutional.<ref name="parliament"/>
The Athens [[bar association|Bar Association]] (DPS), which is the largest legal association in Greece, raised a range of concerns about whether the referendum law approved by the [[Hellenic Parliament]] and [[President of Greece]] was legal. They said the call of referendum and the referendum question itself, featured ''"significant problems on the validity and meaning of voting "yes"/"no" in that referendum"'', in a situation where the result of such referendum could have major importance for the future of Greece. Procedural guarantees for calling referendums provided for by law 4023/2011, as well as Constitutional requirements (Article 44, sections 2 and 3) regarding which issues could be put to a referendum, were assessed not to have been met.<ref name="Legality concerns">{{cite web|url=http://www.dsa.gr/%CE%BD%CE%AD%CE%B1/%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BA%CE%BF%CE%B9%CE%BD%CF%8E%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82/%CE%B1%CF%80%CF%8C%CF%86%CE%B1%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%B4%CE%B9%CE%BF%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%8D-%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BC%CE%B2%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BB%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%B4%CF%83%CE%B1-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%BF%CF%88%CE%AE%CF%86%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82-5%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BB%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85-2015|title=Decision of the Board of DPS for the referendum on 5 July 2015 (Απόφαση του Διοικητικού Συμβουλίου του ΔΣΑ για το δημοψήφισμα της 5ης Ιουλίου 2015)|language=Greek|publisher=Athens Bar Association (DPS)|date=30 June 2015}}</ref>
On July 1, Bloomberg reported they had found a translation mistake in the Greek version of the "''Preliminary Debt Sustainability Analysis''" part of the Institutions "unified proposal" being put to referendum. In this part there were three debt sustainability scenarios, and under the first two the original English document concludes that "this gross financing need metric points to no sustainability issues"<ref>[http://www.iefimerida.gr/sites/default/files/eurogroupdebtanalysis.pdf Preliminary Debt Sustainability Analysis for Greece], original in English.</ref> (Bloomberg's wording for the conclusion was "that there are no sustainability issues") when the country's financing needs are taken into account, while the official Greek translation published to Greek voters and sent to reporters on 29 June, was missing the word "no", so that the Greek text reads ''"there are sustainability issues"''.<ref name="Translation mistake">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-01/it-s-not-all-greek-to-voters-as-key-debt-document-mistranslated|title=Key Greek Referendum Debt Document Mistranslated|publisher=Bloomberg|date=1 July 2015|first=Nikos|last=Chrysoloras}}</ref> This finding stressed the importance of the second concern raised by DPS, about the referendum putting ''"a pair of uncertified documents"'' to a vote, instead of what the law required, ''"a pair of certified translated documents approved by the initial issuer of the documents"''.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
=== Court ruling === Greece's top administrative court, the [[Council of State (Greece)|Council of State]], ruled on the legality of the referendum two days before it was due to be held against a claim that was submitted by private individuals and argued that the referendum could be violating the country's constitution by posing a question regarding "public finances".<ref name="Legality to be judged by Council of State">{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/198843/article/ekathimerini/news/greeces-top-court-to-rule-on-legality-of-referendum|title=Greece's top court to rule on legality of referendum|work=Ekathimerini.com|date=2 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref> The court's decision was that the referendum was within the jurisdiction of the government and that the court had no authority on the issue, thus rejecting the claim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.protothema.gr/politics/article/490058/apofasi-ste-dimopsifisma/|title=Κανονικά διεξάγεται το δημοψήφισμα - Το ΣτΕ απέρριψε τις αιτήσεις|work=protothema.gr|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref>
== Reception ==
=== European Commission === The President of the European Commission, [[Jean-Claude Juncker]], said on 29 June during a press conference on Greece that "the momentum [for finding an agreement] was destroyed unilaterally by the announcement of a referendum and by the decision to mount a 'no' campaign to reject this agreement".<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015">{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-15-5274_en.htm|title=Transcript of President Jean-Claude Juncker's press conference on Greece|publisher=European Commission|date=29 June 2015}}</ref>
The European Commission further objected to the timing of the referendum, stressing it should have been held to allow sufficient time before 30 June 2015 deadline when the ''"20 February 2015 offer ratified by other national parliaments"''—in which Greece had been offered the prospect of completing and extending its existing bailout agreement by a new (yet to be mutually agreed) set of renegotiated terms—expired.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} The Commission also objected to the approach of not choosing a referendum question reflecting the entire dimensions of the comprehensive bailout offer, which was not only about implementation of a "reform programme", but also included a €35bn investment package which it said would spur job creation along with economic growth, and included a guarantee for debt relief according to a renewal of the ''"November 2012 debt relief statement"''.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} This would ensure—conditional on the completion of the second bailout programme under its new renegotiated terms—automatic debt relief, to the extent that the Greek [[debt-to-GDP ratio]] would be reduced to levels below 124% in 2020 and 110% in 2022.<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015"/>
The European Commission also found it strange and inappropriate, that the Greek government asked for voters' opinion on the ''"Institution's 25 June compromise proposal"'' rather than the latest ''"Institution's 26 June compromise proposal"''.<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015"/> It said the latest ''"26 June compromise proposal"''<ref name="European Commission statement 28-06-2015">{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-5270_en.htm|title=European Commission - Press release: Information from the European Commission on the latest draft proposals in the context of negotiations with Greece|publisher=European Commission|date=28 June 2015}}</ref> differed from the ''"25 June version"'' on several points (meeting objections tabled by the Greek government), of which one of the most significant was that the VAT rate for hotels had been reduced from 23% to 13%.<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015"/>
The European Commission claimed that neither of the Institution's proposals, contrary to claims by the Greek government, had contained "excessive austerity", public wage cuts or pension cuts. Instead they had lowered their demand for a public budget primary surplus from the previously required 4.5%—now to be 1% in 2015 followed by a gradual increase to a level of 3.5% for 2018 and beyond—saving Greece from implementing €12bn of extra austerity measures.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Their request for a "wage reform", it said, was about conducting an [[International Labour Organization|ILO]] approved review and update of the current collective bargaining rights in the private sector (not removal of collective bargaining rights)—and implementation of a new approved wage scheme in which public workers were paid in future according to qualifications and performance (instead of clientele deals). Their "pension reform", it said, was calling for the cancellation of incentives for early retirement, along with moving to a system in which all people in Greece received pensions on the same terms (not treating some sectors more beneficially than others).{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
The claim by Juncker that there were no pension cuts in the proposal raised eyebrows, with ''Financial Times'' journalist Peter Spiegel tweeting that it was "simply not true".<ref name='greekreporter'>{{cite web|URL=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2015/06/29/ft-journalist-spiegel-caught-juncker-lying-about-greece/|title=FT Journalist Spiegel Caught Juncker Lying About Greece|work=Greek Reporter|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=29 June 2015}}</ref>
Other important elements of the proposals, the European Commission said, were: to implement a more efficient and independent Tax Collection Authority, opening up closed professions to competition (i.e. so that the Greek price for electricity—which is currently the most expensive in EU—would decline), and to implement a string of measures to ensure more social fairness (guaranteed minimum income scheme, making tax payments more proportionate to income, targeting extra saving cuts in public spending on areas with no adverse impact for average citizens—i.e. increased defense cuts, removing socially unjust favorable tax treatments of ship-owners, fighting corruption in which the focus should be "big fish" rather than "ordinary people", and safeguarding a lasting social fairness by supporting more transparency and efficiency in public administration—in particularly through establishment of a new politically-independent tax administration).<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015"/>
Further, the European Commission signaled that the referendum question, to which they would recommend a "Yes", from its viewpoint should be understood as whether or not Greece wanted to remain part of Europe and the Eurozone, which at the present state included acceptance of receiving conditional bailout help on a set of mutually negotiated and agreed terms. The Commission claimed the biggest impediment to jobs, growth and investment at the moment in Greece, was not the contents of the Institution's bailout proposals, but instead a paralyzing uncertainty caused by the Greek government's decision to cut itself off from continued bailout support and a moratorium on implementing structural reforms. According to the Commission, this uncertainty and standstill could only be removed if Greece at the negotiating table agreed on one of the latest compromise proposals which the Institutions had tabled after accommodating a range of objections and requests tabled by the Greek government. They claimed the confidence effect of voting "Yes" to the settlement of such a deal, the predictability it would bring, together with the injection of liquidity into the economy from disbursements, would restore job creation and growth to the benefit of Greece.<ref name="European Commission statement 29-06-2015"/>
=== Council of Europe === The [[Council of Europe]] stated that the Greek referendum does not meet European standards, as voters were not given a two-week period to make up their minds, as non-binding guidelines recommend. Due to the hasty schedule, the Council of Europe was not able to send [[Election monitoring|election observers]] and the Greek government had not requested them either.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/01/eurozone-greece-rights-idUSL8N0ZH3IO20150701|title=Greek referendum falls short of standards - Council of Europe|publisher=Reuters|date=1 July 2015}}</ref> However the head of the Greek delegation and vice president of the Council's parliamentary assembly, [[Dimitris Vitsas]], denied that there was any decision made by the Council of Europe and said that it was only a personal opinion expressed by the Council's general secretary, [[Thorbjørn Jagland]],<ref>{{el icon}} [http://www.stokokkino.gr/details.php?id=1000000000011991 Διαψεύδει ο Δημήτρης Βίτσας ότι το Συμβούλιο της Ευρώπης είναι αντίθετο με το δημοψήφισμα - stokokkino.gr]</ref> with [[Tiny Kox]], the head of the Left wing in the Council's assembly supporting the same view and asking the general secretary to clarify his previous announcement.<ref>{{el icon}} [http://www.avgi.gr/article/5680498/kox-den-uparxei-anakoinosi-tou-sumbouliou-tis-europis-gia-to-dimopsifisma Κοξ: Δεν υπάρχει ανακοίνωση του Συμβουλίου της Ευρώπης για το δημοψήφισμα avgi.gr]</ref><ref>{{el icon}} [http://newpost.gr/post/472421/syriza-ti-leei-o-tiny-kox-gia-to-symboylio-ths-eyrwphs-kai-to-dhmopshfisma - newpost.gr]</ref>
===United Nations independent experts=== The [[United Nations Independent Expert on the Promotion of a Democratic and Equitable International Order]] and on [[human rights]] and [[international law]], [[Alfred de Zayas]] and [[Virginia Dandan]] respectively, welcomed the Greek referendum and called for international solidarity, while expressing disappointment that the IMF and the EU have failed to reach a non austerity based solution yet, and supporting that ''no treaty or loan agreement can force a country to violate the civil, cultural, economic, political and social rights of its population, nor can a loan agreement negate the sovereignty of a State''.<ref>{{cite web|title=UN human rights experts welcome Greek referendum and call for international solidarity|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=16170&LangID=E|publisher=ohchr.org|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref>
==Campaigns== [[Image:20150703 Greek Referendum Demonstration for NO syntagma square Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|3 July 2015: Demonstration for voting NO in front of the Greek parliament, Syntagma Square, Athens.]] [[File:OXI sign-greecereferendumdemojune2015.jpg|thumb|A "No" campaigner outside the [[Old Royal Palace|Greek parliament building]] on 29 June 2015, holding a sign reading ΟΧΙ ΣΤΗΝ ΕΞΟΝΤΩΣΗ ("no to annihilation").]]
===Positions on implications of the referendum=== {{main article|Endorsements in the Greek bailout referendum, 2015}} There has been substantial disagreement between campaigns on the implications of the referendum, and the public has interpreted it in a variety of ways.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3945677/greece-referendum-vote/ |title=Greek Voters Confused by Referendum Wording as Vote Nears |author=Associated Press |work=TIME.com |accessdate=5 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706002849/http://time.com/3945677/greece-referendum-vote/ |archivedate=6 July 2015 }}</ref> Tsipras has argued that a "No" vote would represent a rejection of the austerity terms demanded by the creditors, and strengthen the Greek negotiating position. Tsipras declared "On Sunday, we are not simply deciding to remain in Europe -- we are deciding to live with dignity in Europe".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/greece-pm-urges-no-vote-live-dignity-europe-182709597.html|title=Greece PM urges 'No' vote to 'live with dignity in Europe'|date=3 July 2015|work=Yahoo News UK|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> Tsipras has repeatedly rejected Greek and international warnings that a "No" vote would be perceived by Greek's main creditors as a "No" to reforms in Greece, and a "No" to remaining in the Eurozone.<ref>{{el icon}} [http://www.naftemporiki.gr/story/973690/al-tsipras-to-oxi-den-simainei-riksi-me-tin-europi Αλ. Τσίπρας: Η διαπραγμάτευση συνεχίζεται, θα συνεχιστεί και τη Δευτέρα], naftemporiki.gr, 2 July 2015, retrieved 8 July 2015.</ref><ref>{{el icon}} [http://news.in.gr/greece/article/?aid=1500009300 http://news.in.gr/greece/article/?aid=1500009300 Τσίπρας: Το «όχι» δεν σημαίνει έξοδο από το ευρώ], in.gr, 1 July 2015, retrieved 8 July 2015.</ref> Advocates of a "Yes" vote, among them a grassroot movement entitled [[Menoume Europi]] (Stay in Europe) have cast the referendum as a decision on Greece remaining in the eurozone, and perhaps even the European Union.<ref>{{el icon}} [http://www.newsit.gr/politikh/samaras-dimopsifisma-eksodo-elladas-euro/413132 Σαμαράς: Το δημοψήφισμα είναι για έξοδο της Ελλάδας από το ευρώ], newsit.gr, 27 June 2015, retrieved 8 July 2015.</ref>
Many international leaders as well as mainstream economists and media warned that if the "No" vote leads to a failure to secure continued bailout support for Greece in due time, this would likely lead to a broader Greek [[sovereign default]], a haircut on Greek bank deposits, a collapse of the banking sector, followed by an aggravated depression of the Greek economy, and a [[Greek withdrawal from the eurozone|Greek exit from the euro area]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Elliot | first = Larry | last2 = Wearden | first2 = Graeme | last3 = Smith | first3 = Helena | title = Europe's big guns warn Greek voters that a no vote means euro exit | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 30 June 2015 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/29/greek-crisis-referendum-eurozone-vote-germany-france-italy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Deen | first = Mark | last2 = Fouquet | first2 = Helene | title = Hollande Says Greece’s Referendum Will Determine Euro Membership | pages = | newspaper = Bloomberg News | location = New York | date = 29 June 2015 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-06-29/hollande-says-greece-s-referendum-will-determine-euro-membership}}</ref> A new local currency to replace the euro would be strongly devalued, which would decrease the purchasing power for Greeks and lead to [[inflation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-07-03/greek-debt-crisis-economist-explains-fallout/6592554|title=Greek debt crisis: Economist explains fallout if Greece goes back to drachma|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015|newspaper=abc News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/03/greece-economy-collapse-close-food-medicine-shortage|title=Greek economy close to collapse as food and medicine run short|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9963b74c-219c-11e5-aa5a-398b2169cf79.html#axzz3euesvmM5|title=Greek banks prepare plan to raid deposits to avert collapse|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref>
[[Eurogroup]] president Jeroen Dijsselbloem said that "in case of a 'No', Greece's (financial) situation will become exceptionally difficult... The economic problems will be even bigger and an aid programme more difficult to implement".<ref name="auto">{{cite news|title=Greek situation deteriorating: Dijsselbloem|url=https://au.finance.yahoo.com/news/greek-situation-deteriorating-dijsselbloem-014808557.html|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=YahooFinance}}</ref> [[European Commission]] head [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] said Greece's negotiating position would be "dramatically weakened" if a 'No' won. Other European leaders have also criticized the Greek government's representation of the referendum options, with EU leaders saying that they would see a "No" vote as a rejection of Europe.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Angry EU leaders lash out at Greece, eyeing endgame|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/198873/article/ekathimerini/news/angry-eu-leaders-lash-out-at-greece-eyeing-endgame|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=Ekathimerini}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=If the Greeks say "no" would weaken the Greek negotiating position (in Greek)|url=http://www.naftemporiki.gr/finance/story/973914/giounker-an-oi-ellines-poun-oxi-tha-apodunamothei-i-elliniki-diapragmateutiki-thesi|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=Naftemporiki}}</ref>
Public opinion strongly favours keeping the euro.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Clear lead for SYRIZA in Public Issue poll; support for euro at 71% | pages = | newspaper = Phantis | location = | date = 15 June 2015 | url = http://www.phantis.com/news/clear-lead-syriza-public-issue-poll-support-euro-71 }}</ref> Of all the political parties which won seats in the parliamentary election in May, only the [[Communist]] [[Communist Party of Greece|KKE]] expressed support for leaving the euro, and indeed for leaving the [[European Union]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18455465 [[BBC News]] report 15 June 2012] – "Greek election is euro versus drachma, Samaras says"</ref>{{unreliable source?|reason=out-of-date, XE opinion?|date=July 2015}}
A majority of European leaders,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2015/jul/02/greek-debt-crisis-athens-creditors-referendum-yes-no-live|title=Greek crisis: IMF says no third bailout without debt relief—as it happened|author=Graeme Wearden|work=the Guardian|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> and the US President [[Barack Obama|Obama]] have expressed the opinion that Greece should remain in the monetary union.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Greek debt crisis: Obama and Merkel monitoring situation closely | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 28 June 2015 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jun/28/obama-merkel-talk-greek-debt-crisis}}</ref> An opposite view comes from the UK Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] who mentioned, according to a leaked note, that it "might be better" for Greece to leave the euro in order to sort its economy out, even though Cameron conceded that there were major risks in that, too.<ref>{{cite news | last = Nardelli | first = Alberto | last2 = Watt | first2 = Nicholas | title = Cameron told EU leader Greek exit from euro may be best option | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 26 June 2015 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jun/26/cameron-told-eu-leader-greek-exit-from-euro-may-be-best-option }}</ref>
=== Greek organisations === Reception by professional/societal associations in Greece: * Technical Chamber of Greece (TCG): Had called a steering committee meeting for approval of a "Yes" recommendation statement, but had to abort their meeting when evidently a group of radical Syriza supporters (not members of the organisation) had hijacked their meeting. The TCG president said: "It is assumed that the referendum is paramount democratic choice of the people. But how is democracy strengthened when people, who obviously support the opinion of SYRIZA, come and threaten our Steering Committee not to make a decision to communicate the opinion of our association in important matters?"<ref name="Reception by Greek associations">{{cite web|url=http://www.kathimerini.gr/821608/article/epikairothta/ellada/epixeirhsh-apotrophs-toy-nai-me-efodoys|title="Επιχείρηση" αποτροπής του "ναι" με εφόδους ('Enterprise' deterrence 'yes' due to raids)|language=Greek|publisher=Kathimerini|date=30 June 2015}}</ref> * Athens [[bar association|Bar Association]] (DPS): DPS recommend a "Yes" vote to stay in Europe. The DPS statement said: "If the referendum ultimately, as has been said and implied, is really about "Yes" or "No" to the European Union, then the answer can not be other than "Yes". Yes to our creative participation in the EU."<ref name="Reception by Greek associations"/> * Panhellenic Federation of Teaching and Research Staff (POSDEP): Recommended a "Yes" vote.<ref name="Reception by Greek associations"/> * The Central Union of Greek Municipalities (KEDE): Recommended a "Yes" vote.<ref name="Reception by Greek associations"/> * Greece Regions Union: Recommended a "Yes" vote.<ref name="Reception by Greek associations"/>
===Positions on the vote itself (Yes/No)=== [[File:Ptmos.Non.juil15.jpg|Banner in Patmos|thumb]] In his initial address, when prime minister Tsipras of the ruling Syriza party announced the plebiscite on 5 July, he recommended a "No" vote to the Greek people.<ref>''Le Monde'', AFP, Reuters, 28 June 2015.</ref> Most other Syriza members also supported a "No" vote.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
ANEL, the other ruling party in coalition with Syriza, announced that they were campaigning for a "No" vote.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Referendum divides coalition partner | pages = | newspaper = Ekathimerini | location = | date = 2 July 2015 | url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/198863/article/ekathimerini/news/referendum-divides-coalition-partner }}</ref> The [[Far-right politics|far-right]] [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] party, not being in the government, also called for a "No" vote.<ref>{{cite news|title=LIVE! OI ΡΑΓΔΑΙΕΣ ΕΞΕΛΙΞΕΙΣ Πηγή: www.lifo.gr|url=http://www.lifo.gr/now/greece/69452|accessdate=27 June 2015|publisher=Lifo|language=el}}</ref>
[[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]], [[To Potami]] and [[PASOK]] parties campaigned for a "Yes" vote.
[[Communist Party of Greece|KKE]] declared it was against both of the latest two versions of the cash-for-reform counter proposals being submitted to the negotiation table between Greece and its public creditors (the counter proposal of the Greek government, and the latest compromise counter proposal of the institutions), and said that it would try to change the question of the referendum, so that people can vote not only against the latest compromise counter-proposal of the Institutions but also against the latest counter-proposal of the Greek government.<ref name=902Chionis>{{cite web|author=|title=Θ. Χιώνης: "Όχι" στην πρόταση-"Σκύλλα" των δανειστών και στην πρόταση-"Χάρυβδη" της κυβέρνησης (VIDEO)|url=http://www.902.gr/eidisi/politiki/70401/th-hionis-ohi-stin-protasi-skylla-ton-daneiston-kai-stin-protasi-haryvdi-tis|publisher=[http://www.902.gr 902.gr]|date=27 June 2015|accessdate=27 June 2015|language=el}}</ref>
[[Keynesian]] economists like [[James K. Galbraith]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.politico.com/agenda/story/2015/07/9-myths-about-the-greek-crisis-000131|title = 9 myths about the Greek crisis - by James K. Galbraith, Politico|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and [[Thomas Piketty]],<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Piketty : "Entre 2009 et 2014, la Grèce est le pays qui a le plus réduit son déficit" |trans-title= Piketty : "Between 2009 and 2014, Greece is the country which reduced its deficit the most" | pages = | newspaper = Marianne | location = Paris | date = 30 June 2015 | url = http://www.marianne.net/piketty-entre-2009-2014-grece-est-pays-qui-plus-reduit-son-deficit-100235110.html |language= fr }}</ref> along with [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel prize in Economics]] recipients [[Paul Krugman]]<ref>{{cite news | last = Krugman | first = Paul | title = Greece Over the Brink | pages = | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York | date = 29 June 2015 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/29/opinion/paul-krugman-greece-over-the-brink.html?_r=1 }}</ref> and [[Joseph Stiglitz]],<ref>{{cite news | last = Stiglitz | first = Joseph | title = Joseph Stiglitz: how I would vote in the Greek referendum | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 29 June 2015 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/29/joseph-stiglitz-how-i-would-vote-in-the-greek-referendum }}</ref> individually expressed their support for the "No" vote on the referendum, arguing that the current austerity programme is a bad option from an economic point of view.
==Opinion polls== According to opinion polls, since the imposition of [[capital controls]] in Greece as a result of the [[European Central Bank|ECB]]'s decision not to enlarge its [[Emergency Liquidity Assistance]] programme in Greece, there was a trend from a clear No-vote majority to a head-to-head race, or even a slight advantage for the Yes-vote, to accept the proposed bailout terms (as of 3 July 2015).<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Financial Times|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/fastft/354731/yes-edges-ahead-latest-greek-opinion-poll|title=Yes edges ahead in latest Greek opinion poll|date=3 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Fox News|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/07/03/poll-shows-tight-race-ahead-greece-referendum/|title=Poll shows tight race ahead of Greece referendum|date=3 July 2015}}</ref>
Poll results listed in the table below are in reverse chronological order and use the date the survey's fieldwork was done, as opposed to the date of publication. If that date is unknown, the date of publication is given. The highest percentage figure in each polling survey is displayed in bold, and the background shaded in the leading option's colour. In the instance of a tie no figure is shaded.

''Note: This section only covers confirmed polls conducted since the announcement of the referendum. Polls not confirmed by their respective pollsters are not shown in the table.''
===Before the referendum announcement=== Two opinion polls were conducted shortly before the announcement of the referendum on 27 June, and prior to the referendum question being made public. The first asked how people would vote if a debt-deal were put to a referendum,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=717394|title=Δημοσκόπηση: Προβάδισμα "ναι" σε δημοψήφισμα, πριν τη "βόμβα Τσίπρα"|date=28 June 2015|accessdate=29 June 2015|quote=αν η νέα επώδυνη συμφωνία παραπεμφθεί σε δημοψήφισμα, εσείς τι θα ψηφίσετε}}</ref> and the second whether people supported reaching an agreement with the creditor institutions or not.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Xinhua |url=http://www.globalpost.com/article/6597052/2015/06/28/most-greeks-want-stay-eurozone-debt-deal-lenders-survey |title=Most Greeks want stay in eurozone, debt deal with lenders: survey |date=28 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630181054/http://www.globalpost.com/article/6597052/2015/06/28/most-greeks-want-stay-eurozone-debt-deal-lenders-survey |archivedate=30 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_28/06/2015_551603|publisher=e Kathimerini|title=Greek MPs approve referendum as lenders see difficulties ahead|date=28 June 2015}}</ref> Both found support for a deal in principle.
== Results == [[File:20150705 after Referendum Syntagma Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|375x375px|Celebrations after the results were settled, [[Syntagma Square]], [[Athens]]]]
The "NO" (ΟΧΙ in Greek) vote won in all the regions of Greece, as well as in all the Greek constituencies. The highest share of "NO" votes was in [[Crete]], particularly in the constituencies of [[Heraklion]] and [[Chania]]. The highest share of "YES" (ΝΑΙ in Greek) votes was in the [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]] region – most notably in the [[Laconia]] constituency – although the number of "YES" votes were outnumbered by "NO" votes.
===Overall=== {{Referendum | yes = 2,245,537 | yespct = 38.69 | no = 3,558,450 | nopct = 61.31 | valid = 5,803,987 | validpct = 94.20 | invalid = 357,153 | invalidpct = 5.80 | total = 6,161,140 | turnoutpct = 62.50 | electorate = 9,858,508 | source = [http://ekloges.ypes.gr/current/e/public/index.html?lang=en Ministry of Interior] | option1 = Approved / YES | option2 = '''Not Approved / NO''' }}

(region)|Ionian Islands]]||'''67.31'''||32.69 |}
== Aftermath ==
Three days following the ''no'' vote of the referendum, the Athens government "formally asked for a three-year bailout from the [[eurozone]]’s rescue fund [on 8 July 2015] and pledged to start implementing some economic-policy overhauls" beginning by mid-July 2015. European finance leaders scheduled a "crisis summit" on 12 July to consider the request. The Greek request includes a "drastic turnaround" for Prime Minister Tsipras regarding "pension cuts, tax increases and other austerity measures."<ref name=wsj20150708> {{cite news |title=Greece Requests Three-Year Bailout in First Step Toward Meeting Creditors’ Demand |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/greek-prime-minister-pledges-concrete-proposals-to-bridge-creditor-impasse-1436348229 |accessdate=10 July 2015 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2015-07-08 |first1=Gabriele |last1=Steinhauser |first2=Tom |last2=Fairless}}</ref> The total amount of loans requested in the Greek proposal is 53.5 billion euros ({{USD|59 billion}}). The Greek parliament approved the Prime Minister's request on Friday, 10 July, and the completed package was forwarded to the eurogroup in advance of Sunday's meeting.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/latest-eu-economics-chief-says-greece-deal-possible-074059545.html# The Latest: Greece seeks 53.5B euros in new bailout package], accessed 10 July 2015.</ref> On Monday, 13 July, the Syriza-led government of Greece accepted a bailout package that contains larger pension cuts and tax increases than the one rejected by Greek voters in the referendum.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/07/12/thisisacoup_n_7781736.html German-Led Eurozone Launching Coup Against Greek Government]. ''[[The Huffington Post]].'' 12 July 2015.</ref>

{{Infobox Television |show_name = Idea |image = |caption = |genre = Musical |writer = |director = Jean-Christophe Averty |starring = [[Barry Gibb]]

[[Donovan|Donovan Leitch]] (Season of the Witch)
Brian Auger, [[Julie Driscoll]] (Shadows of You) |country = |language = [[English language|English]] |producer = [[Michèle Arnaud]] |runtime = |channel = [[Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen|ZDF]] |picture_format = |audio_format = |first_aired = 11 December 1968 |followed_by = }} '''Idea''' was a television special starring the [[Bee Gees]] with [[Brian Auger]] and [[Brian Auger and The Trinity|The Trinity]], [[Julie Driscoll]] and Lil Lindfors. It was aired on 11 December 1968 on [[Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen]] (ZDF). The TV special was produced by [[Michèle Arnaud]] and directed by [[Jean-Christophe Averty]].{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Bee-Gees-The-Julie-Driscoll-Brian-Auger-The-Trinity-Lil-Lindfors-Idea-TV-Special-1968/release/1517334 |title= The Idea TV Special 1968 |publisher=Discogs |accessdate=8 February 2013}} ==Background== On 12 September 1968, the Bee Gees flew to Brussels and spent two weeks recording a television show directed by Jean-Christophe Averty to promote their album ''[[Idea (album)|Idea]]'' on French television. It features the guest appearances by Brian Auger and The Trinity, Julie Driscoll and Lil Lindfors. Swedish singer Lil Lindfors performed "[[Words (Bee Gees song)|Words]]" in her native language. The Bee Gees performed the songs from ''[[Horizontal (album)|Horizontal]]'' and ''Idea'' (1968). The special effects on "[[Indian Gin and Whisky Dry]]" to make it appear that the Bee Gees are bouncing up and down in the glasses. On "[[I Started a Joke]]" features a floating question marks.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=KugbDQHX0R8C&pg=PT354&dq=bee+gees+brussels&hl=fil&sa=X&ei=xQUVUZOkCMOAiQeurYCADQ&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA |title=The Bee Gees: Tales of the Brothers Gibb |last=Hughes |first=Andrew |accessdate=8 February 2013}} During the Bee Gees' stay in Brussels, the Belgian police would not allow their limousine to stop outside the hotel, The Metropole, due to a fashion show held there by French pop star [[Johnny Hallyday]]'s wife [[Sylvie Vartan]]. [[Maurice Gibb|Maurice]]'s leg was injured as he attempted to get out of the car, leading to a formal complaint being filed with a chief of police by the Bee Gees' manager [[Robert Stigwood]]. ==Songs== #[[Bee Gees]] — "[[Massachusetts (Bee Gees song)|Massachusetts]]" #Bee Gees — "[[Idea (song)|Idea]]" #Julie Driscoll, Brian Auger & The Trinity — "[[This Wheel's On Fire]]" #Bee Gees — "[[I Started a Joke]]" #Bee Gees — "[[Such a Shame (Bee Gees song)|Such a Shame]]" #Julie Driscoll, Brian Auger & The Trinity — Break It Up #Bee Gees — "[[When the Swallows Fly]]" #Bee Gees — "[[Indian Gin and Whisky Dry]]" #Brian Auger & The Trinity — Black Cat #Bee Gees — "[[I've Gotta Get a Message to You]]" #Julie Driscoll, Brian Auger & The Trinity — "Season of the Witch" #Bee Gees — "[[Harry Braff]]" #Lil Lindfors — "[[Words (Bee Gees song)|Words]]" #Julie Driscoll, Brian Auger & Julie Driscoll — "Road to Cairo" #Julie Driscoll, Brian Auger & The Trinity — "Shadows of You" #Bee Gees — "[[Swan Song (song)|Swan Song]]" #Bee Gees — "I Have Decided to Join the Airforce" ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Bee Gees}} [[Category:Bee Gees]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:British television specials]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{primary sources|date=August 2015}} [[File:Disha Patani at the ‘Amazon India Fashion Week Spring Summer 2017’.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Disha Patani]] at India Fashion Week, 2016]] [[File:Salmanrampwalk.png|thumb|upright=0.6|[[Salman Khan]] walking the ramp, India Fashion Week]]
'''India Fashion Week''' is a bi-annual [[fashion week]] organized and promoted by the [[Fashion Design Council of India]]. It was sponsored by Wills Lifestyle from 2006-2014 before Amazon.in became the sponsor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fdci.org/newsdetails.aspx?nid=889|title=India Fashion Week - Sponsor Page}}</ref>
The first event in 2000 featured the work of 33 designers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fashion week in India|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/884706.stm |publisher=BBC News|date=18 August 2000 |accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref> There were also over thirty presenters at the Spring Fashion Week in March 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ramp fun begins: Wills Lifestyle India Fashion Week Autumn/Winter 2013 opens today |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Fashion/Ramp-fun-begins-Wills-Lifestyle-India-Fashion-Week-Autumn-Winter-2013-opens-today/Article1-1025245.aspx |newspaper=Hindustan Times |date=12 March 2013 |accessdate=}}</ref>
In 2010, fire permits were not secured in time for the first day events which caused an extra day to be added to accommodate the presentations that had been cancelled on the first day.<ref name="2010reuters">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/indiamasala/2010/03/29/fashion-diary-clothes-controversies-and-a-finale-that-wasnt/|title=Fashion diary – clothes, controversies and a finale that wasn’t|last=David Lalmalsawma|date=29 March 2010|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>
The WIFW autumn-winter 2014 started on 26 March 2014 with actress [[Shilpa Shetty]] walking the ramp wearing the collections of designer [[Tarun Tahiliani]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Shilpa Shetty shines in Tarun Tahiliani’s Collections at Wills Lifestyle India Fashion Week|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/03/shilpa-shetty-shines-in-tarun-tahilianis-collections-at-wills-lifestyle-india-fashion-week/|work=IANS|publisher=news.biharprabha.com|accessdate=27 March 2014}}</ref> The WIFW spring-summer 2015 event started on 8 October 2014 at New Delhi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Monica Dogra goes bold at Wills Lifestyle India Fashion Week|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/10/monica-dogra-goes-bold-at-wills-lifestyle-india-fashion-week/|accessdate=12 October 2014|agency=IANS|publisher=news.biharprabha.com|date=12 October 2014}}</ref>
The Indian fashion industry has become a growing industry with international events such as the Indian Fashion Week and annual shows by fashion designers being held across major cities of the country.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cover Story: Global Design for Indian Fashion|journal=MARKATHON|year=2012|volume=3|issue=10|url=http://web.mit.edu/hauser/www/Hauser%20Articles%205.3.12/Hauser%20Interview%20Markathon%20April%202012.pdf}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Lakme Fashion Week]] *[[India Runway Week]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Liberation Day
|type = national |longtype = [[National Day]] |image = Liberation Day in Jersey 2-0070.jpg |caption = Liberation Day in Jersey, 2007 |official_name = ''Liberation Day'' |nickname = |observedby = [[Jersey]], [[Guernsey]] |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |scheduling = same day each year |date = 9 May |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = [[German occupation of the Channel Islands]] during [[World War II]] }} In [[Jersey]] and [[Guernsey]], '''Liberation Day''' ([[Jèrriais]]: ''Jour d'la Libéthâtion'') is celebrated each year on 9 May, to mark the end of the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands|occupation by Nazi Germany]] during World War II. It is celebrated as Guernsey and Jersey's national day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/jersey/8533765.stm |title=Jersey 'lieu day' motion for Sunday Liberation Day |publisher=BBC News |date=24 February 2010 |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
==History== {{main|Liberation of the German-occupied Channel Islands}} [[File:Jour d'la Libéthâtion Jèrri 9 d'Mai 2011 065.jpg|thumb|left|Re-enacting the raising of flags on Liberation Day 2011]] On 9 May 1945, [[HMS Bulldog (H91)|HMS ''Bulldog'']] arrived in [[St Peter Port]], Guernsey, and the German forces surrendered unconditionally aboard the vessel at dawn. British forces landed in St Peter Port shortly afterwards, greeted by crowds of joyous but malnourished islanders singing, amongst other patriotic songs, "Sarnia-Cherie".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=prGeoO4bgUw |title=Sarnia Chérie (Guernsey anthem) - Sung on Liberation Day in 1945}}</ref>
The same day, {{HMS|Beagle|H30|6}}, which had set out from [[Plymouth]], arrived in [[Jersey]] to accept the surrender of the occupying forces there. Two naval officers, Surgeon Lieutenant Ronald McDonald and Sub Lieutenant R Milne, were met by the Harbour Master, who escorted them to his office where they together hoisted the [[Union Flag]], before also raising it on the flagstaff of the Pomme D'Or Hotel. This has been re-enacted every year on Liberation Day since 1995. From 2003 to 2011 Harbour Master and Jerseyman Captain Howard Le Cornu performed this annually. His father, John E. Le Cornu, and uncle, David M. Le Cornu, had been in the crowds and had witnessed the occasion on 9 May 1945.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-jersey-13336914 |title=Jersey youth vital to Liberation Day – Bailiff |date=9 May 2011 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-jersey-13338561 |title=Jersey celebrates Liberation Day anniversary |publisher=BBC News |date=9 May 2011}}</ref>
Sark was liberated on 10 May 1945, and the German troops in Alderney surrendered on 16 May 1945.{{Citation needed|date = May 2018}}
==Official status==
The Public Holidays and Bank Holidays (Jersey) Act 1952 established Liberation Day as a public holiday if it fell on a weekday.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public Holidays and Bank Holidays (Jersey) Act 1952|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fhtm%2fROFiles%2fR%26O3000-3999%2fJersey_R_%26_O_3038.htm|accessdate=13 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808043848/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fhtm%2FROFiles%2FR&O3000-3999%2FJersey_R_&_O_3038.htm|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=}}</ref> The Public Holidays and Bank Holidays (Jersey) Act 2010 further laid down that Liberation was also to be a public holiday if it falls on a Saturday.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public Holidays and Bank Holidays (Jersey) Act 2010|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f15%2f15.560.20_PublicHolidaysandBankHolidaysAct2010_RevisedEdition_1January2012.htm|accessdate=13 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808043851/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F15%2F15.560.20_PublicHolidaysandBankHolidaysAct2010_RevisedEdition_1January2012.htm|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=}}</ref> It is not a public holiday, and no day off in lieu is provided, if it falls on a Sunday.<ref>{{cite web|title=States of Jersey Official Report|url=http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/Pages/Hansard.aspx?docid=4787a29e00a6babd61bafe7642095881_StatesAssembly&qtf_teaser:query=AND(bcalcontent.bidxcontentlvl1:%22liberation%22,ANY(bcalcontent.bidxcontentlvl1:%22day%22,bcalcontent.bidxcontentlvl1:%22days%22))#_Toc274307186|accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref>
==Ceremonies== [[File:Jour d'la Libéthâtion Jèrri 9 d'Mai 2012 35.jpg|thumb|Bailiff, Lieutenant-Governor and other officials in procession on Liberation Day 2012]] Since the 50th anniversary of Liberation in 1995, a pattern of official ceremonies has developed based in and around Liberation Square in [[Saint Helier]] where the events at the Harbour Master's Office and Pomme D'Or Hotel occurred in 1945. Following a special sitting of the [[States of Jersey]] in the morning, States Members, clergy, the [[Bailiff of Jersey]], the [[Lieutenant-Governor of Jersey|Lieutenant-Governor]], [[Jurat]]s, Crown Officers and other officials process from the Royal Square to Liberation Square accompanied by the Royal Mace and the Bailiff's Seal. An open air ecumenical service takes place in Liberation Square followed by the singing of "Man Bieau P'tit Jèrri"/"Beautiful Jersey" (in Jèrriais and English) and a re-enactment of the raising of flags (including that at [[Fort Regent]]). A parade of vintage and military vehicles, bands and service organisations is reviewed by the official party.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
The afternoon community celebrations are of an informal character, including a programme of entertainments and stalls in Saint Helier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/jersey/8670959.stm |title=Jersey islanders mark Liberation Day |publisher=BBC News |date=9 May 2010 |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
An official ceremony also takes place at the Crematorium where there is a memorial to victims and slave workers of various nationalities. Representatives of affected nationalities take part in the commemoration.<ref>{{cite web|title=Never forget the price of freedom|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/news/2012/05/10/never-forget-the-price-of-freedom/|accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Liberation Day]] * [[Victory in Europe Day]]
==References== {{Commons category|Liberation Day in Jersey}} {{portal|Channel Islands|World War II}} {{reflist|30em}}

page.title: List of blues festivals in Canada

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2018}} '''Canadian blues festivals''' range from small, community-based festivals that feature mostly local performers to major corporate-sponsored festivals that draw nationally and internationally prominent blues bands and huge crowds. Some of the large festivals include the [[Ottawa Bluesfest]], Bluesfest Windsor, the [[Harvest Jazz & Blues Festival]] in [[Fredericton]], New Brunswick, Tremblant International Blues Festival in [[Mont-Tremblant]], [[Quebec]] and the [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]]. These festivals, which are usually organized by volunteer-based blues societies, are an important part of the [[Canadian blues]] scene.
==List== ===British Columbia=== [[File:Matt Andersen entertaining the Burnaby Blues and Roots Festival.jpg|thumb|Matt Andersen entertaining the Burnaby Blues and Roots Festival]] * [https://www.burnabybluesfestival.com/ Burnaby Blues + Roots Festival] - August in [[Burnaby]]<ref>[http://www.burnabybluesfestival.com Burnaby Blues + Roots Festival]</ref> * [http://www.hornby-blues.bc.ca Hornby Island Blues Workshop] - May in [[Hornby Island, British Columbia|Hornby Island]] * [http://www.penderharbourbluesfestival.com Pender Harbour Blues Festival] - early June in [[Pender Harbour, British Columbia|Pender Harbour]] * [http://www.rootsandblues.ca Salmon Arm Roots and Blues Festival] - August in [[Salmon Arm]], in British Columbia's interior * [http://www.nanaimobluesfestival.com/ Summertime Blues Festival] - August in [[Nanaimo]] * [https://jazzvictoria.ca/blues-bash Vancouver Island Blues Bash] - Labour Day Weekend in [[Victoria, British Columbia]]
===Alberta=== * [http://www.beaumontblues.net Beaumont Blues & Roots Festival] - June (previously Labour Day long weekend) in [[Beaumont, Alberta|Beaumont]] * [http://www.calgarybluesfest.com Calgary International Blues Festival] - August * [http://www.calgarybluesfest.com Calgary Midwinter Bluesfest] - February * [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]] - August in [[Edmonton]]
===Saskatchewan=== * [http://www.saskatoonbluessociety.ca Saskatoon Blues Festival] - End of February in [[Saskatoon|Saskatchewan]]
===Manitoba=== * [http://www.greatwoodspark.com/Festival-greatwoods/index.htm Great Woods Music Festival] - August in [[Beausejour, Manitoba|Beausejour]], [[Manitoba]]
===Ontario=== * Atomic Blues Fest - [[Lindsay, Ontario|Lindsay]] * [http://www.barriejazzbluesfest.com/ Barrie Jazz and Blues Festival] - second weekend in June in [[Barrie]] * [[Bluesfest International Windsor|Bluesfest International]] - July in [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]] and [[London, Ontario|London]] * Boon's House Blues & Roots Festival - July in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] * [http://www.burlingtonjazzbluesfestival.ca Burlington Jazz & Blues Festival] - July in [[Burlington, Ontario|Burlington]] * [http://www.calabogieblues.com Calabogie Blues & Ribfest] - August in [[Calabogie, Ontario|Calabogie]] * [http://www.canalbankshuffle.com Canal Bank Shuffle] - October in [[Thorold]] * [http://www.coalflatsblues.com Coal Flats Blues Festival] - September in [[Port Burwell, Ontario|Port Burwell]] * [http://www.escarpmentblues.ca Escarpment Blues Festival] - mid-July in [[Milton, Ontario|Milton]] * [http://www.downtowngeorgetown.com/events/village-festival Georgetown - Festival on Main] - Father's Day Weekend, third weekend in June in [[Georgetown, Ontario|Georgetown]] * House Full of Blues Festival - [[North Bay, Ontario|North Bay]] * [http://www.kitchenerbluesfestival.com Kitchener Blues Festival] - August in [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]] * [http://www.kingstonblues.com Limestone City Blues Festival] - late August in [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]] * [http://www.londonbluesfest.com London Blues Festival] - August in [[London, Ontario]] * Mudcat Blues Fest - August in [[Dunnville, Ontario|Dunnville]] * [http://www.orangevillebluesandjazz.ca Orangeville Blues and Jazz Festival] - first weekend of June in [[Orangeville, Ontario|Orangeville]] * [http://www.orilliaspringblues.com Orillia Spring Blues Festival] - [[Orillia]] * [http://www.oshawajazzandbluesfestival.com Oshawa Jazz and Blues Festival] - August in [[Oshawa]] * [[Ottawa Bluesfest]] - July in [[Ottawa]] * [http://www.paisleyrocks.com/the-artists.html Paisley Blues Fest], first weekend of june in [[Paisley, Ontario]] * [http://www.porquis.ca/web-content/ Porquis Blues Festival] - early July in Porquis * Port Credit Blues and Jazz Festival (also called the [http://www.southsideshuffle.com "Southside Shuffle"]) - early September in [[Port Credit]], Mississauga * [http://www.stratfordbluesandribfest.ca Stratford Blues and Ribfest] - June in [[Stratford, Ontario|Stratford]] * [http://www.tbayblues.ca Thunder Bay Blues Festival] - July in [[Thunder Bay]] * [http://www.twistedpines.com Twisted Pines Blues Festival] - May in the Midland/[[Penetanguishene]] area * [http://www.wasagabeachblues.com Wasaga Beach Blues] - September 13–15, 2013, at [http://www.stonebridgetowncentre.com/ Stonebridge Town Centre] in [[Wasaga Beach, Ontario|Wasaga Beach]] * [http://www.atikokanarts.ca Women in the Wilds Blues Festival] - September in [[Atikokan]], Northwestern Ontario * [http://www.bluesfestwindsor.com/ Bluesfest Windsor] - July 10–12, 2015 in Windsor, Ontario
===Quebec=== * [http://jazzetblues.com/ Festival de Jazz et Blues de Saguenay] - April in [[Chicoutimi]] * [http://www.westislandbluesfestival.com/home.html West Island Blues Festival] - June in [[Pierrefonds-Roxboro|Pierrefonds]]/[[Pierrefonds-Roxboro|Roxboro]], [[Island of Montreal]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160301073455/http://www.montrealjazzfest.com/default-en.aspx Montreal International Jazz Festival] - June in [[Montreal]] (Blues Stage) * [http://www.tremblantblues.com/home/ Tremblant International Blues Festival] - July in [[Mont-Tremblant, Quebec|Mont-Tremblant]] * [http://sherblues.ca/ Sherblues & Folk] - July in [[Sherbrooke]] * [http://www.lileenblues.ca/programmation.html l'Ile en Blues] - August in [[Saint-Laurent-de-l'Île-d'Orléans]] * [http://nuitsblues.ca/ Les Nuits Blues Laurentides] - August in [[Saint-Sauveur, Quebec|Saint-Sauveur]] * [http://www.donnaconablues.com/ Festival de Blues de Donnacona] - August in [[Donnacona]] * [http://3renblues.com/ Trois-Rivières en Blues] - August in [[Trois-Rivières]] * [http://www.centrevilledejoliette.qc.ca/october-blues Festival de Blues de Joliette] - October in [[Joliette]]
===East coast === * Dutch Mason Blues Festival - August in [[Truro, Nova Scotia]]<ref>[http://www.dutchmason.com/festival/ Dutch Mason Blues Festival]</ref> * [[Harvest Jazz & Blues Festival]] - September in [[Fredericton]], [[New Brunswick]] * Wreckhouse International Jazz & Blues Festival - early July in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]]<ref>[http://wreckhousejazzandblues.com/ Wreckhouse International Jazz & Blues Festival]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
