page.title: List of official overseas trips made by Prince William, Duke of Cambridge

revision.text:
[[File:Canada Ottawa William Kate 2011 (2).jpg|thumb|right|The [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Duke]] and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Duchess of Cambridge]] at the official Canada Day celebration in Ottawa, 2011, during their first joint royal tour outside the United Kingdom]] This is a '''list of official overseas visits and Commonwealth tours made by the Duke of Cambridge'''. [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]], as a child, first traveled with his parents on official visits and tours. Now he is one of the United Kingdom's most important ambassadors; sometimes the Duke travels overseas as a representative of the UK. The Duke also undertakes tours of [[Commonwealth realm]]s, of which [[Elizabeth II|his paternal grandmother]] is the queen, as her representative or as a member of the realm's royal family. ==Summary of official overseas visits== {| class=wikitable |- !Number of visits !Country |- |1 visit |[[Afghanistan]], [[Bhutan]], [[Botswana]], [[China]], [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[India]], [[Israel]], [[Japan]], [[Lesotho]], [[Malaysia]], [[Malta]], [[Norway]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Poland]], [[Singapore]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[South Africa]], [[Sweden]], [[Tuvalu]], [[Vietnam]]{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/prince-william-visits-vietnam-to-promote-wildlife-conservation-10659608|title=Prince William visits Vietnam to promote wildlife conservation|author=Rhiannon Mills|publisher=Sky News|date=16 November 2016|accessdate=17 November 2016}} |- |2 visits |[[United States]], [[Germany]]{{cite web|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/prince-william-travel-germany-ahead-032403198.html|title=Prince William to travel to Germany ahead of Cambridges' Canada tour|work=Hello!|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=9 August 2016|accessdate=17 November 2016}} |- |3 visits |[[Australia]], [[Belgium]] |- |4 visits |[[Canada]] |- |5 visits |[[France]], [[New Zealand]] |} ==List of official overseas visits== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! class="unsortable" | Date !! Country !! class="unsortable" |Areas visited !! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | nowrap | 20 March–17 April 1983 || {{Flagu|Australia}} || [[Alice Springs]], [[Canberra]], [[Melbourne]] || At nine months old, the Prince accompanied the [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince]] and [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess of Wales]] on their official tour of Australia and New Zealand.{{cite web|url=http://www.dukeandduchessofcambridge.org/the-duke-of-cambridge/royal-duties/countries-visited|title=Countries visited|publisher=The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge|accessdate=2 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/dec/20/prince-william-and-kate-to-visit-australia-and-new-zealand-in-april|title=Prince William and Kate to visit Australia and New Zealand in April|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |17–30 April 1983 || {{Flagu|New Zealand}} || [[Auckland]] ||The Prince accompanied the Prince and Princess of Wales. |- |22–27 October 1991 || {{Flagu|Canada}} || [[Toronto]], [[Ottawa]], [[Niagara Falls]] ||Visit with the Prince and Princess of Wales and [[Prince Harry]]. |- |23–24 March 1998 || {{Flagu|Canada}} || [[Vancouver]] || Visited Vancouver for public engagements with the Prince of Wales and Prince Harry. |- |28 June–10 July 2005 || {{Flagu|New Zealand}} || [[Wellington]], [[Auckland]] || Prince William was invited by the [[British and Irish Lions]] rugby team to join them on their tour to New Zealand. While there, the Prince also represented [[Queen Elizabeth II|the Queen]] at events to commemorate the end of the [[Second World War]]. |- |10 June 2006 || {{Flagu|Germany}} || [[Frankfurt]] || In his capacity as President of The [[Football Association]], the Prince attended an opening round of the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. |- |17–19 January 2010 || {{Flagu|New Zealand}} || [[Wellington]], [[Auckland]] ||Prince William represented the Queen at the opening of the [[Supreme Court of New Zealand#Building|Supreme Court building]].{{cite web|title=Visit of Prince William to New Zealand|url=http://www.nzembassy.com/united-kingdom/news/visit-of-prince-william-to-new-zealand|website=New Zealand High Commission London|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |15–16 June 2010 || {{Flagu|Botswana}} || [[Gaborone]] || Prince William and Prince Harry visited Botswana, Lesotho and South Africa in June 2010. The visit was the first time that the Princes carried out joint engagements overseas. The visit to Botswana was on behalf of [[Tusk Trust]], of which Prince William is Patron. |- |15–19 June 2010 || {{Flagu|South Africa}}|| [[Cape Town]] ||In support of The [[Football Association|FA]]'s Bid to host the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], the Prince, in his capacity as President of The [[Football Association]], attended an opening round of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. |- |15–19 June 2010 || {{Flagu|Lesotho}} || [[Semonkong]] ||The Princes visited projects supported by [[Sentebale]], the charity which Prince Harry founded with [[Prince Seeiso of Lesotho]]. |- |14 November 2010 || {{Flagu|Afghanistan}} || [[Camp Bastion]] || Attended a [[Remembrance Day|Service of Remembrance]]. |- |17–18 March 2011 || {{Flagu|New Zealand}} || [[Christchurch]], [[Greymouth]]|| Attended a Memorial service on behalf of the Queen for [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]]. The Prince also visited Greymouth, near the site of the [[Pike River Mine disaster]]. |- |19–21 March 2011 || {{Flagu|Australia}} || [[Queensland]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]]||Prince William visited the flood damaged areas of Queensland and Victoria.{{cite web|title=Prince William sees cyclone recovery work in Australia|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12793661|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |[[2011 royal tour of Canada|30 June–8 July 2011]] || {{Flagu|Canada}} || [[Ontario]], [[Quebec]], [[Prince Edward Island]], [[Northwest Territories]], [[Alberta]]|| The first official overseas tour of the Duke and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Duchess of Cambridge]] after their [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|wedding]] in April 2011. |- |8–10 July 2011 || {{Flagu|United States}} || [[Los Angeles]] || In his capacity as President, the Duke and Duchess attended an event hosted by [[BAFTA]].[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/171091/20110628/prince-william-kate-will-attend-bafta-brits-to-watch-event.htm "Royals William and Kate to Attend L.A. 'BAFTA Brits to Watch' Event."] 28 June 2011. |- |2 November 2011 || {{Flagu|Denmark}} || [[Copenhagen]] ||The Duke and Duchess visited the [[UNICEF]] Headquarters. |- |11–13 September 2012 || {{Flagu|Singapore}} || [[Singapore]]||[[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Diamond Jubilee Tour]] on behalf of the Queen with The Duchess of Cambridge. A state dinner was held in their honour by [[Tony Tan|President Tony Tan]].{{cite web|title=Prince William and Kate visit Singapore|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19553238|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |13–15 September 2012 || {{Flagu|Malaysia}} || [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Sabah]]||Diamond Jubilee Tour on behalf of the Queen with the Duchess of Cambridge. |- |16–18 September 2012 || nowrap | {{Flagu|Solomon Islands}} || [[Honiara]], [[Tavanipupu]]||Diamond Jubilee Tour on behalf of the Queen with the Duchess of Cambridge. |- |18–19 September 2012 || {{Flagu|Tuvalu}} || [[Funafuti]]||Diamond Jubilee Tour on behalf of the Queen with the Duchess of Cambridge. |- |7–16 April 2014 || {{Flagu|New Zealand}} || [[Wellington]], [[Blenheim, New Zealand|Blenheim]], [[Auckland]], [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]], [[Cambridge, New Zealand|Cambridge]], [[Dunedin]], [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]], [[Christchurch]]||[[Prince George of Cambridge|Prince George]] accompanied the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge on their official tour of New Zealand and Australia. |- |[[2014 royal tour of Australia|16–25 April 2014]] || {{Flagu|Australia}} || [[Sydney]], [[Brisbane]], [[Uluru]], [[Adelaide]], [[Canberra]]||Prince George accompanied the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. |- |6 June 2014 || {{Flagu|France}} || [[Arromanches]] ||The Duke and Duchess attended the commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the [[Normandy Landings]] at [[Gold Beach]]. |- |4 August 2014 || {{Flagu|Belgium}} || [[Liege]] ||The Duke and Duchess attended [[First World War]] centenary commemorations at the Cointe Inter Allied Memorial, and the [[St Symphorien Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery|Saint Symphorien Military Cemetery]]. |- |20–21 September 2014 || {{Flagu|Malta}} || [[Valletta]] ||The Duke represented the Queen on the visit to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Malta's Independence. The Duchess of Cambridge was originally due to undertake the visit, however she was suffering from acute [[morning sickness]].{{cite web|title=A statement about The Duchess of Cambridge no longer visiting Malta this weekend|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/media/press-releases/statement-about-the-duchess-of-cambridge-no-longer-visiting-malta-weekend|website=princeofwales.gov.uk|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |7–9 December 2014 || {{Flagu|United States}} || [[New York City]], [[Washington, D.C.]] ||The Duke met with President [[Barack Obama]] in the [[White House]].{{cite web|title=The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will visit the United States of America|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/media/press-releases/the-duke-and-duchess-of-cambridge-will-visit-the-united-states-of-america|website=princeofwales.gov.uk|accessdate=2 March 2015}}{{cite web|title=Prince William meets Barack Obama at the White House|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-30385976|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |26 February–1 March 2015 || {{Flagu|Japan}} || [[Tokyo]], [[Fukushima, Fukushima|Fukushima]], [[Ishinomaki]], [[Onagawa]] ||The Duke met with [[Emperor Akihito]] and [[Shinzō Abe|Prime Minister Shinzō Abe]], and toured areas devastated by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tsunami]].{{cite web|title=HRH The Duke of Cambridge to visit Japan and China - Focus on cultural exchange and creative partnerships|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/media/press-releases/hrh-the-duke-of-cambridge-visit-japan-and-china-focus-cultural-exchange-and|website=princeofwales.gov.uk|accessdate=2 March 2015}}{{cite web|title=Prince William meets Japan tsunami survivors who handwrote newspaper|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31681184|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |1–4 March 2015 || {{Flagu|China}} || [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]], [[Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture|Xishuangbanna]] ||The Duke met with [[Xi Jinping|President Xi Jinping]].{{cite web|title=Prince William meets Chinese President Xi Jinping|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31683579|website=BBC News|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |- |10–13 April 2016 || {{Flagu|India}} || [[Mumbai]], [[Delhi]], [[Kaziranga National Park|Kaziranga]] ||The Duke and Duchess met with [[Prime Minister Narendra Modi]].{{cite web|title=Prince William and Kate Middleton Had Lunch With Narendra Modi|url=http://time.com/4290437/william-kate-royals-narendra-modi-india/|website=Time|accessdate=12 April 2016}} |- |14–15 April 2016 || {{Flagu|Bhutan}} || [[Thimpu]] || The Duke and Duchess met with [[Druk Gyalpo]] (King of Bhutan) [[Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck]] and his Queen consort, [[Jetsun Pema]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dukeandduchessofcambridge.org/news-and-diary/12259/press-release|title=Press release|publisher=}} |- |16 April 2016 || {{Flagu|India}} || [[Agra]] ||The Duke and Duchess visited India again to see the [[Taj Mahal]] in [[Agra]]. |- | 30 June–1 July 2016 || {{Flagu|France}} || [[Thiepval]] || The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry attended the centenary commemorations for the [[Battle of the Somme]] at the [[Thiepval Memorial]].{{cite web|title=Battle of the Somme Centenary Commemorations|url=https://www.royal.uk/battle-somme-centenary-commemorations|date=4 February 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180204033642/https://www.royal.uk/battle-somme-centenary-commemorations|archivedate=4 February 2018|deadurl=yes}} |- |23 August 2016 || {{Flagu|Germany}} || [[Düsseldorf]] ||The Duke visited [[Düsseldorf]] to celebrate 70 years of the state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. |- |24 September– 1 October 2016 || {{Flagu|Canada}} || [[British Columbia]], [[Yukon]] || [[Prince George of Cambridge|Prince George]] and [[Princess Charlotte of Cambridge|Princess Charlotte]] accompanied The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge on their official tour of Canada. |- |16–17 November 2016 || {{Flagu|Vietnam}} || [[Hanoi]] || The Duke visited Vietnam to promote wildlife conservation. |- |17–18 March 2017 || {{flagu|France}} || [[Paris]] || The Duke and Duchess met with [[François Hollande|President François Hollande]]. |- |9 April 2017 || {{flagu|France}} || [[Lille]] || The Duke and Prince Harry attended the centenary commemorations for the [[Battle of Vimy Ridge]]. |- |17–19 July 2017 || {{flagu|Poland}} || [[Warsaw]], [[Gdansk]] || Prince George and [[Princess Charlotte of Cambridge|Princess Charlotte]] accompanied the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. |- |19–21 July 2017 || {{flagu|Germany}} || [[Berlin]], [[Heidelberg]], [[Hamburg]] || Prince George and Princess Charlotte accompanied The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. |- |30–31 July 2017 || {{flagu|Belgium}} || [[Ypres]] || The Duke and Duchess attended commemorations to mark the centenary of the [[Battle of Passchendaele]]. |- |12 October 2017 || {{flagu|Belgium}} || [[Flanders]] || The Duke attended the centenary commemorations for the [[Battle of Passchendaele]]. |- |29–30 November 2017 || {{flagu|Finland}} || [[Helsinki]] || The Duke met with [[Sauli Niinisto|President Sauli Niinisto]]. |- |30–31 January 2018 || {{flagu|Sweden}} || [[Stockholm]] || The Duke and Duchess were accompanied on engagements by [[Crown Princess Victoria]] and [[Prince Daniel]].{{cite web|url=http://time.com/5124733/will-kate-swedish-royal-family/|title=See Prince William and Kate Middleton With the Swedish Royal Family|publisher=Time|first=Mahita|last=Gajanan|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=30 January 2018}} |- |1–2 February 2018 || {{flagu|Norway}} || [[Oslo]] || The Duke and Duchess were accompanied on engagements by [[Crown Prince Haakon]] and [[Crown Princess Mette-Marit]]. |- |24–25 June 2018 || {{flagu|Jordan}} || [[Amman]] || The Duke met with [[Crown Prince Hussein]]. He also met Syrian refugee children and toured the Roman ruins of the [[Jerash]] archaeological site.{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/uks-prince-william-begins-politically-delicate-mideast-trip-56119840|title=Prince William on historic Mideast trip, praises Jordan ties|publisher=ABC News|first=Karin|last=Laub|date=24 June 2018|accessdate=24 June 2018}} |- |25–28 June 2018 || {{flagu|Israel}}
{{flagu|Palestine}} || [[Jerusalem]], [[Tel Aviv]];
[[Ramallah]] || The Duke met with [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu]] and [[Mahmoud Abbas|President Mahmoud Abbas]]. This was the first-ever official visit by a British royal family member to Israel and Palestine. He visited holy sites in Jerusalem and the burial site of his great-grandmother [[Princess Andrew of Greece and Denmark]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-royals-israel-palestinians/uks-prince-william-visits-jerusalem-holy-sites-great-grandmothers-tomb-idUSKBN1JO0M3|title=UK's Prince William visits Jerusalem holy sites, great-grandmother's tomb|publisher=Reuters|first=Jeffrey|last=Heller|date=28 June 2018|accessdate=29 June 2018}} |- |8 August 2018 || {{flagu|France}} || [[Amiens]] || The Duke of Cambridge and Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] attended commemorations at [[Amiens Cathedral]] marking the centenary of the [[Battle of Amiens (1918)|Battle of Amiens]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-45107803|title=WW1 centenary: William and PM mark Battle of Amiens|publisher=BBC|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=8 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/amiens-battle-prince-william-theresa-may-first-world-war-france-a8482101.html|title=Prince William and Theresa May to attend Battle of Amiens centenary commemorations|publisher=The Independent|first=Tony|last=Jones|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=8 August 2018}} |- |24–30 September 2018 || {{flagu|Namibia}}
{{flagu|Tanzania}}
{{flagu|Kenya}} || [[Dar es Salaam]]
(among others) || As president of United for Wildlife and patron of [[Tusk Trust]], the Duke visited the three African countries ahead of the Illegal Wildlife Trade Conference in October. Highlights of the tour included visit to the [[Irish Guards]] in Kenya, discussing wildlife issues with Tanzanian [[John Magufuli|President John Magufuli]], and meeting Namibian [[Nangolo Mbumba|Vice President Nangolo Mbumba]] to celebrate UK-Namibia relations.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2018-09-18/william-to-visit-africa-to-promote-fight-against-illegal-wildlife-trade/|title=Prince William to visit Africa to promote fight against illegal wildlife trade|publisher=ITV News|date=18 September 2018|accessdate=20 September 2018}} |- |} ==See also== *[[List of state visits made by Elizabeth II]] *[[List of official overseas trips made by Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Official overseas trips made by Prince William, Duke of Cambridge}} [[Category:Foreign relations of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Personal timelines|William, Duke of Cambridge]] [[Category:Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Overseas trips]] [[Category:Lists of diplomatic trips|William, Duke of Cambridge]] [[Category:Royal visits|William, Duke of Cambridge]]

{{See also|Category:Lists of wars by date}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} [[File:Ongoing conflicts around the world.svg|thumb|400px|
Ongoing armed conflicts in 2018; updated {{monthyear}}.
---- {{legend|maroon|Major wars, 10,000 or more deaths in current or past year}} {{legend|red|Wars, 1,000–9,999 deaths in current or past year}} {{legend|orange|Minor conflicts, 100–999 deaths in current or past year}} {{legend|gold|Skirmishes and clashes, fewer than 100 deaths in current or past year}}]] The following is a '''list of ongoing armed conflicts''' that are taking place around the world and continue to result in violence. ==List guidelines== This list of ongoing armed conflicts is for the sole purpose of identifying present-day conflicts and the death toll associated with each conflict. The guidelines of inclusion are: * Armed conflicts consist in the use of armed force between two or more organized armed groups, governmental or non-governmental alike.{{cite web|title=How is the Term "Armed Conflict" Defined in International Humanitarian Law?|url=https://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/opinion-paper-armed-conflict.pdf|website=International Committee of the Red Cross|date=March 2008|accessdate=1 February 2015}} Interstate, intrastate and non-state armed conflicts are listed. * Fatality figures include battle-related deaths (military and civilian) as well as civilians intentionally targeted by the parties to an armed conflict. Only direct deaths resulting from violence are included for the current and past year; excess deaths indirectly resulting from famine, disease and disruption of services are included along with violent deaths only in the cumulative fatalities count, when available.'' * Listed conflicts are at least 100 cumulative deaths in total and at least 1 death in current or past calendar year. * Fatality totals may be underestimated or unavailable due to a lack of information. A figure with a plus sign indicates that at least that many people have died (e.g. 455+ indicates that at least 455 people have died) – the actual toll could be higher. * Location refers to the state(s) where the main violence takes place, not to the warring parties. Italics indicate disputed territories and [[list of states with limited recognition|unrecognized states]]''. * Only states with ongoing military activity are listed, past states and states where conflicts are no longer active are omitted. * Military conflicts that no longer produce deaths are not listed here, but can be found in the historical [[list of wars]] and the [[list of wars extended by diplomatic irregularity]]. {{anchor|Major wars}} ==10,000 or more deaths in current or past year== The {{table row counter|id=conflicts10000|ignore=1}} conflicts in the following list have caused at least 10,000 direct violent deaths in current or past calendar year. {| class="wikitable sortable" id="conflicts10000" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox Theatre |name = Manoel Theatre |image = [[File:Manoel theatre (12843882153).jpg|200px]] |caption = Façade of the Manoel Theatre |address = 115, Old Theatre Street |city = [[Valletta]] |country = [[Malta]] |designation = Grade 1 [[listed building]] |latitude = |longitude = |architect = |owner = |capacity = 623 |type = |opened = 1732 |yearsactive = 1732-present |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = '''Teatro Pubblico''' (1732-1800)
'''Teatro Reale''' (1800-1873) |production = |currentuse = |website = http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/ }} The '''Manoel Theatre''' ({{lang-mt|It-Teatru Manoel}}; {{lang-it|Teatro Manoel}}) is a [[theatre]] and important performing arts venue in [[Malta]]. The theatre is often referred to as simply '''"The Manoel"''', and is named after [[List of Grand Masters of the Knights Hospitaller|Grand Master]] of [[Knights Hospitaller|the Order of the Knights Hospitaller]], [[António Manoel de Vilhena|Fra António Manoel de Vilhena]], who ordered its construction in 1731. The theatre is reputed to be Europe's third-oldest working theatre (older than the San Carlo in Naples), and the oldest theatre still in operation in the [[Commonwealth of Nations]].{{cite web|title=Manoel Theatre|url=http://www.maltaattraction.com/content.aspx?id=199484|publisher=Valletta - Living history|accessdate=1 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217231601/http://www.maltaattraction.com/content.aspx?id=199484|archivedate=17 December 2014|df=}} The theatre is located on Old Theatre Street ([[Maltese language|Maltese]]: ''Triq it-Teatru l-Antik'') in [[Valletta]]. It considers itself as the country's national theatre and the home of [[Malta Philharmonic Orchestra]] ([[Maltese language|Maltese]]: ''Orkestra Filarmonika Nazzjonali''). Originally called the ''Teatro Pubblico,'' its name was changed to ''Teatro Reale,'' or Theatre Royal, in 1812, and renamed ''Manoel Theatre'' in 1866. The first play to be performed was [[Francesco Scipione, marchese di Maffei|Maffei]]'s [[Merope (Messenia)#Maffei.27s Merope|Merope]]. The theatre is a small, 623 seat venue, with an oval-shaped [[auditorium]], three tiers of boxes constructed entirely of wood, decorated with gold leaf, and a pale blue [[trompe-l'oeil]] ceiling that resembles a round cupola. The building is a Grade 1 [[listed building]] as noted by Malta's Superintendence of Cultural Heritage, and is also scheduled by the [[Malta Environment and Planning Authority]] (MEPA).{{cite web|title=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/01140.pdf|publisher=Superintendence of Cultural Heritage|accessdate=28 February 2014|date=28 December 2012}} ==History== [[File:Triq it-Teatru l-Antik Valletta.jpg|right|thumb|Old Theatre Street, named after the Manoel Theatre.|329x329px]] [[File:Palazzo_Bonici_Valletta,_Malta.jpeg|thumb|right|[[Palazzo Bonici]] used by the Manoel Theatre until 2014http://www.tvm.com.mt/mt/news/tal-manoel-iridu-johorgu-minn-palazzo-bonici-sas-sajf/]] Before the construction of the theatre, plays and amateur theatrical productions were staged in the halls and ''[[piano nobile]]s'' of the Knights' auberges. These were palaces constructed for the ''[[Langue (Knights Hospitaller)|langues]]'' of the Order. The Langue of Italy often held such entertainment, staged by its knights in their Auberge. The records of the Langue even state that on February 2, 1697, some Maltese gentlemen presented a play in the ''[[Auberge d'Italie]].'' Women were prohibited from attending these events after incidents during the Carnival festivities of 1639. In 1731, [[António Manoel de Vilhena]] commissioned and personally funded the construction of the building to serve as a public theatre "''for the honest recreation of the people.''"{{refn|group=n|This phrase was inscribed above the main entrance to the theatre,{{cite news|title=Manoel Theatre façade to be restored|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2013-09-26/news/manoel-theatre-facade-to-be-restored-2727215104/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent|date=26 September 2013}} which still reads to this today: "''Ad honestam populi oblectationem.''"{{la icon}} }} The Grand Master bought two houses from the Priory of [[Navarre]], with a frontage on what is now Old Theatre Street for the sum of 2,186 ''scudi''.{{refn|group=n|Vilhena also paid a further 2,000 ''scudi'' for the reconstruction of the Navarrese knights' two remaining houses, which then became known as the New Priory of Navarre.Repertorio Fondazione Manoel, R.M.K. Treas. A. 25 fo. 65.}} It has a plain [[façade]], in keeping with Valletta's [[Mannerism (architecture)|Mannerist]] style, and has three floors with a [[mezzanine]]-level above the ground floor. The façade incorporates a doorway surmounted by a stone balustraded open balcony, itself supported by three heavy scroll corbels. The interior is decorated in [[Rococo]] style. The theatre was possibly designed by [[Romano Carapecchia]], and was built by [[Francesco Zerafa]] and Antonio Azzopardi. Construction was finished in only ten months. This however, may be because alterations were made to the fabric of the three adjoining houses, incorporating them into a theatre. The building occupied an area of 94½ [[Maltese units of measurement|square canes]],{{refn|group=n|{{convert|496.31|sqyd|m2|lk=in|sigfig=3}}}} which was later altered to 93 square canes and 2½ palms.{{refn|group=n|{{convert|488.64|sqyd|m2|lk=in|sigfig=3}}}} The theatre is said to have been modelled after the contemporary [[Palermo]] Theatre.Scicluna, Sir Hannibal P., "Buildings and Fortifications of Valletta", in ''Malta and Gibraltar''; London, W.H. & L. Collingridge, at p. 215 Its auditorium was originally semi-circular or horseshoe shaped, with an illuminated parterre that served as a small dance floor. The first theatrical performance to be staged at the ''Teatro Pubblico'' was Scipione Maffei's classic tragedy ''Merope'', on January 9, 1732.''Compendio del Giornale del Sac. Fra. Gaetano Rebout. R.M.L.'', Ms. 20. The actors in that production were the Knights themselves, and the set was designed by the Knights' chief military architect, Francois Mondion. On January 26, 1732 a satirical and anti-clerical play "''Il bacchettiere falso''" by Girolamo Gigli was performed. On January 18, 1769, the play "Il trionfo di Minerva", by Lentisco Adrasteo was presented on the occasion of [[Manuel Pinto da Fonseca|Grand Master Manuel Pinto da Fonseca]]'s birthday. A similar honour was also given to [[Ferdinand von Hompesch zu Bolheim]], on his elevation as Grand Master. On this occasion, Hompesch appeared on the balcony thanking the crowd, showering handfuls of gold coins on the people that had gathered to applaud.{{cite web|title=The Opera Page|url=http://czh227.wix.com/the-opera-page#!page-2|publisher=Wix.com|accessdate=28 February 2014}} Over the course of the next half-century, it was the venue for an extensive repertoire of lyric operas performed by companies of visiting professionals or by amateur groups of knights, and French tragedies or Italian comedies. Works by [[Johann Adolf Hasse]], [[Niccolò Piccinni]] and Baldassare [[Galuppi]] were extremely popular at the theatre during its early years. In its early days, the management of the theatre, and censorship of its performances, was entrusted to a senior knight, known as the ''Protettore.''{{cite web|title=The Beginning|url=http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/?m=content&id=135|publisher=Teatru Manoel|accessdate=1 March 2014}} The first recorded [[impresario]] was Melchiorre Prevvost Lanarelli in 1736, and the last Giovanni Le Brun in 1866. From 1768 to 1770 the impresario was a woman, Natala Farrugia. In setting up the theatre, Grand Master de Vilhena set the rent to be paid by the impresario at 320 ''scudi'' per annum, of which 80 accrued for rent from [[Easter]] to August, 120 for autumn, and another 120 ''scudi'' from [[Christmas Island|Christmas]] to [[Carnival]]. When dances or ''veglioni'' ([[masked ball]]) were held in the theatre, the pit was raised by a scaffolding to the level of the stage. On August 22, 1778, regulations were passed for the lighting of the theatre and corridors on such occasions, with the shading of lights, in any manner, being prohibited.{{cite journal |last=Denaro |first=Victor |year=1960 |title=The Manoel Theatre |journal=Melita Historica |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=1–4 |ref=harv}} In 1778, to avoid scandal, theatre companies were prohibited from sleeping in the boxes of the theatre. This was a practice which was common during that time. A few years later, in 1783, the ''Teatro Pubblico'' underwent considerable modification and decoration, based on a design by the Roman architect, Natale Marini. A model was displayed before the [[Inquisition|inquisitor]] and many knights, and the model was so admired that the Commissioners of the Foundation of the Theatre decided to add a further two ''louis,'' as a bonus to Marini’s invoice of 49 ''scudi.''''Diverse Scritture relative alla Fondazione Manoel'', R.M.L., Treas. A. 32, cited by {{harvp|Denaro|1960|p=2}}. [[File:Manoel theatre (12843815575).jpg|thumbnail|left|The pale blue, [[trompe-l'oeil]] ceiling that resembles a round cupola.]] [[Nicolas Isouard]]'s first known opera, ''Casaciello perseguitato da un mago,'' was performed here in 1792, and Isouard became director of this theatre in 1798, after the [[French occupation of Malta|French captured Malta]], and continued to premiere other operas there.Paul Xuereb, The Manoel Theatre, a short history, Valletta, Friends of the Manoel Theatre Several of Isouard's own works, including ''Avviso ai Maritati'' and ''Artaserse'', were performed at the Manoel during this time. French rule over Malta was short-lived and within two years the islands passed into the hands of [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]]. An English gentleman who accompanied [[Battle of Alexandria|Abercrombie’s expedition to Egypt]] in 1801, wrote that:
"La Valette possesses an opera, small indeed, but neat, though much out of repair. Italy and Sicily supply it with very tolerable vocal performers, and it is a very agreeable entertainment for the garrison. It was excessively crowded every night by the officers of the expedition, to whom it was a great source of amusement. The price of admission is one shilling."{{cite book|last=Walsh|first=Thomas|title=Journal of the Late Campaign in Egypt: Including Descriptions of that Country, and of Gibraltar, Minorca, Malta, Marmorice, and Macri; with an Appendix; Containing Official Papers and Documents|year=1803|publisher=T. Cadell and W. Davies|location=Egypt|page=3|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Journal_of_the_Late_Campaign_in_Egypt.html?id=IZrSTMiiNQYC}}
[[File:Manoel theatre (12851453033).jpg|thumbnail|The proscenium and theatre-boxes at the Manoel.]] During the early [[Crown Colony of Malta|British Era]], the "''Teatro Pubblico''" was renamed as the ''"Teatro Reale"'', going through a series of enlargements and re-modellings throughout the 19th century, most notably in 1812, when [[George Whitmore (British Army officer)|Sir George Whitmore]] added today's gallery and [[proscenium]], raised the ceiling by one storey, and added eight more boxes, bringing the total to 67. Whitmore also transformed the auditorium to the oval shape that it has today. Further alterations were made in 1844, when the Manoel’s set designer, Ercolani, repainted the panels on the wooden boxes and had them gilded. Another stratum of silver leaf was added to the panels and ceiling in 1906. Throughout this time, the Teatro Reale was rented out to professional impresarios, who hosted nine-month opera seasons. It was visited by many foreign dignitaries, including [[Walter Scott|Sir Walter Scott]], and [[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen|H.M. Queen Adelaide, the Queen Dowager]], widow of William IV of England, who attended performances of ''Elisir d'Amore'' and ''[[Gemma di Vergy]]'' at the theatre, during her convalescence in Malta. ''[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]'' was given as a gala night in honour of the Queen Dowager, featuring [[soprano]] Camilla Darbois.Rolandi, Ulderico, "Musica e Musicisti in Malta", in ''Archivio Storico di Malta'', Vol. I, Fasc. I, page 20, cited by {{harvp|Denaro|1960|p=3}}. English and Italian opera and operetta were the most popular productions at the ''Teatro Reale'' throughout the 19th century; however, the Maltese public was particularly supportive of operas by [[Rossini]], [[Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]], [[Donizetti]] and [[Verdi]]. [[Image:Royal Opera House (1866) elevation.jpg|thumb|Elevation view of the [[Royal Opera House, Valletta|Royal Opera House]], Valletta, c. 1866.|left]] In 1861, the Teatro Reale was given on perpetual lease, by the government, to Dr. Salvatore Mifsud and Anacleto Conti for an annual ground rent of £236,15, and in 1862, the directum dominium was sold to Emmanuele Scicluna for £7,833.6.8. Subsequent owners were Carmelo Arpa, a chemist (1889) and the Gollcher family (1906-7).Records of Notary Luigi Vella of 5 May 1861, and of 9 September 1802, cited by {{harvp|Denaro|1960|p=4}}. The theatre had fallen into disuse in 1866, as a result of the construction of Malta's new [[Royal Opera House, Valletta|Royal Opera House]], designed by [[Edward Middleton Barry]], on Strada Reale, at the entrance to Valletta. The theatre began to serve as a doss house for homeless and indigent citizens, who rented out the stalls for a few pennies a night. However, in 1873, the ''Teatro Reale'' - was officially renamed the "''Manoel Theatre''", and it enjoyed a brief new lease on life when the Royal Opera House burnt down. But by 1877, the Royal Opera House had been rebuilt, and once more, the Manoel Theatre was eclipsed and fell again into disuse. On December 27, 1922, January 6, 1923 and February 3, 1923, the Manoel Theatre was the venue for the first public airing of Malta's National Anthem, "''[[L-Innu Malti]].''" During the [[Second World War at Sea series|Second World War]], the Manoel Theatre served as emergency accommodation for victims of the constant bombardment by the [[Luftwaffe]] and the [[Regia Aeronautica]]. In the early 20th century, it was also used intermittently as the venue for Carnival balls and, for a period of about twenty years, it operated as a [[movie theatre]]. The theatre was included on the Antiquities List of 1925.{{cite web|title=Protection of Antiquities Regulations 21st November, 1932 Government Notice 402 of 1932, as Amended by Government Notices 127 of 1935 and 338 of 1939. |url=https://www.mepa.org.mt/file.aspx?f=2627 |website=[[Malta Environment and Planning Authority]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6guMwmZDW?url=https://www.mepa.org.mt/file.aspx?f=2627 |archivedate=20 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == Present day == Despite numerous alterations over the years, it retains many of its old architectural features, such as the white [[Carrara marble]] staircase, shell-shaped niches, and [[Vienna|Viennese]] chandeliers. Two water reservoirs beneath the floor create an acoustic environment that is so precise, that the hushed page-turnings of an [[orchestra conductor]] can be heard clearly throughout the auditorium.{{cite book|title=Anthem Guide to the Opera, Concert Halls and Classical Music Venues of Europe|year=2009|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=0857286838|page=323|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mfxgGNCV62IC|editor=Steven Isserlis}} Following the destruction of the [[Royal Opera House, Valletta|Royal Opera House]] by [[World War II|Axis bombardment]] on April 7, 1942, the Manoel Theatre was expropriated by the [[Government of Malta]] in 1956, and was quickly restored to its former glory. It reopened in December 1960 with a performance of [[Coppélia]] by [[Ballet Rambert]].{{cite web|title=The 20th Century|url=http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/?m=content&id=139|publisher=Teatru Manoel|accessdate=1 March 2014}} In subsequent years the theatre [[foyer]] was enlarged by means of the annexation of the adjacent Palazzo Bonici, a grand 18th century palace that was the former home of the Testaferrata Bonnici family, however on January 9, 2007, the Constitutional Court of Malta revoked the 1958 order of possession and use in respect of this property, and ordered that the property be returned to its original owner.{{cite news|last=Cooke|first=Patrick|title=Government breached noble’s property rights|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130904/local/Government-breached-noble-s-property-rights.484738|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=4 September 2013}} This annex currently houses the theatre's bar and restaurant. [[File:Teatro Manoel facade.jpg|thumbnail|Restoration of the facade of the Manoel Theatre has been a source of controversy.]] The theatre is being restored by the Manoel Theatre Restoration Committee.{{cite news|title=Third Phase of Manoel Theatre’s restoration|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2005-06-12/news/third-phase-of-manoel-theatres-restoration-76689/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent on Sunday|date=12 June 2005}} Previous restoration attempts done in the 1970s were heavily criticised, with the removal of a balcony and the reinforcement of old stone with new masonry. The first phase of the new restoration took place in 2003, and included the restoration of the paintings on the frontispiece of the auditorium boxes. In 2004, the auditorium was restored by a team of ''Sante Guido Restauro e Conservazione di Opere d'Arte,'' who unearthed paintings that will allow the understanding of the theatre's development.{{cite web|title=Restoration|url=http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/?m=content&id=138|publisher=Teatru Manoel|accessdate=1 March 2014}} This second phase included the cleaning of the gilt. The third phase included the restoration of the proscenium arch and the boxes it incorporates, while the fourth phase of the restoration project was the ceiling’s restoration, which was inaugurated on October 3, 2006.{{cite news|last=Parquet|first=Karine|title=The Restoration of the Manoel Theatre|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2006-09-24/news/the-restoration-of-the-manoel-theatre-97105/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent on Sunday|date=24 September 2006}} Although controversial,{{cite news|last=Grima|first=Noel|title=Mepa approves Manoel Theatre restoration, except for façade|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2012-11-15/news/mepa-approves-manoel-theatre-restoration-except-for-facade-391249922/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent|date=15 November 2012}} an application to restore the theatre's façade was approved by Maltese planning and heritage supervisory bodies{{cite news|last=Grima|first=Noel|title=Manoel Theatre Façade restoration sees applicant and Mepa clash on cladding|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2012-10-12/news/manoel-theatre-facade-restoration-sees-applicant-and-mepa-clash-on-cladding-317192/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent|date=12 October 2012}} and was restored in 2017.{{cite book|last=Scicluna|first=Edward|date=17 October 2016|title=Budget Speech 2017|chapter=Health, Sports and Culture|url=https://mfin.gov.mt/en/The-Budget/Documents/The_Budget_2017/Budget_Speech_2017_English.pdf|publisher=Ministry for Finance|location=Valletta|isbn=978-99957-58-15-8|pages=139, 140}} Today, the Manoel Theatre continues to put up a broad variety of theatrical productions in both English and [[Maltese language|Maltese]], opera, musical recitals (including lunchtime recitals in ''Sala Isouard''),{{cite web|title=Sala Isouard|url=http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/?m=content&id=128|publisher=Teatru Manoel|accessdate=1 March 2014}} poetry recitals, dramatic readings, and an annual Christmas [[pantomime]], produced by the ''Malta Amateur Dramatic Club''. Management of the theatre is currently entrusted to Chairman Michael Grech, deputy chairman Kenneth Zammit Tabona, and board members Mario Philip Azzopardi, Anita Alosio and Lino Farrugia.{{cite news|title=New board of directors for Manoel Theatre|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2013-05-09/news/new-board-of-directors-for-manoel-theatre-1553498113/|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent|date=29 March 2013}} Many productions are regularly presented, both by local talent and international stars, and the theatre has been a source for the cultural appreciation of the arts in Malta. Since 1960, it has had an official Management Committee and is no longer rented out for whole seasons to impresarios as in the past.The theatre's musical programmes retain some variety, but the main emphasis during recent decades has been on instrumental music. The theatre is listed on the [[National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]]. == World premieres held at Manoel Theatre (incomplete) == * 8 April 2016: ''The Price of One''. Play by [[Edward Bond]]. Directed by [[Chris Cooper (director)|Chris Cooper]].[https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160331/arts-entertainment/world-premiere-of-the-price-of-one-at-the-manoel-theatre.607378 ''World premiere of „The Price of One“ at the Manoel Theatre''.] Article in [[Times of Malta]], March 31, 2016. (English)[https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160403/arts-entertainment/Powerful-Bond.607718 ''Powerful Bond.''] article by Veronica Stivala in [[Times of Malta]], April 3, 2016. * 26 January 2017: ''Concertino for guitar, harpsichord and orchestra'' by [[Reuben Pace]]. [[Malta Philharmonic Orchestra]], [[Michelle Castelletti]] (conductor), [[Johanna Beisteiner]] (guitar), [[Joanne Camilleri]] (harpsichord).[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170122/arts-entertainment/a-baroque-world-premiere.637264 A baroque world premiere.] Article by Iggy Fenech, Times of Malta, 22 January 2017. (English) ==Notable visitors== Many opera singers, musicians and troupes have graced its stage. These include [[Boris Christoff]], [[Mirella Freni]], Rosanna Carteri, Cecilia Gasdia, Louis Kentner, Flaviano Labò, [[Moura Lympany|Dame Moura Lympany]], [[Yehudi Menuhin|Sir Yehudi Menuhin]], [[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]], [[Magda Olivero]], [[Michael Ponti]], [[Katia Ricciarelli]], [[Mstislav Rostropovich]], [[Margaret Rutherford|Dame Margaret Rutherford]], [[Steve Hackett]], [[Kiri Te Kanawa|Dame Kiri Te Kanawa]] and [[Donald Wolfit|Sir Donald Wolfit]]. Visiting companies at the Manoel Theatre have included [[Nottingham Playhouse]], the [[Comédie-Française]] and the [[Berlin State Ballet|Staatsballett Berlin]] (Berlin State Opera Ballet).{{cite web|title=Theatre|url=http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/?m=content&id=127|publisher=Teatru Manoel|accessdate=1 March 2014}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=25em}} == External links == * [http://www.teatrumanoel.com.mt/ Teatru Manoel - Official website] * [http://www.maltaorchestra.com/page.asp?p=6837&l=1 Orkestra Filarmonika Nazzjonali - Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110207121628/http://dwalgodda.com/ Dwal Godda Theatre Company] [[Geographic coordinate system|Coordinates]]: {{coord|35|54|1|N|14|30|45|E|type:landmark}} {{Valletta}} [[Category:National theatres]] [[Category:Theatres in Malta]] [[Category:Opera houses in Malta]] [[Category:Maltese architecture]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Valletta]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1732]] [[Category:Cinemas in Malta]] [[Category:National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]] [[Category:1732 establishments in Malta]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox song contest | name = Melodifestivalen | year = 2016 | semi1 = 6 February 2016 | semi2 = 13 February 2016 | semi3 = 20 February 2016 | semi4 = 27 February 2016 | second = 5 March 2016 | final = 12 March 2016 | presenters = '''All shows:'''
[[Gina Dirawi]]
'''Guest co-hosts''':
[[Petra Mede]]
[[Henrik Schyffert]]
[[Sarah Dawn Finer]]
[[Ola Salo]]
[[Peter Jöback]]
[[William Spetz]] | winner = "[[If I Were Sorry]]" by [[Frans Jeppsson-Wall|Frans]] | host = [[Sveriges Television|SVT]] | venue = [[Scandinavium]],
[[Malmö Arena]],
[[Himmelstalundshallen]],
[[Gavlerinken Arena]],
[[Halmstad Arena]],
[[Friends Arena]] | entries = 27: 6 in the first semi-final, 7 in the other semi-finals; 12 in the final (2 from each semi-final, 4 from the Second Chance round) }} '''Melodifestivalen 2016''' was the 56th edition of the Swedish music competition [[Melodifestivalen]], which selected Sweden's entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]]. The competition was organised by [[Sveriges Television]] (SVT) and took place over the six-week period between 6 February and 12 March 2016. For the 15th consecutive year, the format of the competition consisted of six shows: four semi-final rounds, a second chance round and a final. The 28 competing entries were divided into four semi-finals, with seven compositions in each. From each semi-final, the songs that earned first and second place qualified directly to the final, while the songs that placed third and fourth proceeded to the Second Chance round. The bottom three songs in each semi-final were eliminated from the competition. An additional four entries qualified from the Second Chance round to the final, bringing the total number of competing entries in the final to 12. All six shows were hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]], who was joined by guest co-hosts during each show: [[Petra Mede]] (Semi-final 1), [[Henrik Schyffert]] (Semi-final 3), [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] (Semi-final 4), [[Peter Jöback]] (Second Chance round), [[Ola Salo]] (Second Chance round) and [[William Spetz]] (Final); [[Charlotte Perrelli]] was originally announced as the guest co-host for the second semi-final, however, her role was changed to guest performer after a conflict of interest arose due to her endorsement deal with the Swedish mobile brand [[Comviq]]. An initial 28 entries were selected for the competition through three methods: an open call for song submissions, direct invitations to specific artists and songwriters and a wildcard given to one of the artists that participated in the ''Svensktoppen nästa'' competition organised by [[Sveriges Radio P4]]. Twenty-seven entries ultimately competed as one of the selected songs, "Himmel för två" to have been performed by [[Anna Book]], was disqualified prior to the start of semi-finals as it had competed in the [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014 Moldovan Eurovision Song Contest national selection]], thus violating the rules of the competition. "[[If I Were Sorry]]" performed by [[Frans Jeppsson-Wall|Frans]] was selected as the winner of the 2016 competition after scoring the highest amount of points following the combination of votes from 11 international jury groups and a public vote consisting of telephone, SMS and app voting. The song represented [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016]], which took place in the [[Stockholm Globe Arena]] in [[Stockholm]] on 10, 12 and 14 May 2016. "If I Were Sorry" competed directly in the final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2016 on 14 May due to Sweden being the host nation for the contest following the victory of [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] and the song "[[Heroes (Måns Zelmerlöw song)|Heroes]]" in {{ESCYr|2015}}. At the contest, Sweden placed fifth out of the 26 competing nations in the final, scoring 261 points. ==Format== Melodifestivalen 2016, organised by [[Sveriges Television]] (SVT), was the fifteenth consecutive edition of the contest in which the competition took place in different cities across Sweden. The four semi-finals were held at the [[Scandinavium]] in [[Gothenburg]] (6 February), the [[Malmö Arena]] in [[Malmö]] (13 February), the [[Himmelstalundshallen]] in [[Norrköping]] (20 February) and the [[Gavlerinken Arena]] in [[Gävle]] (27 February).{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|title=Hit kommer Melodifestivalen 2016 – se alla städerna|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/har-ar-staderna-for-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen 2016 tour announced|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_melodifestivalen_2016_tour_announced|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=17 January 2016|date=15 September 2015}} The Second Chance round took place at the [[Halmstad Arena]] in [[Halmstad]] on 5 March while the final was held at the [[Friends Arena]] in Solna on 12 March. An initial twenty-eight entries were intended to compete in the semi-finals, with seven entries taking part in each show. The first semi-final only featured six entries after one of the competing songs was disqualified. The top two entries from each semi-final advanced directly to the final, while the third and fourth placed entries advanced to the Second Chance round. The bottom three entries in each semi-final were eliminated. An additional four entries qualified to the final from the Second Chance round, bringing the total number of competing entries in the final to twelve. [[Christer Björkman]] was announced as the executive producer of the competition, while Annette Helenius was assigned as the project manager, replacing Maria Ilstedt and Christel Tholse Willers from the previous year.{{cite web|title=Inför 2016: Hon tar över Melodifestivalen|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/hon-ska-ta-melodifestivalen-2016-till-nya-hojder|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=15 September 2015}} {| class="wikitable" width=100% style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !colspan=6| '''Competition Schedule''' |- ! Show !! Date !! City !! Venue !! colspan="2"| Hosts |- | [[#Semi-final 1|Semi-final 1]] || 6 February || [[Gothenburg]] || [[Scandinavium]] || rowspan="6"| [[Gina Dirawi]] || [[Petra Mede]] |- | [[#Semi-final 2|Semi-final 2]] || 13 February || [[Malmö]] || [[Malmö Arena]] || — |- | [[#Semi-final 3|Semi-final 3]] || 20 February || [[Norrköping]] || [[Himmelstalundshallen]] || [[Henrik Schyffert]] |- | [[#Semi-final 4|Semi-final 4]] || 27 February || [[Gävle]] || [[Gavlerinken Arena]] || [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] |- | [[#Second Chance round|Second Chance round]] || 5 March || [[Halmstad]] || [[Halmstad Arena]] || [[Peter Jöback]] and [[Ola Salo]] |- | [[#Final|Final]] || 12 March || [[Solna Municipality|Solna]] || [[Friends Arena]] || [[William Spetz]] |} ===Entry selection=== Entries for the 2016 competition were selected through three methods:{{cite web|title=Dags att börja skriva låtar till Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/dags-att-borja-skriva-latar-till-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=26 June 2015}}{{cite web|title=Inbjudan till Melodifestivalen 2016 |url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/article3060958.svt/binary/Inbjudan%20till%20Melodifestivalen%202016.pdf |website=svt.se |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |accessdate=4 February 2016 |language=Swedish |date=26 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704123010/http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/article3060958.svt/binary/Inbjudan%20till%20Melodifestivalen%202016.pdf |archivedate=4 July 2015 |df= }} *14 entries were chosen by a selection panel from submissions received by SVT through an open call for songs. *13 entries were selected by SVT via special invitations to artists and songwriters. *1 entry was provided by the selected artist from the competition ''Svensktoppen nästa'' organised by [[Sveriges Radio P4]]. SVT opened two submission contests that accepted entries between 1 and 16 September 2015 for interested artists and songwriters to submit their proposals for the competition. The ''Regular contest'' was open for entries that had at least one songwriter that already had a musical work published, while the ''Public contest'' accepted entries from songwriters without previously published musical work.{{cite web|title=Invitation to the 2016 Melodifestival|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/article3060975.svt/BINARY/Melodifestivalen%202016%20rules.pdf|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|date=26 June 2015}} Entries submitted for the competition were required to be new compositions which had never been published between 2–3 minutes in length and with at least one songwriter that had Swedish citizenship. The choice of language was free, however, SVT reserved 30% of the contest's places for entries sung mainly in Swedish. SVT also aimed to have at least 50% of the contest's places for entries written by female composers and lyricists either in a solo or collaborative capacity. Following the conclusion of the submission periods, SVT received 2,450 entries—an increase of 273 entries from the previous year. 1,982 of the entries were entered into the ''Regular contest'', while 468 entries were entered into the ''Public contest''.{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|last2=Källman|first2=Pär|title=Nu är låtarna till Melodifestivalen 2016 på plats|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/nu-ar-latarna-till-melodifestivalen-2016-pa-plats|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=16 September 2015}} SVT created a shortlist of entries from the received submissions and formed a selection panel that was tasked to select fourteen entries for the competition. The selection panel consisted of seventeen members: ten men and seven women 18–64 years of age. Half of the jury members represented people working in or involved with the music industry (professional dancers, artist managers, music editors and programme/music directors) and the other half consisted of members of the public who are viewers of Melodifestivalen (with professions such as engineers, bloggers, teachers, consultants and students).{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=De valde låtarna – här är Melodifestivalens urvalsjury 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/de-valde-latarna-har-ar-melodifestivalens-urvalsjury-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=14 January 2016}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" !colspan=2| Members of the Selection Panel |- ! Name ! Profession |- | Anna Shimoda | Editor in chief for ''Hänt.se'', [[Aller Media]] |- | Axel Scholtzé | Production assistant |- | Ben Robertson | Teacher and member of Melodifestivalen club |- | Carl-Philip Landin | Consultant |- | Cecilia Eriksson | Student musician |- | Edin Jusuframic | Dancer and choreographer |- | Ken Olausson | Engineer and blogger |- | Kerstin Behrendtz | Music editor for [[Sveriges Radio P4]] |- | Lisa Arnold | Dancer |- | Magnus Rogmark | Consultant |- | Mari Hesthammaer | Music editor for [[Sveriges Radio P3]] |- | Mari Ryberger | Melodifestivalen entry producer |- | Maria Ericson | Artist manager for [[Allsång på Skansen]], assistant project manager for Melodifestivalen 2016 |- | Martin Glemme | Marketing and PR |- | Rickard Keilor | Programme manager SBS Radio |- | Robert Sehlberg | Music director MTG Radio |- | Simon Grusell | Student |} ===Presenters=== At a press conference on 17 November 2015, [[Gina Dirawi]] was presented as the main host for all six shows of Melodifestivalen 2016.{{cite web|last1=Fahl|first1=Hanna|title=Gina Dirawi leder Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/melodifestivalen/gina-dirawi-leder-melodifestivalen-2016/|website=dn.se|publisher=[[Dagens Nyheter]]|accessdate=17 January 2016|language=Swedish|date=17 November 2015}} Her selection as the host made Dirawi the first woman to host Melodifestivalen three times, having previously presented the competition in [[Melodifestivalen 2012|2012]] and [[Melodifestivalen 2013|2013]]. Dirawi was joined by guest co-hosts during each show: [[Petra Mede]] (Semi-final 1), [[Henrik Schyffert]] (Semi-final 3), [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] (Semi-final 4), [[Peter Jöback]] (Second Chance round), [[Ola Salo]] (Second Chance round) and [[William Spetz]] (Final). Originally, [[Charlotte Perrelli]] was announced as the guest co-host for the second semi-final, however, after a breach of contract arose regarding Perrelli's endorsement deal with mobile phone brand [[Comviq]], her role in the programme was changed to guest performer.{{cite web|last1=Sidner|first1=Julija|title=SVT i krismöte om Charlotte Perrelli|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/melodifestivalen/article22192332.ab|website=aftonbladet.se|publisher=[[Aftonbladet]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=2 February 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Så blir Charlotte Perrellis nya roll i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/sa-blir-charlotte-perrellis-nya-roll-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=3 February 2016}} Mede, Schyffert, Finer and Perrelli had all hosted Melodifestivalen on previous occasions; Mede in [[Melodifestivalen 2009|2009]], Schyffert in [[Melodifestivalen 2005|2005]], Finer in 2012 and Perrelli in [[Melodifestivalen 2003|2003]] and [[Melodifestivalen 2004|2004]].{{cite web|last1=Källman|first1=Pär|title=Gina Dirawi och stjärngänget: Här är programledarna för Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/har-ar-programledarna-for-melodifestivalen-2016-gina-dirawi-petra-mede-charlotte-perrelli-henrik-schyffert-sarah-dawn-finer-ola-salo-peter-joback-och-william-spetz|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|format=17 November 2015}} ===Voting=== During the six shows, viewers could cast their votes through telephone, SMS and mobile application voting.{{cite web|last1=Albinsson|first1=Mathilde|title=Nya regler: Så funkar appen i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/nya-regler-sa-funkar-appen-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=26 January 2016}} For telephone and SMS voting, viewers were able to cast their vote through two different voting lines per voting method: a regular line costing 3.60 SEK and a donation line costing 9.90 SEK of which 8.90 SEK was donated to the charity organisation [[Radiohjälpen]]. Up to 20 votes could be cast per phone number per voting line, allowing a single phone number to contribute a maximum of 80 votes in each round of voting. With the mobile application, each device could send up to 5 votes for free per entry. The results of the semi-finals and Second Chance round were determined solely by viewer votes, while in the final, the results were determined through a 50/50 combination of viewer votes and the votes of eleven international jury groups. 36,711,512 votes were cast in total during the six shows with 4,633,907 SEK collected for Radiohjälpen. ==Competing entries== The twenty-eight competing entries were announced to the public during a press conference on 30 November 2015.{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Sweden: Who will compete in Melodifestivalen 2016?|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_who_will_compete_in_melodifestivalen_2016|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=17 January 2016|date=30 November 2015}} Prior to the press conference, it was only known that the group [[Smilo]] (formerly Smajling Swedes) had been selected for the competition from the artists that participated in the ''Svensktoppen nästa'' competition organised by [[Sveriges Radio P4]].{{cite web|last1=Laufer|first1=Gil|title=Sweden: Smajling Swedes to Melodifestivalen 2016!|url=http://esctoday.com/105544/sweden-smajling-swedes-to-melodifestivalen-2016/|website=esctoday.com|publisher=ESCToday.com|accessdate=4 February 2016|date=6 September 2015}} Among the competing artists were former Melodifestivalen winners [[Tommy Nilsson]] ([[Melodifestivalen 1989|1989]]) and [[Martin Stenmarck]] ([[Melodifestivalen 2005|2005]]). [[Krista Siegfrids]] had also participated in the Eurovision Song Contest in {{ESCYr|2013}} where she [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013|represented Finland]]. [[Ace Wilder]], [[After Dark (drag act)|After Dark]], [[Anna Book]], [[David Lindgren]], [[Dolly Style]], [[Isa Tengblad|Isa]], [[Linda Bengtzing]], [[Mattias Andréasson]], [[Molly Pettersson Hammar]], [[Molly Sandén]], [[Oscar Zia]], [[Panetoz]], [[Patrik Isaksson (singer)|Patrik Isaksson]], [[Pernilla Andersson]], [[Samir & Viktor|Samir and Viktor]], [[Swingfly]] and [[Uno Svenningsson]] have all participated in Melodifestivalen during previous editions. In addition to having participated in Melodifestivalen previously, Molly Sandén also represented Sweden in the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2006]]. On 4 February 2016, SVT held a press conference where they announced that "Himmel för två", written by Sven-Inge Sjöberg, Lennart Wastesson, Larry Forsberg and [[Camilla Läckberg]] and to have been performed by Anna Book, was disqualified from the competition. The disqualification came two days before the song was set to be performed in the first semi-final after it was discovered that the song had previously competed in the audition stage of the [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014 Moldovan Eurovision Song Contest national selection]] under the title "Taking Care of a Broken Heart" with lyrics in English.{{cite web|title=Anna Books bidrag "Himmel för två" diskvalificeras från Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/anna-books-bidrag-himmel-for-tva-diskvalificeras-fran-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=4 February 2016}} {| class="sortable wikitable" width="100%" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Berglund Juhola, Anton Göransson, Robin Danielsson |- | [[Swingfly]] feat. Helena Gutarra | "[[You Carved Your Name]]" | [[Joakim Åhlund]], [[Andreas Kleerup]] |- | [[Victor och Natten]] | "[[100% (Victor och Natten song)|100%]]" | Dag Lundberg, Melker, Jesper Lundh |- | [[Wiktoria Johansson|Wiktoria]] | "[[Save Me (Wiktoria song)|Save Me]]" | Jens Siverstedt, Lauren Dyson, Jonas Wallin |} ==Semi-finals== As in previous years, Melodifestivalen commenced with four semi-finals, which determined the eight entries that advanced directly to the final and the eight entries that qualified to the Second Chance round. The running order for each semi-final was announced on 12 January 2016.{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|title=Från Samir & Viktor till Molly Sandén – startordningen i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/fran-samir-och-viktor-till-molly-sanden-startordningen-i-melodifestivalen-2016-oscar-zia-far-unik-plats|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=12 January 2016}} The semi-final results were based solely on viewer votes. Two rounds of voting took place in each semi-final to determine which entries would advance further and which entries would be eliminated. All seven competing entries in each semi-final (six in the first semi-final) participated in the first round of voting where the top five advanced to the second round, while the bottom two were eliminated. In the second round of voting, the two entries that occupied the first and second places qualified directly to the final, while the third and fourth placed entries proceeded to the Second Chance round. The fifth placed entry was eliminated. All votes from the second round of voting were added to the votes that each entry received from the first round of voting in order to determine the final outcome. ===Semi-final 1=== The first semi-final took place on 6 February 2016 at the [[Scandinavium]] in [[Gothenburg]], hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]] and [[Petra Mede]]. "[[Don't Worry (Ace Wilder song)|Don't Worry]]" performed by [[Ace Wilder]] and "[[Constellation Prize (song)|Constellation Prize]]" performed by [[Robin Bengtsson]] qualified directly to the final, while "[[Bada nakna]]" performed by [[Samir & Viktor|Samir and Viktor]] and "[[Rik (song)|Rik]]" performed by [[Albin Johnsén|Albin]] and [[Mattias Andréasson|Mattias]] advanced to the Second Chance round.{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Melodifestivalen gets underway in Sweden|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=melodifestivalen_gets_underway_in_sweden|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=6 February 2016|date=6 February 2016}} A total of 4,389,687 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 477,689 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]].{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Ace Wilder och Robin Bengtsson är i final i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/ace-wilder-med-don-t-worry-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=6 February 2016}} In addition to the performances of the competing entries, Dirawi and Mede opened the show with a performance titled "Hela Sveriges fest" (All of Sweden's party) and performed together with [[Lasse Kronér]] as part of the interval act in a number titled "Allt är Eurovisions fel" (It's all Eurovision's fault). Spanish girl group and [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest 2006|2006 Spanish Eurovision entrants]] [[Las Ketchup]] also performed their song "[[The Ketchup Song (Aserejé)]]" as an interval act.{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Göteborg: Deltävling ett|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-goteborg-deltavling-ett|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=5 February 2016}} Recurring interval acts such as [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school and dramatic readings of past Melodifestivalen song lyrics by Swedish actors were also part of the programme; [[Stina Ekblad]] performed a dramatic reading of [[Samir & Viktor|Samir and Viktor]]'s [[Melodifestivalen 2015]] entry "[[Groupie (Samir & Viktor song)|Groupie]]".{{cite web|last1=Albinsson|first1=Mathilde|title=Gardells schlagerskola gör comeback i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/gardells-schlagerskola-gor-comeback-i-melodifestivalen|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=22 January 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Palmér|first1=Saga|title=Sveriges skådespelarelit hyllar Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/sveriges-skadespelarelit-hyllar-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=5 February 2016}} Two days prior to the semi-final on 4 February, "Himmel för två", performed by [[Anna Book]], was disqualified after it was discovered that the song had previously been entered and performed in the audition round of the [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014 Moldovan Eurovision Song Contest national selection]]. Book performed the song during the semi-final as an interval act.{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Anna Book sjunger i första deltävlingen i Melodifestivalen 2016 i Göteborg|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/anna-book-sjunger-i-forsta-deltavlingen-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=5 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=5 February 2016}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Draw ! rowspan="2"| Artist ! rowspan="2"| Song ! colspan="3" class="unsortable"| Votes ! rowspan="2"| Place ! rowspan="2"| Result |- ! {{nowrap|Round 1}} ! {{nowrap|Round 2}} ! Total |-style="background:silver;" | 1 |align="left"| [[Samir & Viktor]] |align="left"| "[[Bada nakna]]" | 752,944 | 77,908 | 830,852 | 3 |align="left"| '''''Second Chance''''' |- | 2 |align="left"| [[Pernilla Andersson]] |align="left"| "Mitt guld" | 258,740 | — | 258,740 | 6 |align="left"| Out |- | 3 |align="left"| [[Mimi Werner]] |align="left"| "[[Ain't No Good (Mimi Werner song)|Ain't No Good]]" | 617,265 | 67,180 | 684,445 | 5 |align="left"| Out |-style="background:silver;" | 4 |align="left"| [[Albin Johnsén|Albin]] & [[Mattias Andréasson|Mattias]] |align="left"| "[[Rik (song)|Rik]]" | 725,693 | 61,166 | 786,859 | 4 |align="left"| '''''Second Chance''''' |-style="background:#fe8080;" class="sortbottom" | 5 |align="left"| [[Anna Book]] |align="left"| "Himmel för två" | — | — | — | — |align="left"| Disqualified |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 6 |align="left"| [[Robin Bengtsson]] |align="left"| "[[Constellation Prize (song)|Constellation Prize]]" | 836,672 | 112,863 | 949,535 | 1 |align="left"| Final |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 7 |align="left"| [[Ace Wilder]] |align="left"| "[[Don't Worry (Ace Wilder song)|Don't Worry]]" | 772,879 | 99,797 | 872,676 | 2 |align="left"| Final |} ===Semi-final 2=== The second semi-final took place on 13 February 2016 at the [[Malmö Arena]] in [[Malmö]], hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]]. [[Charlotte Perrelli]] was originally supposed to co-host the show; however, after a breach of contract arose due to her endorsement deal with mobile phone brand [[Comviq]], she appeared only as a guest performer instead. "[[We Are Your Tomorrow]]" performed by [[David Lindgren]] and "[[Save Me (Wiktoria song)|Save Me]]" performed by [[Wiktoria Johansson|Wiktoria]] qualified directly to the final, while "[[Hunger (song)|Hunger]]" performed by [[Molly Pettersson Hammar]] and "[[I Will Wait (Isa song)|I Will Wait]]" performed by [[Isa Tengblad|Isa]] advanced to the Second Chance round.{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Sweden: two more finalists in Melodifestivalen|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_two_more_finalists_in_melodifestivalen|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=13 February 2016|date=13 February 2016}} A total of 4,647,934 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 487,371 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]].{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=David Lindgren och Wiktoria är i final i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/david-lindgren-och-wiktoria-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=13 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=13 February 2016}} In addition to the performances of the competing entries, Dirawi and Perrelli opened the show with a performance titled "Flickorna från Sverige" (The girls from Sweden), while the interval act titled "Rädda schlagerdivan" (Save the schlager diva) included a video presentation that featured [[Claes Elfsberg]] and [[Arja Saijonmaa]] followed by Perrelli performing a Swedish language cover of the song "[[Atemlos durch die Nacht]]" by [[Helene Fischer]] entitled "Här står jag" (Here I stand).{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Malmö: Deltävling två|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-malmo-deltavling-tva|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=13 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=12 February 2016}} Recurring interval acts such as [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school and dramatic readings of past Melodifestivalen song lyrics by Swedish actors were also part of the program; [[Krister Henriksson]] and [[Peter Haber]] performed a dramatic reading of [[Kikki, Bettan & Lotta|Kikki, Bettan and Lotta]]'s [[Melodifestivalen 2002]] entry "[[Vem é dé du vill ha]]".{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Snabbguiden – allt du behöver veta om deltävling två i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/snabbguiden-allt-du-behover-veta-om-andra-deltavlingen-i-melodifestivalen-2016-1|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=13 February "[[Human (Oscar Zia song)|Human]]" performed by [[Oscar Zia]] and "[[My Heart Wants Me Dead]]" performed by [[Lisa Ajax]] qualified directly to the final, while "[[Kizunguzungu]]" performed by [[SaRaha]] and "[[Put Your Love on Me]]" performed by [[Boris René]] advanced to the Second Chance round.{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Sweden: third semi-final results|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_third_semi-final_results|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=20 February 2016|date=20 February 2016}} A total of 4,389,051 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 425,474 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]].{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Oscar Zia och Lisa Ajax är i final i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/oscar-zia-och-lisa-ajax-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=20 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=20 February 2016}} In addition to the performances of the competing entries, Dirawi and Schyffert opened the show with a cover of "[[Under Pressure]]" originally by [[Queen (band)|Queen]] and [[David Bowie]], while the interval acts were stand-up comedy by Schyffert and a performance by Dirawi titled "Love Story". Recurring interval acts such as [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school and dramatic readings of past Melodifestivalen song lyrics by Swedish actors were also be part of the program; [[Marie Göranzon]] performed a dramatic reading of [[Anna Book]]'s [[Melodifestivalen 2007]] entry "[[Samba Sambero]]".{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Norrköping: Deltävling tre|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-norrkoping-deltavling-tre|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=19 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=19 February 2016}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Draw ! rowspan="2"| Artist ! rowspan="2"| Song ! colspan="3" class="unsortable"| Votes ! rowspan="2"| Place ! rowspan="2"| Result |- ! {{nowrap|Round 1}} ! {{nowrap|Round 2}} !
