Helena Gutarra |align="left"| "[[You Carved Your Name]]" | 411,040 | — | 411,040 | 6 |align="left"| Out |- | 3 |align="left"| [[Smilo]] |align="left"| "[[Weight of the World (Smilo song)|Weight of the World]]" | 524,216 | 37,007 | 561,223 | 5 |align="left"| Out |- | 4 |align="left"| [[After Dark (drag act)|After Dark]] |align="left"| "[[Kom ut som en stjärna]]" | 355,959 | — | 355,959 | 7 |align="left"| Out |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 5 |align="left"| [[Lisa Ajax]] |align="left"| "[[My Heart Wants Me Dead]]" | 880,118 | 68,760 | 948,878 | 1 |align="left"| Final |-style="background:silver;" | 6 |align="left"| [[Boris René]] |align="left"| "[[Put Your Love on Me]]" | 598,521 | 57,891 | 656,412 | 3 |align="left"| '''''Second Chance''''' |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 7 |align="left"| [[Oscar Zia]] |align="left"| "[[Human (Oscar Zia song)|Human]]" | 791,989 | 78,463 | 870,452 | 2 |align="left"| Final |} ===Semi-final 4=== The fourth semi-final took place on 27 February 2016 at the [[Gavlerinken Arena]] in [[Gävle]], hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]] and [[Sarah Dawn Finer]]. "[[Youniverse (song)|Youniverse]]" performed by [[Molly Sandén]] and "[[If I Were Sorry]]" performed by [[Frans Jeppsson-Wall|Frans]] qualified directly to the final, while "[[Håll om mig hårt]]" performed by [[Panetoz]] and "[[Rollercoaster (Dolly Style song)|Rollercoaster]]" performed by [[Dolly Style]] advanced to the Second Chance round. A total of 4,590,446 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 627,471 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]]. In addition to the performances of the competing entries, Dirawi and Finer opened the show with a cover of [[Guy Sebastian]]'s [[Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015 Australian Eurovision entry]] "[[Tonight Again]]" titled "Du och jag igen" (You and I again), while the interval act featured a performance by Dirawi, Finer and [[Jon Henrik Fjällgren]] titled "Hela Sveriges sång" (All of Sweden's song). [[Helena Bergström]], who hosted [[Melodifestivalen 2012]] together with Dirawi and Finer, reprised her portrayals of Lasse and Marianne—characters that were part of the interval acts for the 2012 competition. Recurring interval acts such as [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school and dramatic readings of past Melodifestivalen song lyrics by Swedish actors were also part of the program; [[Lena Endre]] performed a dramatic reading of [[Linda Bengtzing]]'s [[Melodifestivalen 2006]] entry "[[Jag ljuger så bra]]".{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Gävle: Deltävling fyra|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-gavle-deltavling-fyra|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=26 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=26 February 2016}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Draw ! rowspan="2"| Artist ! rowspan="2"| Song ! colspan="3" class="unsortable"| Votes ! rowspan="2"| Place ! rowspan="2"| Result |- ! {{nowrap|Round 1}} ! {{nowrap|Round 2}} ! Total |- | 1 |align="left"| [[Eclipse (band)|Eclipse]] |align="left"| "[[Runaways (Eclipse song)|Runaways]]" | 462,162 | 54,294 | 516,456 | 5 |align="left"| Out |-style="background:silver;" | 2 |align="left"| [[Dolly Style]] |align="left"| "[[Rollercoaster (Dolly Style song)|Rollercoaster]]" | 563,559 | 33,537 | 597,096 | 4 |align="left"| '''''Second Chance''''' |- | 3 |align="left"| [[Martin Stenmarck]] |align="left"| "Du tar mig tillbaks" | 345,313 | — | 345,313 | 6 |align="left"| Out |- | 4 |align="left"| [[Linda Bengtzing]] |align="left"| "Killer Girl" | 330,615 | — | 330,615 | 7 |align="left"| Out |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 5 |align="left"| [[Frans Jeppsson-Wall|Frans]] |align="left"| "[[If I Were Sorry]]" | 870,725 | 147,443 | 1,018,168 | 1 |align="left"| Final |-style="background:silver;" | 6 |align="left"| [[Panetoz]] |align="left"| "[[Håll om mig hårt]]" | 766,466 | 67,694 | 834,160 | 3 |align="left"| '''''Second Chance''''' |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 7 |align="left"| [[Molly Sandén]] |align="left"| "[[Youniverse (song)|Youniverse]]" | 852,284 | 85,091 | 937,375 | 2 |align="left"| Final |} ==Second Chance round== The Second Chance round took place on 5 March 2016 at the [[Halmstad Arena]] in [[Halmstad]], hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]], [[Ola Salo]] and [[Peter Jöback]]. The eight entries that placed third and fourth in the preceding four semi-finals competed during the show in four duels. SVT decided which entries would face off in each duel.{{cite web|last1=Källman|first1=Pär|title=Melodifestivalen 2016: Så blir startordningen i Andra chansen|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-2016-sa-blir-startordningen-i-andra-chansen|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=28 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=27 February 2016}} Viewers determined the results during the show through telephone, SMS and application voting. Voting in each duel commenced at the start of the first entry's performance and concluded one minute and thirty seconds following the end of the second entry's performance. Executive producer [[Christer Björkman]] announced which four entries won their duels and advanced to the final in addition to revealing the running order of the final at the conclusion of the show. "Håll om mig hårt" performed by Panetoz, "Put Your Love on Me" performed by Boris René, "Kizunguzungu" performed by SaRaha and "Bada nakna" performed by Samir and Viktor qualified to the final.{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Panetoz, SaRaha, Boris René och Samir & Viktor är i final i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/panetoz-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2016-och-kommer-inleda-hela-finalen|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=5 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=5 March 2016}} A total of 6,059,917 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 441,413 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]].{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Molly Sandén och Frans är i final i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/molly-sanden-och-frans-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=27 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=27 February 2016}} In addition to the performances of the competing entries, Dirawi, Salo and Jöback opened the show with a cover of [[Adele]]'s "[[Skyfall (Adele song)|Skyfall]]", while the interval acts included a duet by Salo and Jöback titled "Sing Me Out" and [[Hasse Andersson]] performing his [[Melodifestivalen 2015]] entry "[[Guld och gröna skogar]]". Recurring interval acts that were also part of the show included [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school and [[Helena Bergström]]'s portrayals of the characters Lasse and Marianne.{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Halmstad: Andra chansen|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-halmstad-andra-chansen|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=4 March 2016}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! Duel ! Draw ! Artist ! Song ! Votes ! Result |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" !rowspan=2 class="unsortable"| I | 1 |align="left"| [[Panetoz]] |align="left"| "[[Håll om mig hårt]]" | 965,823 |align="left"| Final |- | 2 |align="left"| [[Molly Pettersson Hammar]] |align="left"| "[[Hunger (song)|Hunger]]" | 503,953 |align="left"| Out |- !rowspan=2 class="unsortable"| II | 1 |align="left"| [[Albin Johnsén|Albin]] & [[Mattias Andréasson|Mattias]] |align="left"| "[[Rik (song)|Rik]]" | 735,852 |align="left"| Out |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 2 |align="left"| [[Boris René]] |align="left"| "[[Put Your Love on Me]]" | 836,686 |align="left"| Final |- !rowspan=2 class="unsortable"| III | 1 |align="left"| [[Isa Tengblad|Isa]] |align="left"| "[[I Will Wait (Isa song)|I Will Wait]]" | 763,862 |align="left"| Out |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 2 |align="left"| [[Saraha]] |align="left"| "[[Kizunguzungu]]" | 775,093 |align="left"| Final |- !rowspan=2 class="unsortable"| IV | 1 |align="left"| [[Dolly Style]] |align="left"| "[[Rollercoaster (Dolly Style song)|Rollercoaster]]" | 571,216 |align="left"| Out |-style="font-weight:bold;background:gold;" | 2 |align="left"| [[Samir & Viktor]] |align="left"| "[[Bada nakna]]" | 907,432 |align="left"| Final |} ==Final== The final took place on 12 March 2016 at the [[Friends Arena]] in Solna, hosted by [[Gina Dirawi]] and [[William Spetz]]. Twelve entries competed during the show. Eight of the entries qualified directly from the semi-finals, while four of the competing entries qualified from the Second Chance round. The winner was selected by a combination of viewer votes and eleven international jury groups. The viewers and the juries each had a total of 473 points to award. Each jury group distributed their points as follows: 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 points. The viewer vote was based on the percentage of votes each song achieved through the following voting methods: telephone, SMS and mobile application. For example, if a song gained 10% of the viewer vote, then that entry would be awarded 10% of 473 points rounded to the nearest integer: 47 points. Viewers were able to cast their vote in the final from the start of the show until five minutes after the jury groups had distributed their points, allowing the viewers to respond to the outcome of the jury results. In the event of a tie, the viewer vote would overrule the jury.{{cite web|title=Hur röstar jag under direktsändningarna?|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/gruppsida.aspx?programid=2023&grupp=19035&artikel=6362497|website=sverigesradio.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=6 February 2016}} "[[If I Were Sorry]]" performed by [[Frans Jeppsson-Wall|Frans]] was selected as the winner after placing second with the international jury vote and winning the public vote to finish with an overall 156-point total.{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Frans wins Melodifestivalen in Sweden|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=frans_wins_melodifestivalen_in_sweden|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|date=12 March 2016}} A record total of 12,643,477 votes were cast by the viewers during the show with a total of 2,174,489 SEK collected for [[Radiohjälpen]].{{cite web|last1=Palmér|first1=Saga|title=Melodifestivalen 2016 krossar alla röstningsrekord med 12 miljoner röster|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-2016-krossar-alla-rostningsrekord-med-12-miljoner-roster|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=12 March 2016}} In addition to the performances of the competing entries, the interval acts featured an anti-bullying themed performance of the [[Melodifestivalen 2015]] winning song "[[Heroes (Måns Zelmerlöw song)|Heroes]]", in a new arrangement by Moh Denebi, performed by [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] together with a children's choir and a medley of past Melodifestivalen hits intended to celebrate the fifteenth anniversary of the current format of the competition.{{cite web|last1=Palmér|first1=Saga|title=Måns Zelmerlöws nya tolkning av "Heroes" i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/mans-zelmerlows-nya-tolkning-av-heroes-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=10 March 2016}} The medley included: "Adrenaline" ([[Melodifestivalen 2002|2002]]) performed by [[DJ Méndez]], "[[Don't Stop Believing (Mariette song)|Don't Stop Believing]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2015|2015]]) performed by [[Mariette Hansson|Mariette]], "[[Kom (song)|Kom]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2010|2010]]) performed by [[Timoteij]], "Kom och ta mig" (2002) performed by [[Brandsta City Släckers]], "Bröder" ([[Melodifestivalen 2014|2014]]) performed by [[Linus Svenning]], "[[Moving On (Sarah Dawn Finer song)|Moving On]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2009|2009]]) performed by [[Sarah Dawn Finer]], "[[Live Forever (Magnus Carlsson song)|Live Forever]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2007|2007]]) performed by [[Magnus Carlsson]], "Snälla snälla" (2009) performed by [[Caroline af Ugglas]], "Sing For Me" ([[Melodifestivalen 2006|2006]]) performed by [[Andreas Johnson]], "Håll om mig" ([[Melodifestivalen 2005|2005]]) performed by [[Nanne Grönvall]], "[[Begging (song)|Begging]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2013|2013]]) performed by [[Anton Ewald]], "[[Vem é dé du vill ha]]" (2002) performed by [[Kikki Danielsson|Kikki]] and [[Elisabeth Andreassen|Bettan]], "Lay Your Love on Me" ([[Melodifestivalen 2008|2008]]) performed by [[BWO (band)|BWO]], "[[Hero (Charlotte Perrelli song)|Hero]]" (2008) performed by [[Charlotte Perrelli]] and "[[La dolce vita (After Dark song)|La dolce vita]]" ([[Melodifestivalen 2004|2004]]) performed by [[After Dark (drag act)|After Dark]].{{cite web|last1=Albinsson|first1=Mathilde|title=Stjärnspäckat finalmedley – så blir sista mellanakten i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/stjarnspackat-finalmedley-med-andreas-johnson-caroline-af-ugglas-och-anton-ewald-sa-blir-sista-mellanakten-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=Sveriges Television|accessdate=9 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=9 March 2016}} Recurring interval acts that were also part of the show included [[Jonas Gardell]]'s schlager school, [[Helena Bergström]]'s portrayals of the characters Lasse and Marianne and dramatic readings of past Melodifestivalen song lyrics by Swedish actors; [[Pernilla August]] and [[Michael Nyqvist]] performed a dramatic reading of Timoteij's Melodifestivalen 2010 entry "Kom".{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Minut för minut – så blir Melodifestivalen 2016 i Stockholm: Finalen|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/minut-for-minut-sa-blir-melodifestivalen-2016-i-stockholm-finalen|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=11 March 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|last2=Albinsson|first2=Mathilde|title=Så blir sista lektionen i Jonas Gardells schlagerskola i Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/sa-blir-sista-lektionen-i-jonas-gardells-schlagerskola-i-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=11 March 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Palmér|first1=Saga|title=Pernilla August och Michael Nyqvist står för Melodifestivalen 2016 sista tolkning|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/svenska-hollywoodstjarnor-star-for-melodifestivalen-2016-sista-tolkning|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=11 March 2016}} Sarah Dawn Finer also reprised her portrayal of the comedic character Lynda Woodruff, who first appeared in [[Melodifestivalen 2012]].{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|last2=Albinsson|first2=Mathilde|title=Lynda Woodruff gör comeback i finalen av Melodifestivalen 2016|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/lynda-woodruff-gor-comeback-i-finalen-av-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|language=Swedish|date=11 March 2016}}

Song Contest 2016'' == {{Main|Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016}} The ''[[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]]'' took place at the [[Ericsson Globe]] in [[Stockholm]] on 10, 12 and 14 May 2016. In addition to participating in the contest, the Swedish broadcaster [[Sveriges Television]] (SVT) hosted the Eurovision Song Contest after winning the competition in {{Escyr|2015}} with the song "[[Heroes (Måns Zelmerlöw song)|Heroes]]" performed by [[Måns Zelmerlöw]].{{cite web|title=Stockholm to host 2016 Eurovision Song Contest|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=stockholm_to_host_2016_eurovision_song_contest|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=12 March 2016|date=8 July 2015}} As the host nation, Sweden qualified to compete directly in the final of the contest on 14 May. Performing in position 9 during the final, Sweden placed fifth out of the 26 participating countries with 261 points.{{cite web|last1=Roxburgh|first1=Gordon|title=Ukraine wins 2016 Eurovision Song Contest|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=ukraine_wins_2016_eurovision_song_contest|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=14 May 2016|date=14 May 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{sv icon}} [http://svt.se/melodifestivalen Melodifestivalen Official Site] {{Melodifestivalen}} [[Category:2016 Swedish television seasons|Eurovision]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen by year|2016]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] [[Category:2016 in Swedish music]] [[Category:2016 song contests]] [[Category:February 2016 events in Europe]] [[Category:March 2016 events in Europe]] [[Category:Events in Malmö]] [[Category:Events in Gothenburg]] [[Category:Events in Gävle]] [[Category:Events in Halmstad]] [[Category:Events in Norrköping]] [[Category:2010s in Gothenburg]] [[Category:2010s in Malmö]] [[Category:Events in Solna]]

{{coord|41|7|59|N|74|42|55|W|display=title}} {{Infobox recurring event |name = New Jersey State Fair/Sussex County Farm and Horse Show |logo = |image = NJFair-buggy.jpg |caption = Incorporated in 1940 |location = [[Augusta, New Jersey|Augusta]], New Jersey |dates = August |genre = Agricultural Fair |website = [http://www.newjerseystatefair.org The New Jersey State Fair] }} The '''New Jersey State Fair''' is a non-profit agricultural fair held every August at the Sussex County Fairgrounds in [[Augusta, New Jersey|Augusta]], New Jersey. The fair has been held in conjunction with the [[Sussex County Farm and Horse Show]] since 1999 and draws 220,000 residents annually. The Augusta-based event was commonly referred to as the '''Sussex County Fair''' by locals. This fair is not affiliated with nor is to be confused with [[State Fair Meadowlands]], which is a carnival held every June at the [[Meadowlands Sports Complex]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey|East Rutherford]], New Jersey.
==Mission statement== The stated mission of the '''New Jersey State Fair / Sussex County Farm and Horse Show''' is:
*to showcase New Jersey’s agriculture; *provide safe, family-friendly entertainment; *present educational activities; *promote youth development; *give financial support to charitable non-profit agencies
== Summary == The New Jersey State Fair/Sussex County Farm and Horse Show is an annual event held during the first week of every August at the Sussex County Fairgrounds. A traditional agricultural fair, it offers livestock competitions, food tasting competitions, 4-H competitions and exhibitions, crafts, and AHSA-sanctioned horse competitions, including the Sussex County Grand Prix and the [[Lou Dobbs]] Show, Show Jumping Hall of Fame Amateur-Owner Classic. Other fair favorites include an annual fiddlers contest, a Queen of the Fair competition, demolition derby, oxen and tractor pulls, carnival rides, and exhibits from local organizations. Fair proceeds are donated to local charities, which is a tradition dating to 1933.
The fair's roots extend back to 1923 when a Sussex County riding club held a horse show for the children of its members. The horse show thereafter expanded, and was held annually in Branchville, New Jersey, from 1933 to 1975, and then from 1976 to the present at its current location in Augusta, New Jersey. The fair was initially called the Sussex County Horse Show from 1936 to 1940, and then as the Sussex County Farm and Horse Show from 1940 to 1999. In 1999, the Sussex County Farm and Horse Show purchased the rights to the New Jersey State Fair name, which previously operated at [[Garden State Park]] in [[Cherry Hill, New Jersey|Cherry Hill]], New Jersey, and was officially renamed the New Jersey State Fair/Sussex County Farm and Horse Show.<ref>New Jersey State Fair History Committee (2007) ''A Fair to Remember: A Documentary on the History of the Sussex County Farm and Horse Show.'' New Jersey State Fair / Sussex County Farm and Horse Show: Augusta, New Jersey</ref>

[[File:Stalinobus2.jpg|thumb|A bus with Stalin's portrait servicing route 187-К in [[Saint Petersburg]] in May 2010]] '''Nostalgia for the Soviet Union'''<ref>''[http://www.businessinsider.com/why-russia-backs-the-eurasian-union-2014-8 Why Russia Backs The Eurasian Union]''. Business Insider (from [[The Economist]]). August 22, 2014.</ref> ({{lang-ru|Ностальгия по СССР}}) or '''Soviet nostalgia'''<ref>Nikitin, V. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20150329133906/http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/putin-is-exploiting-the-legacy-of-the-soviet-union-to-further-russias-ends-in-ukraine-9170539.html Putin is exploiting the legacy of the Soviet Union to further Russia's ends in Ukraine]''. [[The Independent]]. March 5, 2014.</ref><ref>Taylor, A. ''[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/06/09/calls-for-a-return-to-stalingrad-name-test-the-limits-of-putins-soviet-nostalgia/ Calls for a return to ‘Stalingrad’ name test the limits of Putin’s Soviet nostalgia]''. [[Washington Post]]. June 9, 2014</ref> is a social phenomenon of [[nostalgia]] for the [[Soviet Union|Soviet era]], whether [[politics of the Soviet Union|its politics]], [[Soviet people|its society]], [[culture of the Soviet Union|its culture]], or simply its [[aesthetics]]. Such nostalgia is observed among people in Russia and the other [[post-Soviet states]], as well as persons born in the [[Soviet Union]] but long since living abroad.
In 2004 a television channel [[Nostalgiya (television, Russia)|Nostalgiya]] stylized with a [[hammer and sickle]] was launched in Russia.
==Reasons== According to polls, what is missed most about the former Soviet Union was its shared economic system, which provided a modicum of financial stability. [[Neoliberal]] economic reforms after the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union|fall of the USSR]] and the [[Eastern Bloc]] resulted in harsh living standards for the general population. Policies associated with [[privatization]] allowed of the country's economy to fall in the hands of a [[Russian oligarch|newly established business oligarchy]]. The sense of belonging to a great [[superpower]] was a secondary reason for the nostalgia; many felt humiliated and betrayed by their experiences throughout the 1990s and blamed the upheaval on advisors from Western powers, especially as NATO moved closer into Russia's sphere of influence.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/12/21/why-do-so-many-people-miss-the-soviet-union/ Why do so many people miss the Soviet Union?] ''[[The Washington Post]].'' December 21, 2016.</ref>
According to Dr. [[Kristen R. Ghodsee]], a researcher on post-communist nostalgia in Eastern Europe:
{{bquote|"Only by examining how the quotidian aspects of daily life were affected by great social, political and economic changes can we make sense of the desire for this collectively imagined, more egalitarian past. Nobody wants to revive 20th century [[totalitarianism]]. But nostalgia for communism has become a common language through which ordinary men and women express disappointment with the shortcomings of parliamentary democracy and neoliberal capitalism today."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wamc.org/post/dr-kristen-ghodsee-bowdoin-college-nostalgia-communism|title=Dr. Kristen Ghodsee, Bowdoin College - Nostalgia for Communism|last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>}}

{{Infobox Korean name| |context=north |image=Pyongyang International Film Festival 2014 (15349304435) (2).jpg |caption= |hangul={{linktext|평|양| 국|제| 영|화| 축|전|}} |hanja={{linktext|平|壤| 國|際| 映|畵| 祝|典|}} |rr=Pyeongyang Gukje Yeonghwa Chukjeon |mr=P'yŏngyang Kukche Yŏnghwa Ch'ukchŏn }} The '''Pyongyang International Film Festival''' is a biennial cultural exhibition held in [[Pyongyang]], [[North Korea]]. The [[film festival]] is a very cosmopolitan event; prior to 2002, it was reserved to "non-aligned and other developing countries."{{cite web|url=http://pyongyanginternationalfilmfestival.com/|website=PIFF |title=Pyongyang International Film Festival|accessdate=12 August 2017}} ==History== The event originated in 1987 as the '''Pyongyang Film Festival of the Non-aligned and Other Developing Countries'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/features/lonely-place-north-korea-s-pyongyang-international-film |title=In a lonely place: North Korea's Pyongyang International Film Festival |author=James Bell |work=Sight & Sound |publisher=British Film Institute |date=January 2009 |accessdate=11 January 2016}} The maiden event, held from September 1 through September 10, showed short films, features, and documentaries that were judged for competitive awards. The film festival returned in 1990 and would be regularly held every other year. Recurrent subject matter included domestic cinema that commonly praised the high leadership such as a film shown at the 1992 film festival, verbosely translated, ''Glory of Our People in Holding the Great Leader in High Esteem'', and foreign films about revolutionary resistance. In 2000, officials widened the acceptable breadth of film watching, by screening Japanese films for the first time when [[Yoji Yamada]] arrived to present six of his films.{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=12}} The ninth festival, held in 2004, moderated cultural restrictions further with the screening of a dubbed and censored version of the [[United Kingdom|British]] comedy ''[[Bend It Like Beckham]]'' and [[United States|U.S.]]-produced [[South Africa]]n drama ''[[Cry, The Beloved Country (1995 film)|Cry, The Beloved Country]]''. ''Bend it like Beckham'' won the music prize and later it became the first Western-made film shown on television in North Korea. In 2006, the Swedish horror comedy ''[[Frostbiten]]'' was shown at the festival, the first foreign horror film to ever be shown in North Korea. ''[[The Schoolgirl's Diary]]'', which premiered at the 2006 festival, in 2007 became the first North Korean film in several decades to be picked up for international distribution, when it was purchased by French company Pretty Pictures. It was released in France in late 2007.{{cite news|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,1928365,00.html|publisher=The Guardian|date=2006-10-22|accessdate=2007-05-27|title=Cinematic bombshell from Kim|last=Burke|first=Jason}} ==Organization== The festival is held in the autumn every two years. It has an international jury and both competitive and non-competitive submissions. In that sense, it is "structured ... very much like any other international film festival".{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=11}} Since 2000, the festival has been dominated by films from Western Europe.{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=12}} Many of the films are censored and often have themes emphasising family values, loyalty and the temptations of money. In 2008, 110 films were shown from a total of 46 countries.[http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/front/la-fg-film11-2008oct11,0,7893170.story?page=1 "North Korea Film Festival"], ''LA Times'', October 11, 2008. South Korean films are not shown because of the current political climate.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3805128/Festival-brings-world-cinema-Pyongyang.html |title=Festival brings (some) world cinema to Pyongyang |agency=AFP |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=24 September 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016}}{{better source needed|date=November 2017}} Films critical of North Korean from anywhere in the world are not allowed and neither are sexually explicit films. Anything else goes, and the organizers try to get as many films and visitors to attend.{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=11}} Diplomatic connections or the personal initiative of filmmakers is what often results in a film being admitted. The result is often "an odd mix" of films that are not united by one genre. In recent years, the festival has enjoyed recent popularity abroad, mainly due to the success of [[South Korean cinema]] prompting foreign film enthusiasts' curiosity about the North. Consequentially, film submissions have increased and the selection of films has improved in quality.{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=12}} In 2016, the animated Spanish film ''[[Mortadelo and Filemon: Mission Implausible]]'' was featured, became the first animated Spanish film and the first comic's adaptation to be shown.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} The festival is one of the few North Korean functions that actively seeks connection with the outside world.{{Sfn|Schönherr|2012|p=11}} [[Johannes Schönherr]], author of ''North Korean Cinema: A History'' and a festival delegate in 2000, said "The Pyongyang International Film Festival is a big propaganda event and foreigners who attend the event become extras in the big propaganda show."{{Cite news |last=Moxley|first=Mitch|date=2015-02-03|title=The Reddest Carpet: I Survived the North Korean Film Festival|url=https://www.gq.com/story/north-korean-film-festival-exclusive|journal=GQ Magazine}} ==Major Award Winners== {|border="2"cellpadding="3"cellspacing="0"style="border-collapse:collapse;margin:0auto;" class="wikitable" |- ||Year||Best Film Grand Prix||Best Director||Best Actor||Best Actress |- |1987

[[File:Bildungsstreik Göttingen 1568.jpg|thumb|A [[sit-in]] is one of many tools in the modern movement's repertoires of contention.]] [[File:Rough music.png|thumb|Repertoires can be transitory; consider the disappearance of [[rough music]], popular in the 18th century [[Great Britain]].]] [[File:Schienenblockade.jpg|thumb|Activists blocking [[Fossil fuel phase-out|railway lines leading to a coal mine]] to [[Climate change mitigation|limit climate change]] ([[Ende Gelände 2016]]).]]
'''Repertoire of contention''' refers, in [[social movement]] theory, to the set of various protest-related tools and actions available to a movement or related organization in a given time frame.<ref name=bw/><ref name="SnowSoule2004"/>
== Description ==
Repertoires are often shared between social actors; as one group (organization, movement, etc.) finds a certain tool or action successful, in time, it is likely to spread to others.<ref name=bw/><ref name="SnowSoule2004"/> However, in addition to providing options, repertoires can be seen as limiting, as people tend to focus on familiar tools and actions, and innovation outside their scope is uncommon (see [[diffusion of innovations]]).<ref name=bw/><ref name="Tarrow1998"/>
Actions and tools that belong to common repertoires of contention include, but are not limited to: creation of special-purpose associations and coalitions, public meetings, solemn [[procession]]s, [[vigils]], [[Political rally|rallies]], [[demonstration (people)|demonstration]]s, [[sit-in]]s, [[petition]] drives, statements to and in public [[Mass media|media]], [[boycott]]s, [[strike (action)|strike]]s and [[pamphleteering]]. Repertoires change over time, and can vary from place to place.<ref name="SnowSoule2004"/><ref name="Tarrow1998"/> They are determined both by what the actors know how to do, and what is expected from them.<ref name="Tarrow1998"/> Early repertoires, from the time before the rise of the modern [[social movement]], included [[food riot]]s and [[banditry]].<ref name="SnowSoule2004"/> The changing nature of repertoires of contention can be seen in a sample element of the mid-18th century [[Great Britain|British]] repertoire of contention, the [[rough music]]: a humiliating and loud public punishment inflicted upon one or more people who have violated the standards of the rest of the community.<ref name="Tilly2003"/> For yet another example, consider that in the recent years, [[Internet]]-focused repertoires have been developed (see [[hacktivism]]).<ref name=bw/> Recent scholarship has introduced a notion that in addition to the "traditional" and "modern" repertoires, a new, "digital", repertoire may be emerging.<ref name="EarlKimport2011"/>
While the term is used most often in the social movement theory context, it can be applied to any political actors.<ref name="Tilly2002"/> Repertoires of contention also existed before the birth of the modern social movement (a period most scholars identify as the late 18th to early 19th century).<ref name="Tarrow1998"/>
The term is attributed to [[Charles Tilly]].<ref name="bw"/><ref name="Tarrow1998"/>
==References== {{reflist|35em|refs=
<ref name="EarlKimport2011">{{cite book|author1=Jennifer Earl|author2=Katrina Kimport|title=Digitally Enabled Social Change: Activism in the Internet Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IZAS_YGFVeMC&pg=PA16|accessdate=11 June 2011|date=31 March 2011|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0-262-01510-3|page=16}}</ref>
<ref name="SnowSoule2004">{{cite book|author1=David A. Snow|author2=Sarah Anne Soule|author3=Hanspeter Kriesi|title=The Blackwell companion to social movements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6ACcrTbUuEUC&pg=PA300|accessdate=22 January 2011|year=2004|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-631-22669-7|pages=300–}}</ref>
<ref name="Tarrow1998">{{cite book|author=Sidney G. Tarrow|title=Power in movement: social movements and contentious politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-VHOc4XpDAC&pg=PA30|accessdate=22 January 2011|year=1998|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-62947-8|pages=30–}}</ref>
<ref name="Tilly2002">{{cite book|author=Charles Tilly|title=Stories, identities, and political change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nf0EPulxiZwC&pg=PA5|accessdate=22 January 2011|year=2002|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-1882-7|pages=5–}}</ref>
<ref name="Tilly2003">{{cite book|author=Charles Tilly|title=The politics of collective violence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ycwqpVKx4H4C&pg=PA45|accessdate=22 January 2011|year=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-53145-0|pages=45–}}</ref>
<ref name="bw">Brett Rolfe, ''[http://digitalstrategist.typepad.com/articles/paper_repertoire.pdf Building an Electronic Repertoire of Contention]''. ''Social Movement Studies'',Vol. 4, No. 1, 65–74, May 2005</ref> }}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Seedbed''''' is a [[performance art|performance piece]] first performed by [[Vito Acconci]] on 15–29 January 1972 at [[Sonnabend Gallery]] in [[New York City]].
In the piece, there is a low wooden ramp merging with the floor. The ramp extends across the width of the room, beginning two feet up the side of one wall and slanting down to the middle of the floor.
In his original performance of the piece, Acconci lay hidden underneath the ramp installed at the Sonnabend Gallery, masturbating. The artist's spoken fantasies about the visitors walking above him were heard through loudspeakers in the gallery.<ref name="description">{{ cite news |publisher=Kunstmuseum Luzern |title=Vito Acconci - Kunstmuseum Luzern |date=May 1978 }}</ref>
"In this legendary sculpture/performance Acconci lay beneath a ramp built in the Sonnabend Gallery. Over the course of three weeks, he masturbated eight hours a day while murmuring things like, "You're pushing your cunt down on my mouth" or "You're ramming your cock down into my ass." Not only does the architectural intervention presage much of his subsequent work, but all of Acconci's fixations converge in this, the spiritual sphincter of his art. In ''Seedbed'', Acconci is the producer and the receiver of the work's pleasure. He is simultaneously public and private, making marks yet leaving little behind, and demonstrating ultra-awareness of his viewer while being in a semi-trance state." - [[Jerry Saltz]]
A video of the piece itself shows no sexual content; it all is merely suggested.<ref>http://www.ubu.com/film/acconci_seedbed.html</ref>
[[Marina Abramović]] performed ''Seedbed'' as part of her ''[[Seven Easy Pieces]]'' in 2005.<ref>[http://pastexhibitions.guggenheim.org/abramovic/ Guggenheim, Past exhibitions]</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://pastexhibitions.guggenheim.org/abramovic/ Guggenheim Press Release on ''Seven Easy Pieces'' as interpreted by Marina Abramović] - Nov.9-15, 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060209063317/http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/arts/art/15228/index.html Interview ''New York Times'' - Provocateur: Marina Abramović]
{{Performance art}}
[[Category:Performances]]

{{ElectionsSC}} Prior to 1865, the [[Governor of South Carolina]] was chosen by the [[South Carolina General Assembly|General Assembly]]. The constitution of 1865 provided for the voters of [[South Carolina]] to choose the governor; [[James Lawrence Orr]] was the first elected governor of South Carolina. 41.4% |} ==Statistics== ===Firsts=== *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1865|gubernatorial election of 1865]] was the first gubernatorial election of [[South Carolina]]. *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1868|gubernatorial election of 1868]] was the first election that [[African American|blacks]] were given the right to vote in South Carolina. *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1896|gubernatorial election of 1896]] was the first gubernatorial election that featured the use of a [[primary election]]. *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1898|gubernatorial election of 1898]] was the first gubernatorial election that featured the use of a [[Two-round system|runoff election]]. ===Votes=== *There have been 51 gubernatorial elections in South Carolina. *[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] have won 40 of the 47 (85%) elections that they nominated a candidate. *[[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] have won 10 of the 18 (56%) elections that they nominated a candidate. *[[James Lawrence Orr]] won with the smallest margin of victory in the [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1865|gubernatorial election of 1865]]: 743. *[[Carroll A. Campbell, Jr.]] garnered the largest margin of victory in the [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1990|gubernatorial election of 1990]]: 316,797. *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1926|gubernatorial election of 1926]] had the lowest vote: 16,589. *The [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 2002|gubernatorial election of 2002]] had the largest vote: 1,107,725. ===Unique politicians=== *Only [[Duncan Clinch Heyward]] in the [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1904|gubernatorial election of 1904]] and [[Robert Archer Cooper]] in the [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1920|gubernatorial election of 1920]] faced no opposition in both the primary election and the general election. *[[Olin D. Johnston]] is the only governor to be elected to nonconsecutive terms in [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1934|1934]] and [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1942|1942]]. *Only three governors have been defeated for reelection: [[Daniel Henry Chamberlain]] in [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1876|1876]], [[David Beasley]] in [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1998|1998]] and [[Jim Hodges]] in [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 2002|2002]]. *[[Coleman Livingston Blease]] has made the most attempts for governor (8): [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1906|1906]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1908|1908]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1910|1910]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1912|1912]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1916|1916]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1922|1922]], [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1934|1934]] and [[South Carolina gubernatorial election, 1938|1938]]. He was successful in 1910 and 1912. ==See also== *[[Governor of South Carolina]] *[[List of Governors of South Carolina]] == External links == * [http://www.sciway.net/hist/governors/gov_term.html SCIway List of South Carolina Governors in Chronological Order] {{South Carolina gubernatorial elections}} {{Governors of South Carolina}} [[Category:Governors of South Carolina| ]] [[Category:South Carolina gubernatorial elections| ]] [[Category:Quadrennial events]]

{{redirect|SHAC}} {{Infobox non-profit | Non-profit_name = Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty | Non-profit_logo = [[File:Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (logo).png|200px]] | Non-profit_type = | Non-profit_slogan = | founded_date = November 1999 | founder = [[Greg Avery]]
[[Heather Nicholson]]
Natasha Dellemagne | active = 1999-2014 | location = UK and US | origins = England | product = | focus = [[Animal rights|Animal-rights]] campaign to close [[Huntingdon Life Sciences]]. Opposition to [[animal testing]]. | method = [[Leaderless resistance]]
[[Direct action]] | num_volunteers = | num_members = | homepage = [http://www.shac.net/ shac.net]}} '''Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty''' ('''SHAC''') was an international [[animal rights]] campaign to close down [[Huntingdon Life Sciences]] (HLS), Europe's largest contract [[Animal testing|animal-testing]] laboratory. SHAC ended its campaign in August 2014. HLS tests medical and non-medical substances on around 75,000 animals every year, from rats to primates.[http://www.drugresearcher.com/news/ng.asp?n=72122-faseb-us-government-huntingdon "New bill clamps down on animal activist activity"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712081822/http://www.drugresearcher.com/news/ng.asp?n=72122-faseb-us-government-huntingdon |date=12 July 2007 }}, ''Drug Researcher'', 17 November 2006.*[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=42 "From push to shove"] Southern Poverty Law Center, Fall 2002.Townsend, Mark. [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,940033,00.html "Exposed: secrets of the animal organ lab"], ''The Observer'', 20 April 2003. It has been the subject of several major leaks or undercover investigations by activists and reporters since 1989. SHAC was started in November 1999 by three British animal rights activists—[[Greg Avery]], [[Heather Nicholson|Heather James]], and Natasha Dellemagne—after video footage supposed to have been shot covertly inside HLS in 1997 by [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) showed HLS staff shaking, punching, and shouting at beagles in their care.Alleyne, Richard. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1318487/Terror-tactics-that-brought-a-company-to-its-knees.html "Terror tactics that brought a company to its knees"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 19 January 2001. *Also see [https://web.archive.org/web/20051029044713/http://www.shac.net/movies/crueltyfootage.mov "It's a Dog's Life"], ''Countryside Undercover'', Channel Four Television, 1997. The footage was broadcast by Channel 4 in the UK, the employees were dismissed and prosecuted, and HLS's licence to perform animal experiments was revoked for six months. PETA stopped its protests against the company after HLS threatened it with legal action, and SHAC took over as a [[leaderless resistance]].Doward, Jamie and Townsend, Mark. [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/focus/story/0,6903,1273697,00.html "Beauty and the beasts"], ''The Observer'', 1 August 2004. The campaign used tactics ranging from non-violent protest to the alleged firebombing of houses owned by executives associated with HLS's clients and investors. The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), which monitors US domestic extremism, has described SHAC's ''modus operandi'' as "frankly terroristic tactics similar to those of anti-abortion extremists," and in 2005 an official with the FBI's counter-terrorism division referred to SHAC's activities in the United States as domestic terrorist threats.[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=42 "From push to shove"], Southern Poverty Law Group ''Intelligence Report'', Fall 2002Lewis, John E. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080801014736/http://epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=247787 "Statement of John Lewis"], US Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, 26 October 2005, accessed 17 January 2011. In 2009 and 2010, 13 members of SHAC, including Avery, James, and Dellemagne, were jailed for between 15 months and eleven years on charges of conspiracy to blackmail or harm HLS and its suppliers. On 12 August 2014, SHAC officially announced it was closing its campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.shac.net |title=SHAC ends |publisher=Shac.net |accessdate=12 August 2014}} ==Background== HLS tests household cleaners, pesticides, weedkillers, cosmetics, food additives, chemicals for use in industry, and drugs for use against Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, and cancer.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1123837.stm "A controversial laboratory"], BBC News, 18 January 2001. It uses around 75,000 animals every year, including rats, rabbits, pigs, dogs, and primates (marmosets, macaques, and wild-caught baboons).[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=42 "From push to shove"] Southern Poverty Law Group ''Intelligence Report'', Fall 2002. *Townsend, Mark. [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,940033,00.html "Exposed: secrets of the animal organ lab"], ''The Observer'', 20 April 2003. The company has been the subject of several undercover investigations since 1989. Sarah Kite of the [[British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection]] (BUAV) secured a job and filmed inside HLS in 1989. Zoe Broughton did the same for Channel Four in 1996, as Michelle Rokke claimed to have done for PETA in 1997. Lucy Johnston for ''The Daily Express'' gained access in 2000. A diary kept by Kite, who worked undercover there for eight months, alleged that HLS workers routinely mishandled the animals, shouting at them, throwing them into their cages, and mocking them for having fits in response to toxicity tests. In 1997, Zoe Broughton came out with footage showing puppies being hit and shaken. A year later, Michelle Rokke allegedly obtained footage of the [[vivisection]] of a monkey in HLS in New Jersey, in which a technician expresses concern that the animal is inadequately anaesthetized.[http://www.insidehls.com/inside_kite.htm "The First Investigation"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827213152/http://www.insidehls.com/inside_kite.htm |date=27 August 2008 }}; [http://www.insidehls.com/inside_broughton.htm "It's a Dog's Life"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827213115/http://www.insidehls.com/inside_broughton.htm |date=27 August 2008 }} (Zoe Broughton for Channel Four in 1996); [http://www.insidehls.com/inside_rokke.htm "HLS busted again"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827212839/http://www.insidehls.com/inside_rokke.htm |date=27 August 2008 }} (Michelle Rokke for PETA in 1997); and Johnstone, Lucy and Calvert, Jonathan. [http://www.insidehls.com/inside_xeno.htm "Terrible despair of animals cut up in name of research"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827213308/http://www.insidehls.com/inside_xeno.htm |date=27 August 2008 }} (Lucy Johnston for ''The Daily Express'' in 2000). *Also see Mann, Keith. ''From Dusk 'til Dawn: An insider's view of the growth of the Animal Liberation Movement''. Puppy Pincher Press, 2007, pp. 198–199. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051031040108/http://www.huntingdonsucks.com/gallery/scared_monkey.mov "Undercover video footage of HLS employees apparently dissecting a live monkey"], filmed at the HLS Princeton Research Center, New Jersey, accessed 20 June 2009. Between 2006 and 2008, an [[Animal Defenders International]] employee filmed undercover inside HLS after securing a position inside its primate toxicology unit in Cambridgeshire.[http://www.ad-international.org/publications/go.php?id=1576&si=98 "Huntingdon Life Sciences Investigation"], Animal Defenders International, 15 July 2009, accessed 17 January 2011. *[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2009/02/04/18568236.php "HLS Infiltrated by Undercover Investigation"], indybay.org, accessed 17 January 2011. *Also see [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fg-uetBwGho "Save the Primates"], Animal Defenders International, shown at the European Parliament in February 2009, courtesy of ''YouTube'', accessed 17 January 2011. According to Mark Matfield of the [[Research Defence Society]], a pro-animal testing lobby group in the UK, HLS lost a great deal of business after these investigations, primarily among the pharmaceutical industry. "There was an ingrained feeling among scientists and business people that this company had transgressed in a very serious way," he said.Rudacille, Deborah. ''The Scalpel and the Butterfly: The Conflict between Animal Research and Animal Protection''. University of California Press, 2001, p. 286. ==Structure== ===SHAC UK=== SHAC was founded in November 1999 by Greg Avery; his second wife, Natasha Avery (née Dellemagne); and his first wife, Heather Nicholson (née James). Avery and Nicholson had been involved in previous high-profile campaigns against facilities in the UK that bred animals for laboratories. In 1997, after a ten-month campaign, they caused the closure of [[Consort beagles|Consort Kennels]], which bred beagles for animal research. Later that year, they started [[Save the Hill Grove Cats]] against Hill Grove farm in Oxfordshire, which bred cats for laboratories. The farm closed after two years. SHAC maintained a decentralized approach with no official central leadership, allowing activists throughout the UK and North America to act autonomously, though ''The Guardian'' described Avery in 2008 as the ''de facto'' leader.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/24/profile-animal-research-activists "Campaigns, protests and prison terms: how activists formed militant cell"], ''The Guardian'', 24 December 2008. After Avery was jailed, another activist, Thomas Harris, ran the group in the UK until he was imprisoned in 2010.Weaver, Matthew. [https://www.theguardian.com/science/2010/oct/25/animal-research-animal-welfare "Animal rights activists jailed for terrorising suppliers to Huntingdon Life Sciences"], ''The Guardian'', 25 October 2010. Before their convictions, Nicholson, Avery, and Dellemagne would publish reports on the SHAC website and by mail, and provide press information and interviews; in April 2004 they were reported to be living together rent-free in a cottage provided by a supporter, Virginia Jane Steele.Doward, Jamie. [https://www.theguardian.com/animalrights/story/0,11917,1189921,00.html "Sex and violence allegations split animal rights campaign"], ''The Observer'', 11 April 2004. SHAC also obtains income from fundraising stalls. According to ''The Times'', one stall in London's Oxford Street could generate £500 in a single day, and in total around £1 million in donations had been raised by 2008.Yeoman, Fran. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article5391799.ece "The £1m hate campaign paid for by high street collections"], ''The Times'', 24 December 2008. According to prosecutors in a 2008 court case, the senior members of SHAC co-ordinated the campaign from a cottage in Little Moorcote, near [[Hook, Hart|Hook]], Hampshire.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article4902105.ece "Animal rights activists' 'blackmail campaign spanned Europe and US'"], ''The Times'', 7 October 2008. They would meet every three months to receive updates from colleagues in the United States and Europe.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7657837.stm "Police bugged animal rights group"], BBC News, 7 October 2008. According to ''The Times'', Gavin Medd-Hall, a former computer technician, would lead research into potential targets. The police found spreadsheets at the cottage documenting the location of targets and details about their children and security arrangements. Sarah Whitehead, an experienced campaigner known in the group as "Mumsy", would lead younger members and carry up to five attacks in a night, according to the judge. ===SHAC USA=== SHAC USA was founded in 2004 by Kevin Jonas, sometimes spelled Kjonaas by the media, a political science graduate of the [[University of Minnesota]], after he had spent two years working in the UK with Greg Avery. Prosecutors in the U.S. said that a house in [[Somerset, New Jersey]] — a few miles from a HLS laboratory — was the headquarters of SHAC USA; Jonas lived there with Lauren Gazzola, SHAC USA's campaign co-ordinator, and Jacob Conroy. According to Jonas, the "SHAC campaign" came to mean any action aimed at contributing to the demise of HLS, whether legal or not, while SHAC itself referred only to the incorporated group that ran a news and information service. Jonas writes that these distinctions were made in various legal proceedings.Jonas, Kevin. "Bricks and Bullhorns" in Best, Steven and Nocella, Anthony J. (eds.) ''Terrorists or Freedom Fighters?'', Lantern Books, 2004; see p. 271 for legal distinctions. He told the Southern Poverty Law Center in 2002: "There's a very famous quote by John F. Kennedy. 'If you make peaceful revolution impossible, you make violent revolution inevitable.'"[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=42 "From Push to Shove"], Southern Policy Law Center, Fall 2002. After he was imprisoned in 2006 for inciting harassment against HLS, [[Pamelyn Ferdin]], a former child actor, became president of SHAC USA. ===Methods=== ====Secondary and tertiary targeting==== SHAC's ''modus operandi'' is known as secondary and tertiary targeting. Activists engage in [[direct action]]—ranging from lawful protests to intimidation, harassment, and violent attacks—not only against HLS, its employees, and its employees' families, but also against secondary and tertiary targets such as HLS's business partners, and ''their'' business partners, insurers, caterers, cleaners, children's nursery schools, and office suppliers.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/4295706.stm "Childcare group warned of 'hell'"], BBC News, 29 September 2005. *Also see [{{cite web |url=http://epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=247787 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801014736/http://epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=247787 |archivedate=1 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }} U.S. Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works. A New York yacht club, for example, was covered in red paint because members of the club worked for Carr Securities, which traded in HLS shares.Lewis, John E. [http://epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=247787 "Statement of John Lewis"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801014736/http://epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=247787 |date=1 August 2008 }}, U.S. Senate Committee on Environment & Public Works, 26 October 2005, accessed 17 January 2011. The campaign drove down HLS's profits, suppressed its share price, and made it difficult to find business and financial partners.[https://www.theguardian.com/animalrights/story/0,,1787250,00.html "Money talks"], ''The Guardian'', 1 June 2006. *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/1247506.stm "Lab firm ditched by share brokers"], BBC News, 28 March 2001. The SHAC website said it published names and addresses only so that people could protest within the law,[http://www.shac.net/disclaimer/disclaimer.html SHAC Disclaimer] but testimony to the British House of Commons in 2003 included excerpts from a document reported to have come from SHAC, which advised activists on tactics for protests outside targets' homes. These included throwing rape alarms in roof guttering at night, setting off fireworks, and ordering taxis and pizzas.[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200203/cmhansrd/vo030319/halltext/30319h01.htm House of Commons Hansard Debates], 19 March 2003. In 2001, HLS managing director in the UK, [[Brian Cass]], was beaten outside his home by three masked men — animal rights activist David Blenkinsop was sentenced to three years in prison for the attack — and HLS marketing director Andrew Gay was attacked on his doorstep with a chemical spray to his eyes that left him temporarily blinded.[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=42 "From push to shove"], Southern Poverty Law Group ''Intelligence Report'', Fall 2002. ====Shareholders==== In 2000, SHAC obtained a list of HLS shareholders, including the names of usually anonymous beneficial owners — those holding shares through third parties — and the pension funds of the British Labour Party, Rover cars, and the London Borough of Camden. The list was passed to ''The Sunday Telegraph'', which published it on 3 December 2000, and several beneficial owners disposed of their shares; the Labour Party sold its 75,000 shares in January 2001. Two weeks after the ''Telegraph'' story, an equity stake of 32 million shares was placed on the London Stock Exchange for one penny each.Huntingdon Life Sciences, financial report 2002. On 21 December 2000, HLS was dropped from the New York Stock Exchange because its [[market capitalization]] had fallen below NYSE limits, and on 29 March 2001, HLS lost both of its [[market maker]]s and its place on the London Stock Exchange. Shortly after this, HLS moved its headquarters to the United States, incorporating as Life Sciences Research (LSR), and secured a $15m loan from investment bank [[Stephens Inc.|Stephens, Inc]], its largest shareholder. In September 2005, after the firebombing of the homes of a Canadian brokerage employee and a British pharmaceutical executive, the New York Stock Exchange asked LSR to delay moving its listing from the [[OTC Bulletin Board]] to the main exchange.[https://www.theguardian.com/business/story/0,3604,1565018,00.html "Huntingdon delays listing after attacks"], ''The Guardian'', 8 September 2005. LSR has since transferred its listing to the [[NYSE Arca]] electronic exchange. HLS is no longer a publicly traded company after being bought by CEO Andrew Baker.[http://www.outsourcing-pharma.com/Preclinical-Research/LSR-goes-private-in-Lion-Holdings-takeover "LSR goes private in Lion Holdings takeover"], ''Outsourcing'', pharma.com, 1 December 2009. In June 2005, Vancouver-based brokerage [[Canaccord Capital]] announced that it had dropped a client, Phytopharm PLC, in response to the May 2005 [[Animal Liberation Front]] (ALF) firebombing of a car belonging to Canaccord executive Michael Kendall. The ALF stated on its website that activists placed an incendiary device under the car, which was in Kendall's garage at home when it caught fire during the night. Kendall and his family went into hiding. Phytopharm was targeted, as were those doing business with it, because it had business links with HLS.Won, Shirley, and Zehr, Leonard. [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/ArticleNews/TPStory/LAC/20050624/RCANNA24/TPBusiness/TopStories&ord=167360581&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true "When threats turn to firebombs, Canaccord cuts loose on client"]{{dead link|date=June 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''The Globe and Mail'', 24 June 2005. In May 2006, an anonymous group said it would be writing to every one of GlaxoSmithKline's 170,000 small investors warning them to sell their shares. The letters began arriving at investors' home addresses on 7 May 2006, asking that shares be sold within 14 days, and that the group be informed of the sale by e-mail via a Hotmail address.[https://www.theguardian.com/animalrights/story/0,,1770638,00.html "Animal rights activists tell drug firm's small investors to sell up or else"], ''The Guardian'', 9 May 2006. The number of letters sent was smaller than claimed; the BBC said at least 50 shareholders received the warning.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4756381.stm Glaxo wins injunction over threat], 9 May 2006. Writing in ''The Sunday Telegraph'' the following week, British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] expressed support for animal experimentation in the face of an ''"appalling ... campaign of intimidation."'' {{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1518328/Tony-Blair-Time-to-act-against-animal-rights-protesters.html|title=Tony Blair: Time to act against animal rights protesters|date=2006-05-13|access-date=2018-01-26|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} ===Ties to the ALF=== The SHAC website features ALF news. Kevin Jonas — who took charge of SHAC UK while the Averys and James were jailed for six months in 2002 — declared his support for the ALF, and [[Robin Webb]], spokesman for the ALF in the UK, attended and addressed SHAC conferences in the United States. A posting on the website ''Bite Back'' on 7 September 2005 claimed the ALF had carried out an attack on the home of Paul Blackburn, corporate controller of GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), in [[Buckinghamshire]], because GSK is a customer of HLS. The activists admitted to detonating a device containing two litres of fuel and four pounds of explosives on the doorstep of Blackburn's home.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/health/article571964.ece Bomb attack on Glaxo executive], ''The Times'', 28 September 2005 In 2006 the ALF warned that it was targeting HLS suppliers, and that year firebombed a car belonging to the finance director of Canaccord Capital, a brokerage firm. Members of SHAC said the company had acted as brokers for [[Phytopharm]], which had used HLS for contract testing.Laville, Sandra and Campbell, Duncan. [https://www.theguardian.com/animalrights/story/0,11917,1514393,00.html "Animal rights extremists in arson spree"], ''The Guardian'', 25 June 2006. In December 2006, Donald Currie was jailed for 12 years in connection with fire bombing offenses against HLS customers; police described him as an "active bomber for the [[Animal Liberation Front]]."Addley, Esther. [https://www.theguardian.com/frontpage/story/0,,1852939,00.html "Animal Liberation Front bomber faces jail after admitting arson bids"], ''The Guardian'', 18 August 2006. *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6215144.stm "Willing to maim in the name of animals"], ''BBC News'', 7 December 2006. A British police operation found that the core group of SHAC activists would compile private encrypted reports detailing the legal protests and an illegal blackmail campaign—the former attributed to SHAC, the latter claimed by the ALF or [[Animal Rights Militia]]. In 2008 and 2010 when 13 SHAC members, including the Averys and Nicholson, were convicted of conspiracy to blackmail, police said their actions were on behalf of the ALF; senior members of SHAC were regarded by police as key figures within the ALF, according to ''The Guardian''. The members had sent incriminating emails describing their involvement in direct action, including one email sent to ''Bite Back'' in 2007 providing the details of an ALF attack the previous evening.Laville, Sandra. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/24/huntingdon-life-sciences "Animal rights extremists still targeting lab"], ''The Guardian'', 24 December 2008. *Laville, Sandra. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/23/ukcrime-animalwelfare "From a Hampshire cottage, animal extremists plotted campaign of violence"], ''The Guardian'', 23 December 2008. SHAC spokespersons have denied any link between their campaign and the ALF. The FBI linked SHAC with attacks claimed by the militant animal rights group, the [[Animal Liberation Brigade]]. They issued an arrest warrant for [[Daniel Andreas San Diego]], who they described as being "involved with the Stop Huntington Animal Cruelty campaign", in connection with bomb attacks against two of HLS's clients in California.Doyle, Leonard. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/5217035/Animal-rights-activist-added-to-FBIs-most-wanted-terrorist-list.html Animal rights activist added to FBI's most wanted terrorist list], ''The Telegraph'', 24 April 2009. A [[wiretap]] of Kevin Jonas' telephone revealed San Diego had called him on the day of one of the bombings. San Diego was added to the [[FBI Most Wanted Terrorists]] List in 2009 and remains at large.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/wanted_terrorists/daniel-andreas-san-diego/view|title=FBI's Most Wanted Terrorists List: Daniel Andreas San Diego|date=2009-04-21|publisher=FBI|accessdate=2011-01-18}} ==Convictions and legislation== Several companies targeted by SHAC in the UK obtained injunctions. These include HLS itself, Chiron UK, Phytopharm, Daiichi UK, Asahi Glass, Eisai, Yamanouchi Pharma, Sankyo Pharma, and BOC. The injunctions compelled SHAC to print the injunction on their website, so that SHAC's action targets were juxtaposed with a legal notification that there was a 50-yard exclusion zone around the homes of employees and places of business. Protest outside HLS itself was allowed to occur one day a week with a police presence. HLS tried but failed in June 2004 to obtain a permanent injunction against SHAC. SHAC's argument against the enforceability of such injunctions was that, despite having hundreds of supporters, a website, mailing address, telephone information hotline, mailing list, and bank account, it does not exist as a corporate or charitable body, and therefore cannot prevent its supporters from taking action against HLS.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2004/06/24/cnhunt24.xml "Huntingdon told to prove animal rights group exists"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 24 June 2004. SHAC's campaign prompted the introduction of sections 145–149 of the British [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005]], which created new offences intended to protect animal-testing facilities, including prohibiting acts or threats intended to cause someone to terminate or not enter into a contract with such a facility.Tempest, Matthew. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-1320712,00.html "Crackdown on animal rights extremists"], ''The Guardian'', 31 January 2005[https://web.archive.org/web/20051030225623/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200405/cmstand/d/st050120/am/50120s08.htm "Serious Organised Crime and Police Bill"], House of Commons, 2005. The first person to be convicted under the Act was Joseph Harris, a doctor of [[molecular biology]], who attacked property owned by companies supplying materials to HLS; he received a three-year sentence.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hampshire/5362926.stm "Animal rights protester is jailed"], BBC News, 20 September 2006. In February 2007, a number of SHAC supporters were charged with illegal street collecting without a licence.Smit, Martina. [http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/misc/print.php?artid=1209501 "21 'illegally' collected for animal rights terror"], thisislocallondon.co.uk, 22 February 2007. According to the Metropolitan Police, two stalls in London's Oxford Street collected over £80,000 a year. In March 2007, three activists were jailed under the Act for intimidating HLS suppliers; one supplier dropped its contract with HLS after being invaded by demonstrators wearing skull masks.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/6423061.stm "Three 'violent' activists jailed"], BBC News, 6 March 2007. ===2006: SHAC 7 (U.S.)=== [[File:SHAC7.png|right|thumb|300px|Logo of the SHAC 7 Support Group]] In March 2006, a federal jury in [[Trenton, New Jersey]], found six members of SHAC guilty of using their website to incite attacks on those who did business with HLS.Kocieniewski, David. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/03/nyregion/03animals.html "Six Animal Rights Advocates Are Convicted of Terrorism"], ''The New York Times'', 3 March 2006. Originally, seven individuals (the SHAC 7) were charged: Kevin Jonas (former president of Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty USA), Lauren Gazzola, Jacob Conroy, Joshua Harper, Andrew Stepanian, Darius Fullmer, and John McGee. McGee was later dropped from the case.Cook, John. [http://www.salon.com/life/feature/2006/02/07/thugs_puppies "Thugs for Puppies"], ''Salon'', 7 February 2006. They were charged with conspiracy to violate the [[Animal Enterprise Protection Act]], in the first application of the 1992 statute. Jonas, Gazzola, Conroy, and Harper were charged with conspiracy to harass using a telecommunications device (sending [[black fax]]es), while Jonas, Gazzola, Conroy, and SHAC USA were charged with stalking via the internet. The defense of the SHAC 7 rested largely on the 1969 case ''[[Brandenburg v. Ohio]]'', in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled that political speech is legal unless it can be shown that a defendant has told specific individuals to commit specific, imminent acts of violence.[https://www.motherjones.com/news/outfront/2006/01/america_no1_threat.html "America's #1 Threat"], ''Mother Jones'', January/February 2006. They were sentenced on 3 March 2006, four of them to between three and six years, and ordered to pay joint restitution of $1,000,001.00. {{citation needed|date=February 2014}} In 2011, [[NPR]] reported that Andrew Stepanian of the SHAC 7 -- since released—had been imprisoned in the highly restrictive [[Communication Management Unit]] of the U.S. federal prison system. ===2007: Operation Achilles (UK)=== On 1 May 2007, a series of raids—Operation Achilles—took place against SHAC in Europe, involving 700 police officers in England, Amsterdam, and Belgium.Evers, Marco. [http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,517875,00.html "Resisting the Animal Avengers", Part 1], [http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,517875-2,00.html Part 2], ''Der Spiegel'', 19 November 2007. Thirty-two people were arrested, including Greg and Natasha Avery, and Heather Nicholson, who were charged with blackmail, along with nine others.[https://www.theguardian.com/animalrights/story/0,,2070273,00.html "Animal rights activists involved in bid to shut lab among 30 arrested in raids"], ''The Guardian'', 2 May 2007. The Averys pleaded guilty in July 2008, along with a co-accused Dan Amos. In October 2008 Trevor Holmes, Gerrah Selby, Daniel Wadham, Gavin Medd-Hall, and Heather Nicholson, who denied the charges, were sent to court.[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/92cf1796-93d2-11dd-b277-0000779fd18c.html "Activists in live testing trial deny blackmail"], ''The Financial Times'', 6 October 2008. Prosecutors told jurors that a 2007 meeting between the defendants had been bugged by police, and revealed that SHAC supported illegal acts that were traced to attacks on people across Great Britain. The prosecution also alleged there was evidence of direct email links between SHAC, the Animal Liberation Front, and Animal Rights Militia.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7655147.stm "Five deny animal rights blackmail "], BBC News, 6 October 2008. Holmes was acquitted but the other four were convicted. In January 2009, Nicholson was sentenced to 11 years imprisonment, Greg and Natasha to nine years, Medd-Hall to eight years, Wadham to five years, and Selby and Amos to four years.Yeoman, Fran. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article5558700.ece Jail for animal rights extremists who waged six-year blackmail campaign], ''The Times'', 21 January 2009. Injunctions called [[ASBO|Anti-Social Behaviour Order]]s were served on all seven, restricting their contact with companies targeted in the campaign.Bowcott, Owen. [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jan/21/huntingdon-animal-rights "Court jails Huntingdon animal test lab blackmailers"], ''The Guardian'', 21 January 2009. In 2009 ''The Sunday Times'' reported that Adrian Radford, a former soldier and gay rights activist, had befriended Natasha Avery and had been informing the police about the activity of senior SHAC members between 2004 and 2007.Grimston, Jack [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article5821799.ece "Animal terrorist group foiled by informant dressed as a beagle"], ''The Sunday Times'', 1 March 2009. ''Der Spiegel'' wrote that as a result of the police operation the number of attacks on HLS and associated businesses declined drastically, although the day after the convictions new posts on SHAC's website indicated that the campaign would continue.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/3920431/Animal-activists-still-continuing-campaign-of-threats-and-intimidation.html "Animal activists still continuing campaign of threats and intimidation"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 24 December 2008. ===2008 onwards=== In 2008, activists from various groups, including SHAC, [[Campaign against Highgate Rabbit Farm|targeted Highgate Rabbit Farm]] in [[Market Rasen]], Lincolnshire, which sold rabbits and ferrets to HLS and other laboratories; the ''Close Highgate Farm'' campaign included an ALF raid in which 129 rabbits were removed and £100,000-worth of property damaged.[http://www.marketrasenmail.co.uk/news/Animal-rights-activists-in-court.4627668.jp Animal rights activists in court], ''Market Rasen'', 24 October 2008. *[http://www.thisislincolnshire.co.uk/news/Rabbit-farm-raid-accused-quite-impressionable/article-953443-detail/article.html Rabbit farm raid accused 'impressionable'] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130505161112/http://www.thisislincolnshire.co.uk/news/Rabbit-farm-raid-accused-quite-impressionable/article-953443-detail/article.html |date=5 May 2013 }}, ''This Is Lincolnshire'', 1 May 2009. *[http://www.thisislincolnshire.co.uk/news/Rabbit-breeder-felt-sick-campaign/article-948679-detail/article.html "Rabbit breeder 'felt sick' at campaign"]{{dead link|date=June 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''Lincolnshire Echo'', 30 April 2009. In 2009, a new group, '''Militant Forces Against Huntingdon Life Sciences''', emerged in Germany and Switzerland, targeting Bayer staff, a Novartis director, the CEO of Pfizer, and Highgate farm, among others.[http://www.20min.ch/ro/news/suisse/story/-Vous-avez-deux-choix-Monsieur-Vasella--31713116 "Vous avez deux choix Monsieur Vasella"], 20 minutes online, Switzerland, 24 August 2009. *Rogers, David. [http://www.20min.ch/ro/news/suisse/story/-Vous-avez-deux-choix-Monsieur-Vasella--31713116 "Militant animal rights groups says behind Tyrol arson"], ''Austrian Times'', 6 August 2009. *Boyle, Catherine. [http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/health/article6742059.ece "Extremists' attacks on Novartis chief intensify"], ''The Times'', 7 August 2009. In 2010, five more members of SHAC pleaded guilty to criminal charges. Sarah Whitehead, Nicole Vosper and Thomas Harris plead guilty to conspiracy to blackmail; Jason Mullan and Nicola Tapping plead guilty to breaching section 145 of [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005|SOCPA]]. They were all jailed for between six years and fifteen months. ''The Times'' reported that their activities included "posting hoax bombs to homes and offices, making threats of violence, daubing abusive graffiti on property and sending used tampons in the post." Harris' sentence was extended after he, Maria Neal and Christopher Potter also pleaded guilty to additional charges relating to attacks on branches of [[Barclays]], including painting "ALF" on the buildings. At the time Barclays Asset Management was linked to HLS.Bloxham, Andy and Bingham, John. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8258311/Animal-rights-extremists-sentenced-for-attacks-on-Barclays-due-to-links-to-testing-laboratory.html Animal rights extremists sentenced for attacks on Barclays due to links to testing laboratory], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 14 January 2011. ==References== {{div col}} [https://www.npr.org/2011/03/03/134227726/data-graphics-population-of-the-communications-management-units DATA & GRAPHICS: Population Of The Communications Management Units], Margot Williams and Alyson Hurt, [[NPR]], 3 March 2011; retrieved 4 March 2011. {{div col end}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} ;External links *[http://www.shac.net SHAC website] *[http://www.huntingdon.com Huntingdon Life Sciences website] *[http://indymedia.org.uk/en/actions/2008/shac Indymedia UK SHAC topic page] *[http://www.shac7.com The Shac 7] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051029044713/http://www.shac.net/movies/crueltyfootage.mov The footage shot undercover inside HLS by PETA]; see [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZpZ-j5OU6rQ the same footage] on ''YouTube''. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071115162807/http://www.insidehls.com/insidehls.htm "Inside HLS"], describes five undercover investigations into HLS between 1989 and 2001 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080427023032/http://www.xenodiaries.org/index.html ''Diaries of Despair''], ''Uncaged Campaigns'', accessed 17 January 2011. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MNfuqLQrJak "Hit 'Em Head On"], SHAC, 9-minute video on ''YouTube'', 2006. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FP3ub3Dkfno "Time for Action 3"], SHAC, 4-minute video on ''YouTube'', 2005. ;Books and articles *Bhattacharya, Shaoni. [https://www.newscientist.com/news/news.jsp?id=ns99994913 Scientists demand law against animal rights extremism], ''New Scientist'', 22 April 2004. *British Home Office. [http://www.statewatch.org/news/2004/jul/animal-rights.pdf "Animal Welfare—Human Rights: protecting people from animal rights extremists"], July 2004. *Cox, Simon and Vadon, Richard. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4020235.stm "How animal rights took on the world"], BBC Radio 4, retrieved 18 June 2006. *{{cite journal|title=The SHAC Model: A Critical Assessment|pages=11–28|journal=[[Rolling Thunder (journal)|Rolling Thunder]]|author=[[CrimethInc. Ex-Workers Collective]]|issue=6|date=Fall 2006|url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/rollingthunder/shac.php}} *Gibson, Ian. [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200203/cmhansrd/vo030319/halltext/30319h01.htm Statement by Dr. Ian Gibson (Norwich, North)] ''Hansard'', 19 March 2003. *Robbins, John. [http://www.lawson-cruttenden.co.uk/articles/076_160804thelawyer.pdf "Red in Tooth and Law"], ''The Lawyer'', 16 August 2004. {{Refend}} {{Atestingend}} {{Animal rights|state=collapsed}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty}} [[Category:Animal rights movement]] [[Category:Animal Liberation Front]] [[Category:Eco-terrorism]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]] [[Category:Anti-vivisection movement]]
